story:
¿Qué es VERDEate.com?

Usamos la web y las redes sociales para generar impactos medioambientales positivos a través de Retos Verdes ¡Reta tu Lado Verde o el de tu empresa!

¿Para qué necesitamos recoger fondos en VERDEate.com?

Nuestra plataforma lleva 1 año de funcionamiento oficial y ya hemos reducido más de 74 toneladas de CO2 y ahorrado más de 1.8 millones de litros de agua a través de acciones voluntarias de nuestros usuarios aceptando Retos Verdes.

Queremos construir una aplicación Móvil para incrementar el alcance de Nuestros Retos Verdes, y así mismo, su impacto ambiental positivo en la región de habla hispana.

¿Qué necesitamos de ti?

  • Necesitamos que te registres en www.verdeate.com y empieces a aceptar Retos Verdes.
  • Necesitamos que nos apoyes con tus fondos para desarrollar el App.
  • También necesitamos que motives a tus amigos a hacer lo mismo.

¿Qué obtienes ayudando a VERDEate.com?

  • Satisfacción personal por ayudar a conservar nuestro planeta tierra a través de acciones sencillas y personales.
  • Recibirás acceso exclusivo a nuestro App para aceptar Retos Verdes y aprender de sostenibilidad en nuestra vida diaria.
  • Si no logramos la meta propuesta de recolección de fondos, igual estaremos tratando de desarrollar el App. 

¿Qué otras formas de ayudar existen?

  • Puedes ayudarnos a difundir la campaña a través de tus perfiles en Redes Sociales.

story:
I. Summary

I participated in a Sierra Club outing in Yunnan, China in October 2013. During the trip, I discovered Yuhu (玉湖), a farming village frozen in time, retaining the indigenous flavor of the local Naxi minority lifestyle and the profound cultural heritage of the region. I would like to help the villagers maintain their tradition and history through eco-education and  eco-friendly refuse management.

Yuhu is part of the UNESCO Cultural Heritage site of Lijiang.  The houses are built with unique rocks called “monkey head”, a mix of rocks and dried earth and straw, as they were in the early 20th century.  Beginning in 1922,  Dr. Joseph Rock , an Austrian-American botanist and geographer who subsequently introduced the area to the world (see multiple National Geographic articles), lived and researched the Yuhu  area for 27 years.  Today, there is a museum there, run down, but as testament to his work.

With the snow-covered Jade Dragon Mountain as its backdrop and numerous streams and rivers, Yuhu has become a prime tourist stop for locals and foreigners alike.  Unfortunately, visitors and locals often leave behind waste in the streets and in popular recreation areas such as the horse stable and mountain hiking trails.  The villagers need help in order to educate themselves and the tourists about ecotourism and refuse management, since the government has more pressing issues and is unable to give assistance with these matters.  


II. What We Need & What You Get

The projects I advocate will last from 1-2 years and cost $8,030 in total.  If the goal is not met, the project will be scaled down accordingly.  The project manager will donate some of her time to the projects as well.  One of the tasks of the project manager is to work with the village committees to introduce a small fee for horseback riding, with the proceeds going to sustaining the village ecological projects. 

Funds raised will be distributed in phases to the project manager with photo verification of work completed and periodic telephone calls.   

III. The Projects and Proposed Expenses

  Green Tourism Promotion - $8,030

   a. Tourist Education

.  Develop a detailed project plan

·  Locate a site for a Visitor Center/Information Center with the village committee, start renovation. (The village committee has already agreed to the project concept.)

·  Design, develop, prepare, and install a small local ecology exhibition.

·  Develop and place ecotourism signs around the village.

·  Purchase and place garbage cans in the parking lot and the riding stable. About 300  visitors come to Yuhu a day.

·  Provide “green” garbage bags (at US 2c/ea) to horeseback riding customers for 6 months. Subsequent funding will be provided by the villagers. 

    b. Villager Training

·  Prepare material/handbook to promote the concepts of ecology and waste recycling and management

·  Recruit and train volunteer guides to advocate environmental conservation and refuse management   

·  Conduct 9 workshops at 9 sub-villages and with 220 families primarily those who operate horse stables, on the concept of ecotourism 

(A subsequent project will provide similar ecology training to elementary school children.  Fundraising for this project will begin after the successful completion of the current project.)

IV. The Impact

If this project is successful, Yuhu can become a model village for other areas where similar issues have arisen.  This campaign has a high likelihood of success because it will be directed and run by an experienced, Chinese, Naxi native environmentalist and a villager of Yuhu.  Ms Lushan Jizhen He has worked with conservation and tourism companies on education programs and ecotourism projects under the umbrella of the Nature Conservancy.  She is fluent in Mandarin, Naxi, and English and an excellent communicator.  Since Ms He has prior experience working with the local village communities and government agencies, she can share successes and help others initiate similar programs elsewhere. Currently, with her husband, she manages a café and hostel in the heart of Yuhu, an ideal tourist stop.
 
IV. Other Ways You Can Help 

If you cannot donate but you would like to help, please spread the word to other people about this campaign. Look up “Yuhu, Yunnan” on the Internet to appreciate the beauty and the uniqueness of this place.  Learn about the minorities in China, such as the Naxis.  Please keep us in mind, in case you change your mind about donating.  Thanks for your time.

story:
Our project is a 2 hour documentary called Ancient Tomorrow.


Imagine if we'd found evidence of an ancient power technology capable of producing free and safe sustainable energy for everyone.  We've teamed up with several engineers and archaeologists who believe we've done just that. We are creating a 2 hour documentary on location in some of the most ancient sites on the planet.  Egypt, Peru, Bolivia may hold secrets to an ancient technology we have lost for thousands of years.


In 2 hours, we will present stunning evidence from some of the least explored sites in the world.  These sites hold some amazing and real technologies that could affect the future of free energy technology.


What We Need & What You Get

To fully fund this project fully, we will need $500,000 dollars. 

We will raise as much as we can through this site in order to continue the process and tap into all of our options. 


We will need to cover the cost of production, including travel, permits and food, not to mention the post-production process which includes some visual effects to highlight the scientific breakthroughs we will be discussing.


We will also be raising money through corporate sponsors and advertising, but every dollar counts and we would like this project to be unfettered by the hands of corporate greed!  The more we can raise via everyday citizens like you, the more control we will have over the topics discussed and breakthroughs we can share.


If we cannot raise the $50,000 we are asking for on this site, we will continue to search for grants, other donations, and sponsors until we raise the money we need to shoot this documentary with the highest quality and integrity.


In return we will be offering some cool and unique perks including Skype Chats with the cast, Watching the movie before it is released online, and even a camping expedition with Adventurer and Chemist, JJ Yosh.


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate $1, like our page on Facebook, share the link to our page and spread the word about this powerful documentary that will shed light on one of the greatest possibilities of the new millennium: Free Energy.

story:
SLUMCHELLA started as a plan for an epic event.  Our aim was to bring musicians from all around the world to Kenya to perform in one rural village and one urban slum to rally a grassroots opposition to the displacement of 1 million indigenous people by a massive hydroelectric dam.  Due to a recent pledge by the Kenyan government to SUPPORT the dam, widespread violence across the north and a total information blackout regarding the dam and its impact, it has become clear that the event is currently neither possible nor wise. In response to the situation, we changed strategy- scaling down to maximize impact. A team of 2 filmmakers, 1 photographer and a writer are going to the Turkana province of northern Kenya to investigate and record the ongoing displacement of nearly 1 million indigenous tribesmen by the development of the GIBE 3 dam.  Our goal is to bring the story onto the world stage, using our tools as artists and journalists.  The product of this mission will be a compelling media piece to be used by any organization that opposes the destruction of some of mankind's last, functional indigenous communities along with the precious environment in which they have lived since the origin of our species.




Let us first introduce ourselves. We are VILLAGE BEAT- a California-based collective of artists and activists who work to protect the rights of Kenya's indigenous tribes. Our credo: Art as action.

In the spirit of fighting for a cause that matters to all of humanity, regardless of status or wealth- we are democratizing our fundraising effort. 


We are asking for $3 from a few thousand of you.


We need you to help us protect the rights of Kenya's indigenous people. 


Your action will cost less than the price of a gallon of gas. A latte. An organic avocado. An hour and a half of public parking. We reason that $3 is a significant contribution that nearly everyone can make. But your involvement doesn't stop there. You are about to become part of a movement. 

Along with $3, we need your voice to send this message as far and wide as possible; to ask everyone you know to do the same. Born in this way, SLUMCHELLA will be our performance, you see?  We will all be on stage together, making art and demanding justice.


While the posted $36,000 goal reflects our previous needs to put on two concerts, our new goal is $10,000.

The funds we raise will go to:

1.  Hard expenses of getting our team of 5 to Kenya. 

2.  Transporting and sustaining the team during the trip from Nairobi to Lake Turkana and back. 


VILLAGE BEAT (click here) is a California-Registered 501(c)(3) Non-Proft Organization.
All donations are tax-deductible.

Our ability to cover the story and produce a compelling media piece depends entirely on reaching our new goal.


In gratitude for your contribution and participation in spreading the word, you get the Calif Sessions EP (about 20 minutes of original music) recorded by Village Beat last year in Nairobi with the MCs of the Calif Records crew.  Original genge ("people's music") heard nowhere else before.  




Beginning in the early-1800's, Native Americans were forcibly removed from their homelands to accomodate the expansion of European-American settlement. Sitting Bull, chief of the Hunkpapa Lakota Sioux, an icon of strength and resistance, was one of the last to surrender in 1881 to the US Army, after resisting confinement to a reservation and dependence on US Indian Agency relief for over 20 years. 

Today, the indigenous tribes of East Africa face a similar ultimatum: surrender and abandon your land and way of life, or stay and die. 

In this lifetime, we have the clarity to look back on the darkest hours of our history with deep regret for the destruction and irreplaceable loss of entire cultures. In this lifetime, we can act to prevent it from happening again.  



The GIBE 3 dam will be a man-made disaster that will exceed the scale of the famine we've witnessed this year in Somalia, which has led to the displacement of at least 500,000 Somalis, now living in the world's largest refugee camp, Dadaab in eastern Kenya. The relief effort has cost over $1 billion. $1 billion of life support for victims of a crisis that has already occurred. $1 billion that could have been spent on crisis prevention and the development of sustainable infrastructure. SLUMCHELLA is an action to prevent a future crisis of an additional 1 million displaced people. So we ask, $36,000 now to spark a movement or billions later?


Think of GIBE 3 dam as an earthquake, a tsunami, a hurricane, or an oil spill that will forever erase the way of life of some of mankind's last indigenous people. Now realize that, unlike the sudden catastrophes of recent years that have cost millions of lives, we can see this one coming. In fact, it can even be stopped.





The role we will play in this saga is to produce a compelling media piece that will be utilized by our organization and others who oppose the GIBE 3 dam.


The epic tale of GIBE 3 is not a secret. Despite a total lack of environmental or social impact assessments, the project moves forward. Most remarkable is that there has been no attempt to mobilize the coalition that actually has the power to stop the project. That coalition is comprised of the affected communities and those of us who live in a 'mediacratic' society with the power to sound the alarm and influence policy.


Discussion Forum to produce a People's Statement of Indigenous Rights:

In the Turkana communities, we will hold discussion forums between local and tribal leaders, research groups and human rights organizations to inform the communities about the impact of GIBE 3 dam- many for the first time. The aim of these forums is to produce a video and written Peopleâ€™s Statement of Rights to be delivered to the Kenyan Government.

 

Our specific demands to the Kenyan government will include the following:

1. To prevent the construction of the GIBE 3 dam (by whatever means are determined to be most effective by                                                               the Kenyan government), until certifiable third-party environmental and social impact assessments have been conducted and are found to be agreeable to all concerned parties.

 

2.  To formally pledge to abstain from purchasing electricity generated by the GIBE 3 dam, thereby rendering the project economically inviable.

 

3.  To prepare a contingency plan that is informed by - and in the interest of - the displaced Kenyan citizens, in the event that the GIBE 3 dam project is completed.

 

The plan shall include:

a.         Temporary crisis-mitigation infrastructure (water, food, security, shelter, sanitation, medical facility access, communication) for 400,000-1 million people, over a minimum period of 5 years.

b.         Measures to provide a sustainable, alternative way of life for the displaced nomad/pastoralist and lake-dependent communities (permanent alternative water solutions, permanent resettlement and land-use agreements, education facilities, local economy development assistance and cultural preservation).


CLICK HERE FOR REFERENCES AND THE LATEST REPORTS ON THE GIBE 3 DAM



**CLICK HERE TO SEE US COME TO LYF**

story:
Thank You for your Support!

We like to thank all backers who supported our campaign!
Your generosity will contribute in the rebuild of our plant nurseries, which are holding a rare collection of Lao native plants. With your help we are able to continue our work in maintaining this collection and continue our research on these plant species. 

We will keep all our backers updated about the progress of the construction of our new nurseries. 

Thank you again for your support!

With all the best, 

PTK Team 

Heavy storm destroyed our rare and endangered plant nurseries!

In the afternoon of March the 3rd a heavy storm destroyed 2 plant nurseries at the Pha Tad Ke Botanical Garden in Luang Prabang Laos. The nurseries are housing a rare collection of native Lao plant species, like Orchids, Carnivore plants and ferns. Since these specimens require a shaded area to grow, immediate action to rebuild these facilities is required.

Pha Tad Ke is a Non-Profit organisation and not funded by the government, all incomes to run the daily operations and projects are covered with entrance fees and donations. Since we don't have adequate funds available to rebuild our destroyed nurseries we need you help!

 

We Need You HELP!!!!

We need to raise a minimum of $5000 to rebuild the basic structures of our plant nurseries to be able to give the proper care our sensitive plant collection requires. Specially our native Orchid collection contains many rare and some endangered species. 

 

The Mission of Pha Tad Ke is:

The Mission of Pha Tad Ke is to stimulate a fundamental change of awareness that leads towards a holistic view of nature and society for sustainable ecological and biodiversity conservation.

Our four main goals are:

  • Research, Educate, Show and Preserve the Flora and Ethnobotany of Laos
  • Promote Sustainable Organic Farming to Mitigate Effects of Global Warming and Support Biodiversity Conservation
  • Promote and Develop Green Tourism Projects in Luang Prabang and the RegionDevelop and Promote Art and Cultural Programs to Engage a New Generation in Creative and Intelligible Thinking

For more information about our garden and our projects please visit our Website.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please get the word out on social media and make some noise about your campaign. We appreciate your help!!!

story:
Animal Rescue Special Unit (A.R.S.U.) is a lately –two years– formed group of volunteers, with aim to uncage and/or rescue animals in great danger (in avenues, motorways, rain gutters, trees, etc)  and so far has rescued 201 animals form certain death at 197 incidents.

 

For further information, photos and videos of A.R.S.U. (in Greek E. M. A. Z.), please visit our page in Facebook https://www.facebook.com/EMAZ.NGO/ 

in YouTube

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCg5pIY9vXo4sEA...

 

We are not able to respond at any occurrence, mainly because of financial problems and unfortunately our unit has temporarily quite its operation. In order to organize better, we need financial support so as to replace most of our tools and equipment, since they are already due and defective.

 

We, as unit, therefore, ask for your help to cover the cost of equipment (special rescuing tools and kits), as well as fixed operating expenses. Even one (1) euro from all of our followers and of those participate in each rescue and support our mission can make a big difference to the unit’s operational capacity and enable us to save more animals in danger.

 

 

We are in immediate need for the below mentioned equipment, that helps us to act safely:

 

1) Means of our transportation = 10000.00 -

https://www.google.gr/search?q=rescue+truck&amp...

 

2) Mountaineering / Climbing Equipment = 8000.00 -

https://www.google.gr/search?q=climbing+gear&am...

 

3) Heavy Type Tools: Drilling - Drill - Tillers = 5000.00 -

https://www.google.gr/search?q=climbing+gear&am...

 

4) Personnel‘s personal protection items = 8000.00 -

http://servicescompanyinc.com/uploads/3/4/4/0/3...

 

5) Rescue Tools - Evacuation of Animals = 5000.00 -

Http://www.animal-care.com

 

All the related costs will be evidenced with the respective proof. Moreover, the respective depositors will be periodically notified of the purchase receipts.

 

Here are the emails and accounts of the online service PayPal, where you may deposit any amount:

 

1.      Email: E.M.A.Z@outlook.com -

               Beneficiary Account: Chris K. Michalopoulos -

Alpha Bank, Greece: IBAN GR51 0140 9600 9600 0231 0020 175, Beneficiary Account: Chris K. Michalopoulos

National Bank of Greece, Greece: IBAN GR12 0110 3820 0000 3827 4779 024, Beneficiary Account: Chris K. Michalopoulos

 

Please feel free to state the details of the deposit with a private message to our pages, indicating with detailed reference (Name, Last Name, Telephone Number).

 

Thank you all for all that you offer in Animal Rescue Special Unit (A.R.S.U.) - E. M. A. Z.

 

Because all individually and together, we can!

 

Thank you,

Administration of Animal Rescue Special Unit (A.R.S.U.) - E. M. A. Z.

story:
Short Summary

We started Urbanized in Washington, DC in July 2017. The idea arose when we remembered the days we worked together at Starbucks during college. The daily amount of coffee thrown away in the trash made a lasting impression on us and sparked the idea to repurpose waste into useful products.

We first entered the market in July 2017 with three prototypes made from recycled coffee grounds: exfoliating soap, fertilizer, and wood stain and sold them at different farmers' markets. The exfoliating soaps were the bestsellers and we decided to fully focus on improving our soaps and expanded our sales channel to coffee shops. After learning from our customer interaction, we created a gift set that contains 3 travel size soaps — all-natural, no palm oil, no animal cruelty. In November 2017, we switched our full focus on e-commerce and grew our social media presence. Since then, we successfully launched our soap on Amazon and Tundra: A natural exfoliating soap made from repurposed coffee grounds which reduces the appearance of cellulite and stretch marks and helps alleviate eczema, psoriasis, and dermatitis. Our product has 70 positive reviews rated 4.5 out of 5.0 stars on Amazon. In 2018. we successfully completed the Bethesda Green accelerator program.

We recently established local partnerships to collect orange peels, teas, and flowers. We want you to be the first to try our cool new products before we launch them on Amazon. Your purchase will help us order the raw materials necessary to make these awesome products.
 

What We Need & What You Get

The money raised will be used to purchase two things: our uniquely designed shipping boxes and raw ingredients. That's it! It goes without saying that the more money we raise, the better prices we can get at higher volumes. 

You would be the first backers to try our natural and eco-friendly soaps made from black tea, passion fruit tea, orange peels, rose petals, or eucalyptus leaves! 

We normally sell our gift set for 12.95 on Amazon. If you purchase a 3-month supply, you'll receive a 35% discount, and if you purchase a 6-month supply, you'll receive a 50% discount! 
 

The Impact

We repurpose waste into eco-friendly products with a vision of living in a zero-waste world ?. 

It is estimated that only 1/3 of the organic waste in landfills is recycled and the remaining 2/3s are incinerated and end up in the atmosphere as methane gas, largely contributing to greenhouse gas emissions. 

Our goal is to reinvent the way we see and manage waste. Your purchase helps divert this waste into useful cool new products that customers can benefit from!
 

Risks & Challenges

Our goal is to ship the product right in time for the holiday season and we will certainly do our best to achieve this goal. There is, however, a small change that some orders may be shipped after the holiday season in case we encounter external factors that may delay our production process for whatever reason. 
 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to purchase our product, please share this campaign on social media! You may find us @urbanizedbeauty across all platforms. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts!

story:
With your help, we can continue to contribute to creating and growing happy communities. 

What We Do

As the Unknown Gardener I've been planting symbols and flower arrangements around the expressway in Kitchener Waterloo area for the past seven years. You may have seen our work in the following areas:

  • 2008 400 Daffodils by Conestoga Mall exit (by the Lexington Rd bridge)
  • 2009 500 Daffodiles by the northbound ramp of the Wellington st cutoff (now barely visible)
  • 2010  650 Purple Alyums in a giant heart shape by the Frederick st cutoff that only came up one year
  • 2011  375 hyacyinths by the Lancaster street bridge which were destroyed by bridge construction
  • 2012  450 daffodils just past the Fischer-Hallman cut off
  • 2013  Another 250 daffodils to fill in the original design by Conestoga Mall
  • 2014 350 daffodils by the Lancaster street bridge
  • 2015 With your contribution, the biggest planting yet.

Why We Do It

I started doing this to add a bit of fun and happiness to residents if only for a few seconds in hope that they will share their good mood with others they meet. After a long, cold winter I wanted to do something to brighten everyone's day and thought flowers would be the best way. Who doesn't like flowers? My goal is to have something in bloom along the expressway all spring/summer/fall but it's a lot of work and turns out to be a lot of money.

Why Contribute?

So far, I've been buying supplies almost entirely by myself. In order to get even close to my goal, I need your help. Past plant designs cost between $350 and $500. With your help I can take my planting to a new level.  

Currently I plant with bulbs (daffodils seem to be the only bulbs that come up year after year) but hearty bulbs typically bloom in spring. Seeds typically don't "take unless you have time to nurture them. Due to our Guerrilla Gardening techniques, we are in and out of the planting site in under 20 minutes. To have something bloom in different times of the season, I need to plant actual plants. Plants are far more expensive than bulbs. I'd like to begin with Black Eyed Susan's and Day Lilies which cost between $2 - $3 each and to make it visible from the road, I'll need to plant at least 400 - 500. If the $1500 goal is met, I'll plant both kinds of flower.

Is this legal?

Probably not; sometimes you have to bend a few harmless rules to make everyone smile.
story_txt:
With your help, we can continue to contribute to creating and growing happy communities. 

What We Do
 As the Unknown Gardener I've been planting symbols and flower arrangements around the expressway in Kitchener Waterloo area for the past seven years. You may have seen our work in the following areas:   2008 400 Daffodils by Conestoga Mall exit (by the Lexington Rd bridge)
 2009 500 Daffodiles by the northbound ramp of the Wellington st cutoff (now barely visible)
 2010  650 Purple Alyums in a giant heart shape by the Frederick st cutoff that only came up one year

2011  375 hyacyinths by the Lancaster street bridge which were destroyed by bridge construction 

2012  450 daffodils just past the Fischer-Hallman cut off 

2013  Another 250 daffodils to fill in the original design by Conestoga Mall
2014 350 daffodils by the Lancaster street bridge

2015 With your contribution, the biggest planting yet.
  Why We Do It
 I started doing this to add a bit of fun and happiness to residents if 
only for a few seconds in hope that they will share their good mood with others they meet. After a long, cold winter I wanted to do 
something to brighten everyone's day and thought flowers would be the best way. Who doesn't like flowers? My goal is to have something in 
bloom along the expressway all spring/summer/fall but it's a lot of work and turns out to be a lot of money.
Why Contribute?
So far, I've been buying supplies almost entirely by myself. In order to get even close to my goal, I need your help. Past plant designs cost between $350 and $500. With your help I can take my planting to a new level.  
Currently I plant with bulbs (daffodils seem to be the only bulbs that come up year after year) but hearty bulbs typically bloom in spring. Seeds typically don't "take unless you have time to nurture them. Due to our Guerrilla Gardening techniques, we are in and out of the planting site in under 20 minutes. To have something bloom in different times of the season, I need to plant actual plants. Plants are far more expensive than bulbs. I'd like to begin with Black Eyed Susan's and Day Lilies which cost between $2 - $3 each and to make it visible from the road, I'll need to plant at least 400 - 500. If the $1500 goal is met, I'll plant both kinds of flower.   Is this legal?
Probably not; sometimes you have to bend a few harmless rules to make everyone smile.

story:
About 25zero


Melting glacial ice is one of the clearest indicators of climate change. Nowhere is this more apparent than where you’d least expect to find ice – at the equator, where 25 mountains still have a glacier. Within a quarter of a century these glaciers will be gone due to climate change - in some cases, far sooner. Put simply 25 mountains zero latitude, 25 years zero ice – 25zero

25zero is an adventure/environment/multimedia project with 3 key goals:

1.  Summit to Summit 

25zero teams will climb 6 of the 25zero mountains during the UN climate change talks in Paris (COP21) December 2015 (a mountain in each country they are located in). 

The teams will transmit live images and video footage of the rapidly disappearing glaciers from the summits of these mountains into the COP 21 conference and to global media outlets powerfully highlighting the urgency of the issue. 

This is the 21st annual COP meeting and the goal is to get a meaningful, legally binding climate change deal finally agreed. 

Project leader Tim Jarvis is a world-renowned adventurer and environmental scientist and will personally climb 3 of these mountains: Carstensz Pyramid in Asia, Mount Stanley in Africa’s Rwenzori Mountains and Chimborazo in South America. 

2.  Climb it. Change.

For those who can’t get to the mountains, the 25zero ‘virtual climb’ App means you can still get involved. 

Climber data (including voice logs) will be captured periodically by the climbers to augment data captured and stored (including GPS coordinates, altitude, still images and video). This information will then be relayed and embedded into an App so ‘virtual climbers’ can share in the experience of climbing these mountains with Tim and his teams.

The App will enable users to choose the difficulty level of the mountain they want to climb. Users can also undertake their own personal challenge or race friends or colleagues. Reaching certain ‘event points’ on the mountain unlocks interesting stories, facts and footage about the mountains, the people, plants and animals that live there and what can be done about climate change.

Competition is invited between participants with the goal to raise money for our charity partner, WWF. The fundraising functionality directs campaign proceeds directly to WWF climate change projects and sharing of the experience via social media.

WWF climate change initiatives include community forestry projects, renewable energy projects and projects designed to change community behaviour amongst others.

 Do it as a personal challenge or as part of a team whilst getting fit and fighting climate change. Just Climb it!


3.  Your voice 

25zero’s website, original online content, social media program and the virtual climb App will engage with large numbers of people not currently engaged in the issue. It will provide both useful information and interesting stories on climate change, as well as the current state of action/ inaction and crucially, what you can do to make a difference. 

The goal is to engage with more people and focus on solutions we can all contribute towards rather than a message of negativity and despair. This includes a petition, information that demystifies climate change and what can be done about it. 

What We Need

The cost of the climbs, including travel and logistics have been covered, the App has been funded and the 25zero team is working on the project pro bono. 

In order to create major media pressure on decision makers and to provide WWF with the opportunity to raise more funds for their work however we need your help. 

We need resources to ensure the transmission of realtime images and messages from the mountains along the equator directly to the world's leaders at COP21. This includes:

  • Bandwidth to get images from some of the highest and most remote mountains in the world to a global audience
  • On the ground, in-country support
  • Media mobilisation and logistics
  • Some communications equipment costs
  • Messaging via mass media and social media platforms


What You Get

For your contribution you get to be part of a project that focuses the attention of millions of people not currently engaged with climate change on the issue. 

You will take part in recording history, helping us capture images and video of these unique glacial environments before they melt and to record the stories of the people, plants and animals that rely on them for their survival .

You will also be helping us to put pressure on global decision makers to save us from the worst effects of climate change for the benefit of us all. We will be doing this by using these glacier's decline as a clear visual indicator of this complex global issue. There is momentum and the time for action is now.

A range of 'perks' has been developed as our way of saying 'thank you' for your valuable contribution.


The Impact

A lot of noise, misinformation and media fatigue exists around the issue of climate change whilst the carbon trajectory the world is on is the wrong one. 25zero provides an exciting, unique way of reaching large numbers of people not engaged with the issue, whilst influencing key global decision makers and getting kids and the public involved via the 25zero virtual climb App. 

In summary:

  • 25zero wants to ensure a legally binding climate change agreement is reached at the COP21 climate change talks, with various state, federal and NGO partners helping ensure our glacier melt images and messages are powerfully put across in support of this goal. 
  • 25zero will contribute massive media awareness about COP21 given how newsworthy and interesting the project is. It influences not only those in attendance at COP21 but also focuses global attention on COP21 letting them know that the world is watching and expects a result.
  • Ongoing media attention around 25zero’s climbs into 2016 and 2017 will ensure a continued sense of urgency about turning any agreement that is reach at COP21 into actual on-ground action. Ie how to deliver on any commitments made and actually reduce the amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.
  • 25zero will raise money for WWF climate change projects that are making a difference. These include community forestry projects, renewable energy projects and projects designed to change community behaviour amongst others.


Risks & Challenges

The biggest risk associated with 25zero is its not going ahead. This will not happen as 25zero has raised money to cover the costs of teams climbing the mountains and in developing the App, website and social media campaign. The main risk we face is that without your help we will not get the message out as far and wide as it needs to.

The bigger risk is that COP21 does not result in a meaningful climate change agreement and that climate change continues unchecked. The world’s nations have meet once a year for 20 years and to date not agreed on a way forward. This time must be different.

Compared to this, the risks associated with 25zero are minimal. Climbing mountains involves some risks but the men and women that form the climb teams are experienced and dedicated to the cause. They take responsibility for their actions and believe in trying to set a positive example of what can be done, highlighting the changes that are happening and committing to do something about it. 

Project leader Tim Jarvis has a proven track record in delivering on what is promised and in pulling off some of the most audacious expeditions ever undertaken. His most recent expedition was an authentic retracing of the polar survival journey of Sir Ernest Shackleton – the original was described as "the greatest survival journey of all time" by the first man to climb Mount Everest, Sir Edmund Hillary. Tim’s team used the same equipment and clothing as Shackleton had 100 years ago. 

Tim uses his expeditions and work to promote progressive thinking in the area of climate change and biodiversity loss and is an environmental scientist, and WWF-Australia Global Ambassador.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't manage a financial contribution to 25zero we urge you to spread the word! 

  • Like us and share on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and Vimeo!
  • Share this campaign with your communities and ask them to donate! (don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!)

Climb it. Change. Let’s do something about it.


* Carstensz Pyramid images courtesy of Mike Roberts -Adventure Consultants

story:
Hi, My name is Mike and this video shows what we do. You can see how many butts were collected over the winter. I want to get The Sidewalk Buttler on the all sidewalks we walk on.

The plan is pretty simple...

 If you are tired of all the litter and poisons that are thrown in the streets and waterways then you are able to help.

 We are asking for funds to ramp up the sales, manufacturing and distribution of the Buttlers and bring the program to the cities and towns you live in.

 Somewhere nearby, each summer, there is a group effort to clean up a park or beach where we live. This is a great method to involve people in caring about the communities that we live in. Everybody goes out on a sunny Saturday or Sunday to pick up and clean up and get a Tee shirt for the days labor and commitment. 

Then come Monday, the habits and the trash  are right back, because you haven't provided any alternatives to the previous actions. 

In other words, the butts are back again! 

The Buttlers provide a year round,energy free alternative to the littering problem in a clean concise fashion, that doesn't interfere with any maintenance programs such as sweeping, snow removal or grass cutting. 

Each Buttler will hold about 600 butts before needing to be emptied and recycled. This is equivalent to 30 packs of butts off the ground .

Who can use a Sidewalk Butler?

  • If you have or work in a store, office, library, sandwich shop, museum, hair salon, coffee shop...
  • If you have or manage an office building, hotel, motel, apartments, parking lot ,bus stop...
  • If you have a Restaurant or Bar,candy store, pizza place, bakery
  • Basically anywhere people and the outdoors meet
  • If you don't have a location, buy one and we will find a spot that can use it


What We Need and Why

We will use the monies raised to fulfill the initial orders placed for the Buttlers. The machinery and tooling are already in place. While those orders are  moving forward, we will take the balance of the cash to complete the following:

  • Build an E-commerce website to bring the Buttlers to the web.
  • Complete our Non-Profit application and launch UrbanCare ,the name of the new company
  • Market to cities, towns, civic groups, businesses and supportive  concerns to help them build their own programs to implement The SideWalk Buttlers on their own sidewalks.
  •  Create jobs with the development of these programs, and eventually bring the marketing and manufacturing aspect to areas directly served by the Buttlers.


The Impact on our sidewalks and waterways

These few components  will make a difference:

     All butts are recycled 100% for free by TerraCycle. 

"2012 was another record year for TerraCycle. It marked the 9th straight year of revenue growth as well as the launch of the world’s first recycling program for one of the most commonly littered items on the planet – cigarette butts. After launching the program in Canada in May, it was quickly expanded to the US and Spain with help from Santa Fe Natural Tobacco and British American Tobacco, respectively. The collected cigarette butts are recycled into plastic pellets and used to make industrial products like shipping pallets." Quote from TerraCycle website

The way this works is pretty simple. First, register on TerraCycle. You will find many,many others items that are eligible for recycling there in addition to  butts. Once a collection of butts are gathered, you print off a prepaid shipping tag. Put the butts in a (recycled)plastic bag, pop them in a cardboard shipping box(again recycled), slap on the tag and you're all done. Your account will be credited for the amount and you build up points for something in the future. What a great idea!!

Quantitative Results 

We will be able to track and measure the results of the recycling program.  Someone said, "If you don't write it down, it doesn't exist, If you write it down, you can measure it"  


Jobs, Jobs, Jobs

The next component is very special to me...My personal  goal is to get this initial Maine operation fully staffed and run by our veterans. We'll build systems for sales, manufacturing and distribution of the Buttlers throughout the country using this first shop as a model.

Then we'll set up shops in each State to provide jobs for our Vets. I fully believe that we can take the concept of the Buttlers and provide work, respect and hope to those who have served.

 In addition,each location will serve as an incubator/workshop for ideas for future businesses for our Vets. There's a huge resource of unfulfilled and paid for talent waiting to be unleashed. There just needs to be the opportunity to grow it  " Enlist a Buttler - Employ a Veteran"

There is no reason that we can't take this Buttler concept and apply it to every city and town in the US. Talk about scalable!! 

Show me a sidewalk that couldn't benefit from a Buttler standing vigil.        What beach, pier, boardwalk or waterway couldn't use a way to help keep itself free from butts.

If I can get these results in the video from just a few Buttlers, imagine what this First in the Nation campaign could do to your city or town ?  


Other Ways You Can Help

If you know someone  that needs a Buttler, get them  on line, find us and buy one. Tell everyone you know what's up!! 

Forward this message to everyone on your mailing lists. This is inspiring to read, not the usual "junk" mail.  

If you don't want a Buttler of your own, but want to help, then donations are greatly appreciated. There is a lot of work to be done, and all of it requires some money to complete.

story:
Summary of the Project and its Impact

The Youth Leadership Program (YLP) of Fenner Nature Center  is a group of 12-18 year old leaders who love nature and love teaching others about the natural world!  Over the last year, YLP members have been planning and designing a natural playscape which will be built within Fenner Nature Center’s grounds.  The playscape will allow kids to play creatively while enjoying all that nature has to offer.  It will offer a bridge between playing in a playground the local park, and free-play in the natural world.  It will be built of natural materials and will blend into the forest.

It’s crucial for the current generation of children to get away from video games, t.v. screens, plastic toys, and sterile environments.  Kids need to go outside and experience the living world.  Studies continue to show that it is important for children’s (and adults!) own health and sense of well-being to have an attachment to the land.  Nature is a great place for parents and children to bond and create memories.  It’s also the place where kids can grow to appreciate the outdoors and develop into stewards of it.

As Richard Louv (author of Last Child in the Woods) has said:

Passion is lifted from the earth itself by the muddy hands of the young; it travels along grass-stained sleeves to the heart. If we are going to save environmentalism and the environment, we must also save an endangered indicator species: the child in nature.


What YLP Needs

Members of YLP are passionate about encouraging other kids to get out in the natural world to explore and learn!  But, in order to build the playscape, we need your help!  We will need to buy materials to make the playscape a reality. 

 The total project cost is $2390 but, we have already secured nearly $1000 in materials, equipment and design services  by selling  bake sale items, apples,  and postcards at the Apple Butter Festival in October 2013. However, we still have a ways to go and could use your help!

Here is a partial list of the items we will need to purchase:

Lag Bolts

Cement

Rain barrel

Hand Pump

Pond liner

Plywood for interpretive sign

Plywood for bird blind

Paint

Painting supplies

4 x 4 posts

Cargo Net

Willowscape Willow Trees

Bobcat Rental


How You Can Help!

Please donate if you can.  Even $5 -10 will make a difference toward reaching our goal.  If you can’t contribute at this time, but would still like to help us, please considering sharing this Indiegogo campaign with others who you think might be able to help!   We also need help to begin the building of the playscape at Fenner’s Earth Day Extravaganza on April 19, 2014.  Thank you!

the young; it travels along grass-stained sleeves to the heart. If we are going
to save environmentalism and the environment, we must also save an endangered
indicator species: the child in nature.
What YLP Needs
Members of YLP are passionate about encouraging other kids to get out in the natural world to explore and learn! 
But, in order to build the playscape, we need your help!  We will need to buy materials to make the
playscape a reality.  The total project cost is $2390 but, we have already secured nearly $1000 in materials, equipment and design services  by selling  bake sale items, apples,  and postcards at the Apple Butter Festival in October 2013. However, we still have a ways to go and could use your help! 
Here is a partial list of the items we will need to
purchase:
Lag BoltsCement
Rain barrel
Hand Pump
Pond liner
Plywood for interpretive sign
Plywood for bird blind
Paint
Painting supplies
4 x 4 postsCargo NetWillowscape Willow TreesBobcat Rental


How You Can Help!
Please donate if you can. 
Even $5 -10 will make a difference toward reaching our goal.  If you can’t contribute at this time, but
would still like to help us, please considering sharing this Indiegogo campaign
with others who you think might be able to help!   We
also need help to begin the building of the playscape at Fenner’s Earth Day Extravaganza
on April 19, 2014.  Thank you!

story:
Our Story

My name is Wawi Amasha. I was raised in a small village in the Embu region of Kenya. I am an artist, designer, and cultural activist.

My life in the village taught me so much about the very basics that are so crucial for living. From the time I can remember, I was learning things like weaving, making musical instruments, farming, dancing, hunting, fetching firewood, grazing cattle and so much more. One of the things I miss the most was the communal spirit of the people working together for the greater well being of everyone around. The fact that it took more than a village to raise a child showed a commitment and love that people had for each other. Now like in many places in the western world, people are more divided and even worse of, living in abject poverty.

I moved to California 16 years ago. My life, here in America, is so different from the village I grew up in. The lack of real community, the lack of respect for elders, the lack of respect for the environment and the lack of respect for each other saddens my soul. But it is not just happening in America. I go home regularly, and I notice the changes. The villages are turning in to deserts. The land has been overgrazed by livestock and the community members have cut down nearly every tree for firewood. Often the few trees standing are not even native to Kenya, or Africa for that matter. I see the need for change. My home needs to be “re-activated.”

The important aspects of our traditions and environment need to be taught again for they are being lost completely in the quest for a “better life.” We had a better life and we were fooled in to believing it was primitive and uncivilized. There is always room to grow, but it doesn't have to come at the cost of changes an entire way of life that worked very well for the people. Let me ask you this, is it more civilized to live in a community that lives at one with nature and and comes together to care for those in need or is it more civilized to spend half of a nation’s wealth on warfare while people go jobless and hungry with no one to turn to? 

Africa needs a lot of healing!

This healing starts when each one of us acknowledges the need for that healing. Then, we can re-activate Africa to it's original state of abundance.

My art is about the celebration of life. I express this universal (truth) energy through the use of vibrant colors with the intent of preserving the beauty of African cultures and traditions. My art is my way of communicating the important role Africa has to play in the our global community


The Impact

My goal is to buy raw land in Kenya and build a village of mud huts/houses that will serve as a living space as well as a cultural resource center for conscious art, fair trade, and eco-friendly agriculture. The purpose of this center is to re-activate the spirit of working together and consciously using the natural resources to create goods. It will also be a communal place for people to exchange skills and ideas that will facilitate a healthy and meaningful lifestyle, beyond basic survival. The center will offer workshops and projects for people from villages throughout Kenya and will involve learning skills such as:

Agriculture: organic farming, permaculture and holistic grazing management. The emphasis will focus on growing nutritious crops for the community more than growing cash crops that garner little money for the farmer, while destroying ecosystems and using enormous amounts of water.

Environmentally sustainable practices: Collecting rainwater and learning to irrigate on a small scale in order to save some crops in case of rain shortage. Picking up trash, harvesting solar energy for cooking so we can stop cutting trees for firewood and charcoal and concentrate more on re-planting native trees, food baring trees, medicinal trees and re-activating the soils.

Traditional crafts: Basket weaving, soapstone carvings, building traditional instruments, sewing and embroidery

Ancestry wisdom: Tapping into the wisdom of our elders and ancestors through proverbs and story telling. Learning our tribal languages, songs, dances, celebrations and rituals.

Traditional arts: Jewelry making, painting, ceramics just to name a few.


What We Need & What You Get

In order to accomplish this, I am looking to raise at least $30,000 to purchase the raw land and get the groundwork started. I will be giving perks from my line of one-of-a-kind collectible products, which include bracelets, galaxy rings, and a collection of Acrylic paintings and ceramic arts. Your contribution will be a part of something great for the bettering of Africa and the world. It is with great hope and faith that I trust to reach my goal so I can get started with this project in the beginning of 2012.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to donate or want to do more to help, please spread the word to your relations. Sharing this message on your social networks and list serves can be very helpful. Word of mouth is even better though, so if you can talk me up to your friends, family and co-workers, I would greatly appreciate your help.

My art and fashion can be viewed directly from my websites:

www.wawiart.com
www.mamiafrika.com

30% of all WawiArt and Mami Afrika fashions sales will go towards the village project. The rest of the funds will be used to uplift impoverished communities in Kenya. We will produce and distribute goods that will uplift and nourish many people in the rural communities and facilitate the continuation of creating this rare and beautiful art.


Contact Information:
Wawi Amasha
wawiamasa@gmail.com
323.374.3476

story:
Who is We Are Cove Point?

We Are Cove Point formed in December 2014 when a group of impacted local residents teamed up with activists from around the mid-Atlantic, determined to do everything we can to stop the construction of the massive liquefied natural gas (LNG) export terminal Dominion is building in the Cove Point neighborhood of Lusby, Maryland.

The domestic fracking industry has seen better days and is counting on exports to be its golden solution that increases the value of fracked gas and funds a massive build-out of infrastructure and new fracking wells. In the eastern US, the success of this export terminal at Cove Point is the pivot point that will either lead to a vast expanse of wells, pipelines, compressor stations and gas-fired power plants (and all of the pollution, risks and health impacts that come with these things), or an industry with an uncertain future that's struggling to stay afloat.

Locally, residents are suffering under construction that's seen this rural community on the Chesapeake Bay taken over by massive industrialization. Roads are often blocked by giant construction vehicles, there have been accidents (at the job site and on neighborhood streets), emissions of hazardous toxins have exceeded legal levels, and people are forced to deal with grimy roads, loud noise, heavy truck traffic, and a complicit and over-bearing police force while the construction continues around the clock. If this project is completed, 21.5 tons of pollutants would be pumped each year into the air of Lusby, Calvert County's biggest town. Nowhere else in the world does an LNG export terminal exist in as densely populated an area as this. More than 8,000 people live within the 2.2 mile emergency evacuation zone, a distance recommended by the Department of Energy in the case of an explosion. There are around 300 houses further down Cove Point Road, where their only connection to the rest of the world is the road that passes the terminal; for them, there is no evacuation.

Since the creation of We Are Cove Point, we launched a very successful Indiegogo campaign (raising nearly $22,000!) and hired an organizer with the money. We've done a series of direct actions, a ton of media work, and a whole lot of community organizing — culminating most recently in the largest march Southern Maryland has ever experienced for anything in its history.

In June, two prominent industry insiders spoke directly about the impact We Are Cove Point and allied groups have been having on Dominion's building of this export terminal. Dr. Bernard Weinstein, Associate Director of the Maguire Energy Institute, told a gas industry forum that he was "real skeptical" that the Cove Point terminal would get finished and that "the political and environmental push back is going to be tremendous," citing specifically the work that "protesters" were doing around Cove Point. Additionally, Dominion CEO Tom Farrell, speaking at a utilities conference, worried that “In the hands of those who oppose the energy infrastructure, social media gone viral can erode industry credibility and make our job to communicate the facts much harder.”

We have an increasing amount of momentum on our side, but we're running out of money. That's why it's so important we meet our goal with this Indiegogo campaign to keep our work afloat.

This Cove Point LNG export terminal must be stopped — and we need your help to do it.

What We Need & What You Get

At the beginning of 2015, we established a year-long $50,000 budget to hire a full-time organizer and cover things like outreach materials, office supplies, legal and administrative costs, and community events.

Our last Indiegogo campaign had a goal of $20,000. We raised $21,782! Between that and donations from supporters, we've raised $29,728 total in our short existence. Through mid-July, we've spent $24,133.10 in the following breakdown:

  • Organizer pay - $12,000
  • Legal costs - $389
  • Publicity and merchandise - $3,692.56
  • Props, banners and yard signs - $650
  • Special events - $1,220
  • Fiscal agent fees - $3,656.87
  • Funding Calvert Citizens for a Healthy Community - $2,000
  • Miscellaneous and supplies - $524.67
At the time of this writing, that leaves us with $5,594.90. That should last us about two months. A lot is happening with Dominion, and we need to be moving full-speed ahead right with them. Helping us meet our goal will enable us to do the work we need to do to protect the health and well-being of people in Lusby from the risks associated with this export terminal.

The Impact

The export terminal being built by Dominion in Cove Point places the local community at risk of a catastrophic event such as a chemical spill or explosion. Because of these risks, no LNG export terminal has ever been built in a populated area like this one — anywhere in the world.

In March 2014, there was an explosion at an LNG plant in Plymouth, Washington, which sent flames hundreds of feet high.  People as far as six miles away felt the blast, and a two-mile radius was evacuated.

Within a two-mile radius of Dominion's plant in Cove Point there are 2,365 homes including 19 in-home daycare centers. And the only emergency access to the facility is a narrow two-lane road.

The We Are Cove Point campaign is about more than saving the local community. If this export terminal is built, it will directly make fracking more profitable throughout the Marcellus and Utica shales that lie beneath Maryland, Kentucky, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Virginia and West Virginia. More fracking means more families and communities that are exposed to its hazards. In Pennsylvania, where fracking is prevalent, farmers have lost their farms and families have been forced out of their homes because of fracking. We're also starting to see more deaths from fracking-related illnesses.

The chemicals used in fracking — and the gases and radiation that are released in the process — poison water, land and air. Fracking is correlated with numerous health impacts. And methane leaks have made water undrinkable, started spontaneous house fires and add to the climate crisis. Fracking also causes earthquakes.

This export terminal would drive construction of more pipelines and compressor stations from Massachusetts to North Carolina. This means more communities would be at risk of local pollution and catastrophic explosions. Communities up and down the East Coast are fighting this expansion of fossil fuel infrastructure — and many of them have stood with us to oppose Dominion Cove Point, because they see how this one project directly enables gas projects they're fighting where they live.

Instead of expanding fossil fuel infrastructure, we need to be decreasing it and moving to healthier and more sustainable sources of energy. Stopping this first export terminal on the East coast will send a strong message that other terminals will be stopped, too. 

We can stop Dominion's terminal. Marylanders stopped one from being built at Sparrow's Point in 2013. New Yorkers just achieved a fracking ban statewide. The momentum is on our side. We can turn the tide toward a livable future.

Risks & Challenges

Our greatest obstacle is time because construction of the terminal has already started — though it started six months behind schedule, largely due to the pressure we've placed on it. The community was kept in the dark until late in the decision-making process. So far, we have been unsuccessful at stopping the project by appealing to legislators or through the courts. Still, these efforts continue. There are cases currently in front of courts, and there are legislators who we're working with to take action — and we're seeing progress there.

No matter what, we need to keep building a strong grassroots base and organize strategic direct action to slow the construction process. This will be necessary, whether we win by finally studying the real public safety risks and health impacts, through revocation of Dominion's permits, through the courts or by physically placing our bodies in the way.

There is a real potential to build on this activated grassroots foundation. People in the community have demonstrated great support when people have risen up and taken action. More people are interested in getting involved both locally and from outside the community.

We are holding regular conference calls and have created working groups to work on particular pieces of the campaign. We have a full-time organizer in the community who can help to coordinate the pieces and orchestrate events. This force is moving in the right direction. We just need each of you to give what you can to help us do all we can.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you care about this campaign but can't donate money at this time, there are other ways that you can help. Spread the word about this to other people you know and encourage them to donate. Follow We Are Cove Point on Facebook and Twitter (@wercovepoint), and share our posts and tweets. Sign up for the email list at our website, www.wearecovepoint.org. If you're interested in volunteering, or have other questions or thoughts, contact donny@wearecovepoint.org.

 Thanks for reading all the way through this! Your support makes all the difference!

story:
Despite the urgent alarms sounded by climate scientists, no federal climate legislation has ever become law on the federal level in the United States.  That's why we founded Vote Climate U.S. PAC to elect candidates to transition to clean, renewable, non-nuclear energy - like wind solar and geothermal - and to put a price on carbon. 

We plan to highlight the seriousness of climate change through humor.  Holy BLEEP Mable is a political ad-campaign featuring the quirky couple Mable and Manny, who find themselves in various Holy BLEEP Mabel moments as they experience weather extremes resulting from climate change.  In this first phase of our project, we'll produce 1 of 3 political ads, from concept to creation. 

Please help us bring Mabel and Manny to life and create our ads to elect candidates who can pass climate legislation.  Mabel, Manny and the rest of us here are aiming for an historic, political victory on the most critical issue of our time.

Meet Mabel and Manny, our quirky couple starring in our Vote Climate U.S. PAC ads, who find themselves in various "Holy BLEEP Mabel" moments as they experience weather extremes related to climate change.  See below for more information on the campaign.

Meet Mabel, the Star of our TV Ads, and our Crew Mate Sean


Meet Manny the Star of our TV Ads

The Cast & Crew for our Ad Shoots L to R - Front - Ross, Seda, Andy, Mabel -  Back L to R - Angel, Sean, Linden, Karyn, Sam and Manny.

Join the 2,900 members of our Vote Climate U.S. PAC/Climate Challenge Facebook page.  Please take a look at our video linked above, for more information on our campaign.

What We Need

No donation is too small or too large.  Please donate $1, $5, $10, $25 $50, $100, whatever you can afford.  We'll appreciate any amount you give and put it to good use, fueling the momentum of our campaign.  If we meet our goal of $3,000, it will go toward our ads, allowing us to pay for a director, co-producer, writer and lighting director for the production of our ads.  As supporters of the concept and the campaign, they are giving us an extraordinarily great price.

We'll use your donation to:

  • Pay our professional production team - Andy, Ross, Sam and the Crew
  • Write and refine the scripts
  • Cast and direct the actors
  • Shoot the ads

The Producers - Andy & Ross Setting-up the Ad Shoot

If we do not reach our goal, we will use whatever we raise to make the first ad, but let's not consider failure, let's get it done!  If we exceed our goal, your donation will help pay for editing the ad and getting it ready for placement.  Here's hoping for success beyond our wildest dreams.

The Impact

Our unique and simple approach is to make a series of 3-ads, designed to run in targeted congressional districts to change the political dynamics on climate change.  If we succeed, we will make history, we will change history.  But for now, let's stay focused on the first step - making the first ad.  

Our Creative Action Team

Andrew Harper, President of 60iMedia and award winning producer/director/ Defenders of Wildlife, The Nature Conservancy, the National Wildlife Refuge System, Moroccan American Center, Health Reform Coalition, Kids in Need of Defense, Share Our Strength and the School-Based Health Alliance.  His productions have promoted national and state advocacy campaigns including:  green buildings, conservation, health care and hunger issue and have been featured in campaigns promoted at the White House and on Capitol Hill.  He strongly believes in producing media that matters and brings passion and creativity to all of his productions.

Mark Dann, Treasurer of Vote Climate U.S. PAC, is an expert on voter targeting, fundraising, grassroots mobilization and message development in the U.S. and internationally.   

Kwame E. Bidi, is a new team member.  He recently recieved his Master's Degree from the Heller School for Social Policy and Management at Brandeis University.  He specializes in the entire facet of the project cycle:  needs assessment, planning, implementation, monitoring and impact assessment.  He has more than 5 years managing development projects in the U.S. and Sub-Saharan Africa with the UNDP, MIT and Global Environment Fund.  He currently works for a Boston-based organization and reviews development projects in the MIT Global Ideas Challenge program.  Social entrepreneurship excites Kwame. 

Dave

Dave Finnigan, Welcome to our newest team member.  Dave  is a social entrepreneur working on his third big project.  From 1966-1976 he served as Information, Education and Communication consultant to the family planning programs of South Korea and Taiwan helping them bring average family size down from six kids to two.  From 1976-2006 Dave visited over 2,000 elementary schools where he taught over one million students, their parents and teachers to juggle with slow-moving nylon scarves and sold them juggling "props" of his own design.  Since 2007 Dave has been refining Climate Change is Elementary a program designed to take families from awareness to significant action with regard to their carbon and water footprints.  He is now ready to teach other people how to deliver that program in schools world-wide.


Karyn Strickler, President of Vote Climate U.S. PAC, has executive-level experience leading successful issue advocacy, congressional, U.S. Senate and ballot measure campaigns.  She ran a statewide PAC in Maryland, winning 100% of their targeted races.  Karyn was the finance director for Congressman Chris Van Hollen (MD-8), whom Time Magazine called "a hero to environmentalists."  She hosted and produced the first and only TV show ever, dedicated exclusively to climate change, called Climate Challenge(See link to episode above). Karyn is an Ironman triathlon, age-group champion.

Sam Lichtman, a senior, film major who directed a documentary on climate change and attended FAMU, the top film school in Europe, where he made a film that won the AU Visions Craft Award.  Sam directed, produced, filmed and edited our Indiegogo video presented above.  

We are proud to such an esteemed group of individuals on our team.

Other Ways You Can Help

YOU are the power behind our campaign.  We will gratefully accept any donation, small or large, but if you simply cannot make a donation, you can still help:

  • Join us on Facebook
  • Follow us on Twitter
  • email us at voteclimate.us at gmail.com
  • Sharing this page with your friends, family, neighbors and co-workers through email, Facebook, Twitter and other social media.  Ask them to donate.  This is how campaigns like this one succeed!!
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!  It helps to position our campaign to attract funders.
  • We thank you.  With your help, we will succeed!

    We're just getting started so we do not yet have a website, but we will post it when it's ready.

    Only U.S. citizens or permanent residents may donate.  If you donate $200 in a single year, we are required to report your donation to the Federal Election Commission, so it is best if you do not make anonymous donations.  Thank you for your cooperation.  

    Copyright Vote Climate U.S. PAC 2013.  All campaign materials, including but not limited to videos, story boards, scripts, written materials and others are the exclusive property of Vote Climate U.S. PAC and may not be altered, reproduced or used in any form without our written permission and proper credit.  We encourage you to share our Indiegogo campaign. 

    Authorized by Vote Climate U.S. PAC, Mark Dann Treasurer, and not authorized by any candidate or candidate’s committee.

    An E&E Publishing Service

    CAMPAIGN 2014: Activist launches super PAC to help 'pro-climate' candidates  (Thursday, December 5, 2013)

    Jennifer Yachnin, E&E reporter

    When Maryland political activist Karyn Strickler determined Congress isn't pursuing climate change policy aggressively enough, she didn't sit down to write her lawmaker or contact an environmental group; she opened her own super PAC.

    Strickler, who made her mark in the Old Line State in the late 1980s and early 1990s while working on abortion rights issues, recently founded the Vote Climate U.S. PAC to focus on the election of what she calls "pro-climate" candidates in competitive districts.

    "I've worked on some of the most divisive issues of our time, so I feel prepared to take on climate change, to the extent that anyone is prepared to take on climate change," Strickler said.

    A former executive director of the Endangered Species Coalition, Strickler also produced her own public access television program, called "Climate Challenge," for five years.

    "I've watched and waited for 10 years for existing groups to take political action on climate change; none of the existing groups and none of the existing politicians have succeeded," Strickler said.

    But unlike some super PACs, Strickler's effort isn't backed by an independently wealthy individual.

    While Strickler said she plans to contribute some personal funds to the project, she largely hopes to raise capital via the fundraising website IndieGogo.com.

    "I welcome all interested billionaires," Strickler said, then joked about California billionaire environmentalist Tom Steyer, who runs the NextGen Climate Action PAC: "If Steyer wants to pair up, I'm there."

    In the meantime, Strickler makes a pitch for donations in a video posted to the fundraising site, explaining that the PAC will use its first $25,000 to produce the first of three video ads.

    The trio of ads, which Strickler said will be aired in competitive House races, will focus on Mable and Manny, a "quirky couple" who find themselves facing problems caused by extreme weather.

    Strickler said the commercials, which will be known as "Holy Shit Mabel!," were inspired when she learned of tidal flooding in Miami. She said her husband, American University history professor Allan Lichtman, turned to her and said, "That's what I call a 'Holy Shit Mabel' moment!"

    The fledgling PAC has not determined which races it will target in 2014, but Strickler said it's likely the ads could air in Colorado, Florida, Ohio, Pennsylvania, California or New York.

    "Let's face it, the Republicans are not exactly on our side on the climate issue; even the Democrats aren't very good. That's one of the major challenges that we face," said Strickler, who said her goal is the implementation of a carbon tax.

    She added that the PAC could target Senate races as well, depending on its fundraising. The IndieGogo site reported the group had raised about $800 as of last night.

    "I'm reluctant to do this," Strickler said. "I don't have a lot of resources. I'm not a know-it-all on the issue, but I'm tired of waiting."

    Want to read more stories like this?

    About E&E Daily

    Environment & Energy Daily (E&E Daily) is written and produced by the staff of E&E Publishing, LLC. Designed for policy players who need to know what's happening to their issues on Capitol Hill, from federal agency appropriations to comprehensive energy legislation, E&E Daily is the place insiders go to track their environmental and energy issues in Congress. E&E Daily publishes daily

    www.eenews.net

story_txt:
Despite the urgent alarms sounded by climate scientists, no federal climate legislation has ever become law on the federal level in the United States.  That's why we founded Vote Climate U.S. PAC to elect candidates to transition to clean, renewable, non-nuclear energy - like wind solar and geothermal - and to put a price on carbon. 
We plan to highlight the seriousness of climate change through humor.  Holy BLEEP Mable is a political ad-campaign featuring the quirky couple Mable and Manny, who find themselves in various Holy BLEEP Mabel moments as they experience weather extremes resulting from climate change.  In this first phase of our project, we'll produce 1 of 3 political ads, from concept to creation. 
Please help us bring Mabel and Manny to life and create our ads to elect candidates who can pass climate legislation.  Mabel, Manny and the rest of us here are aiming for an historic, political victory on the most critical issue of our time.Meet Mabel and Manny, our quirky couple starring in our Vote Climate U.S. PAC ads, who find themselves in various "Holy BLEEP Mabel" moments as they experience weather extremes related to climate change.  See below for more information on the campaign.


Meet Mabel, the Star of our TV Ads, and our Crew Mate Sean






Meet Manny the Star of our TV Ads

The Cast & Crew for our Ad Shoots L to R - Front - Ross, Seda, Andy, Mabel -  Back L to R - Angel, Sean, Linden, Karyn, Sam and Manny.
Join the 2,900 members of our Vote Climate U.S. PAC/Climate Challenge Facebook page.  Please take a look at our video linked above, for more information on our campaign.






What We Need
No donation is too small or too large.  Please donate $1, $5, $10, $25 $50, $100, whatever you can afford.  We'll appreciate any amount you give and put it to good use, fueling the momentum of our campaign.  If we meet our goal of $3,000, it will go toward our ads, allowing us to pay for a director, co-producer, writer and lighting director for the production of our ads.  As supporters of the concept and the campaign, they are giving us an extraordinarily great price.
We'll use your donation to:

Pay our professional production team - Andy, Ross, Sam and the Crew
Write and refine the scripts
Cast and direct the actors
Shoot the ads




The Producers - Andy & Ross Setting-up the Ad Shoot
If we do not reach our goal, we will use whatever we raise to make the first ad, but let's not consider failure, let's get it done!  If we exceed our goal, your donation will help pay for editing the ad and getting it ready for placement.  Here's hoping for success beyond our wildest dreams.


The Impact
Our unique and simple approach is to make a series of 3-ads, designed to run in targeted congressional districts to change the political dynamics on climate change.  If we succeed, we will make history, we will change history.  But for now, let's stay focused on the first step - making the first ad.  
Our Creative Action Team




Andrew Harper, President of 60iMedia and award winning producer/director/ Defenders of Wildlife, The Nature Conservancy, the National Wildlife Refuge System, Moroccan American Center, Health Reform Coalition, Kids in Need of Defense, Share Our Strength and the School-Based Health Alliance.  His productions have promoted national and state advocacy campaigns including:  green buildings, conservation, health care and hunger issue and have been featured in campaigns promoted at the White House and on Capitol Hill.  He strongly believes in producing media that matters and brings passion and creativity to all of his productions.





Mark Dann, Treasurer of Vote Climate U.S. PAC, is an expert on voter targeting, fundraising, grassroots mobilization and message development in the U.S. and internationally.   


Kwame E. story:
OrangeRay & "We are the Architects of a New Reality" seeks to educate and inspire change! Being that the Central California agriculture belt is the "bread basket" of the U.S., it is essential that we wake the farming industry up to the long term effects of Monsanto's GMO food crops, along with the neonicotinoid insecticides and their neuro-toxins which are the number one cause of the collapse of our honey bee colonies. Whether the chemical kills via paralysis or by starving them out, either way, it is a slow and torturous death.

    Without our pollenators, we have no food industry.

   The loss of our bees is horrifying! Bees produce a number of products that are not only rich in nutrients but have many medicinal uses including: Bee venom is used to destroy HIV cells. 

    As an ecology biologist and Emeritus Professor at University of Arizonia, Dr. Mcpherson is a compelling speaker! His passion and commitment to waking people up to some unpopular truths, has not been without consequences. But it's so much more... Mcpherson walks the walk!

  "Guy is professor emeritus of natural resources and the environment at the University of Arizona, where he taught and conducted research for twenty award-winning years. His scholarly work, which has for many years focused on conservation of biological diversity, has produced 10 books and more than 100 articles. He lives in an off-grid, straw-bale house where he puts into practice his lifelong interest in sustainable living via organic gardening, raising small animals for eggs and milk, and working with members of his rural community.

   Guy developed a comprehensive set of durable living arrangements in response to the ongoing collapse of the industrial economy and global climate change. He shares property in a rural area developed specifically to provide abundant supplies of food and water as well as maintaining comfortable body temperature in the absence of fossill fuels."

 By including Dr. Mcpherson as a speaker at the Oct. 6th 2013 March Against Monsanto Fresno Event, we elevate the conversation and hopefully, turn the volume up on the vitally important harsh realities that are breathing down our neck. With a corporate stranglehold on the propaganda media, we must seek truth out and bring it to the people so they may be empowered to effect change and force industries to not only comply with environmental protection laws but human and animal rights as well. Another sad fact: We must fight for the Environmental Protection Laws themselves! 

   Bringing the "science" directly to an energized group, we can in turn, take the facts to the street and educate our independent communities. 

 Thank You for Your Consideration:)

                                        OrangeRay: inspire & ignite change

                                                    OrangeRay.com
