story:
A Big Thank You

Thanks to everyone who contributed to our project in Phase I.  Your contribution is greatly appreciated and has helped us get one step closer to a new Holocaust museum in Danville, Iowa.  Phase II has been launched to raise the needed funds to start the preparation of the land for the building of the museum.

Here is the link to Phase II  http://igg.me/at/annefrank/x/1748294

 Anne Frank's Iowa Connection

Oceans Apart was written and illustrated by two teenage girls from Burlington, Iowa.  A copy of their work is a wonderful perk for our campaign.

The Wagner sisters in the corn fields of Iowa were pen pals with the Frank sisters ... 

Just before the Frank family went into hiding, Anne and her older sister Margot were writing letters back and forth between two sisters in Danville, Iowa named Juanita and Betty Ann Wagner.  

The pen pal project started in Juanita's classroom when teacher Birdie Mathews asked if students would be interested in writing to children abroad.  Juanita drew the name of young Anne Frank and immediately wrote to her at an address in Amsterdam.  Juanita's and Anne's older sisters began to write one another as well.  

Anne was an avid postcard collector and sent her new friend in Iowa a postcard from Amsterdam telling about her hobby.  In a letter from Anne to Juanita she tells of looking at a map of Iowa but not finding Danville.  Anne asked Juanita if it was close to the city of Burlington.  

Then the Nazis invaded and the letters stopped.  The Wagner sisters had no idea the Frank sisters were Jewish but knew they were suffering in the war.  Many years later Betty Ann wrote to Margot asking if her family was all right.  It was then Otto Frank who responded letting Betty Ann know his wife and daughters died in a concentration camp.

Today these precious letters from Anne, Margot and Otto, are at the Simon Wiesenthal Center (a museum focused on racism and the history of the Holocaust) in Los Angeles, California.

Back in Danville there is a very humble museum where school children and visitors can come and learn about Birdie Mathew's pen pal project.  Copies of these very important letters are in Danville, Iowa.  It really amazes children to know the young (now very famous) author of a diary found a place in the heart of a little girl from hometown Iowa. 

     visit us at Danville Station

See the Frank sister's letter here at Traces.org

What We Need ...

A new educational facility is desperately needed to share this amazing part of history for school children and adults alike.  The local fundraising has begun with a significant amount raised which will allow us to purchase the property adjoining the current museum.  We are in the final stages of this sale so soon we will have room to build.

Our goal is to expand the current facility with a building project estimated to cost $2,000,000.  Therefore we are launching the fundraising on this site hoping to raise the first $100,000 -- or more!

Once the building project is complete, it will serve as a museum, educational center and library.

We have perks!

  • A thank you card from the school children of Danville, Iowa.
  • A copy of the children's book Oceans Apart - signed by both young authors.
  • A Danville Station tee shirt.
  • In memory of - we will honor your loved one on our Facebook pages.
  • A paving brick with your name engraved outside the new educational facility.
  • A Holocaust Education Book Package to donate to a favorite teacher or school district in your community.
  • Bronze, Silver and Gold Levels of Giving (each assuring you a space on the wall of the new museum letting the world know you helped make this happen!)  You can help us by giving any amount today!
  • We all have someone on our Christmas/Hanukkah list who is hard to buy for.  Please consider donating to this educational cause and we will email you a certificate made out to that special someone.  Then they will know what you did in their name.  Just send us a message and we will take care of it immediately.

“How wonderful it is that nobody need wait a single moment before starting to improve the world.” Anne Frank

The Impact - "If you build it, they will come"

Here in Iowa we believe "if you build it, they will come".  Thousands of school children and visitors from around the world will come to Danville to learn about Anne's connection to Iowa.  We know this new museum will make Anne Frank and the war more real to visitors.  In addition, we believe a children's book entitled Oceans Apart will make this period of history more real to readers.  Your contribution will make a world of difference!

People all around the world know Anne Frank.  Still today, decades after the war, her diary is widely read in schools.  This part of history has great value in Holocaust education all around the world.

The Postcard Project

Even if you cannot give financially, you can do something very important and inexpensive to help this project. Since Anne collected postcards, the children of Danville schools  are collecting postcards with a goal of collecting 1.5 million.  

This will be in honor of the 1.5 million children who perished in the Holocaust.  The children hope to collect cards from all around the world.  It's a great project for anyone, including a classroom in your community!  Tell a teacher about this project today!  

Please mail postcards to:

Danville Schools
419 S Main Street
Danville, Iowa 52623  

A Children's Book Written by Kids for Kids

 Oceans Apart - The Connection between Anne Frank and Her Small Town Pen Pal

The amazing story of Anne Frank's Iowa connection desperately needs to be told in schools around the world.  Two girls from Burlington wrote and illustrated a children's book on the subject entitled Oceans Apart.  This book is now published as part of the A BOOK by ME series.  To learn more about the book series click here.  www.abookbyme.com

An old fire station currently houses a museum called Danville Station which tells the story of the Wagner sisters.  It is extremely small and doesn't even have a restroom.  Despite this fact, many school children visit Danville each year to learn about Anne Frank's connection to the corn fields of Iowa.

Through local fundraising efforts the funds to purchase the adjoining land have been raised.  We are ready to move forward and build a larger educational museum for children around the country to visit.

A BOOK by ME Holocaust Series

Over 70 books have now been written and illustrated by children for children in this series.  The vision started when Deb Bowen met three Jewish survivors in her area named Esther.  Esther Avruch, Esther Katz and Esther Schiff became dear friends and Bowen could not let their stories die with them.  She asked young people to meet them, hear their stories and then write and illustrate a children's book about their lives.  The writing project has grown by word of mouth.  Today there are stories about Jewish survivors, World War II veterans who were eyewitnesses to the concentration camps and Righteous Gentiles (non-Jews who risked their lives to help a Jewish person).

 

"I started to read the materials and stories, and I could not put them down.   It was so powerful to read both the student's interpretation, as well as the direct stories from the survivors themselves.  I have many times researched and studied the Holocaust, but these stories bring the experience to life."

Mary Jean Eisenhower
CEO People to People International
Granddaughter to President Dwight D. Eisenhower      
 
 
 

 

“Each book in the series is a gem! The individual and personal participation and investment of the youthful authors and illustrators is quite outstanding. May you have continued success in your Holy Work.”

Rabbi Jonathan Porath
Jerusalem 

                                                                                                                         

 

Please Help Us Get the Word Out ...

Another thing you can do to help us is to use the share tools to put this amazing project on your Facebook and Twitter.  Call a friend or send an email today.  In doing so, you will help us get the word out about this great project!  

Thank you for helping us make this dream a reality!

 

"Everyone has inside of him a piece of good news. The good news is that you don't know how great you can be! How much you can love! What you can accomplish! And what your potential is."--Anne Frank

story:
Muscogee (Creek) Nation Demands Halt to Wetumpka Casino Project’s Desecration of Sacred Ceremonial Ground

(Wetumpka, Alabama) August 9, 2012 – The Muscogee (Creek) Nation demands a halt to construction of the “Creek Casino Wetumpka” expansion project, which is desecrating the sacred Hickory Ground.  The Poarch Band of Creek Indians already excavated approximately 60 human remains to build the casino, and the recently announced $246 million expansion will cause further desecration to Hickory Ground.

“The Muscogee (Creek) Nation is committed to protecting the burial and ceremonial grounds of our ancestors,” said Principal Chief George Tiger.  “We have attempted to convey to the Poarch Band why it is wrong to disturb the peace of our ancestors and burial grounds.  However, the Poarch Band does not seem to share our cultural values and respect our traditional ways.”

Hickory Ground, known as “Oce Vpofv” in the Muscogee language, was the last Capitol of the National Council of the Muscogee (Creek) Nation, prior to forced removal to Indian Territory in the 1830s.  The sacred place includes a ceremonial ground, a tribal burial ground and individual graves. 

Hickory Ground was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1980.  In 1984, the federal government officially recognized the Poarch Band of Creek Indians, descendants of Muscogee (Creeks) who were not removed and did not live in Alabama as Muscogee Creeks.  The Alabama Historical Commission transferred Hickory Ground to the Poarch Band, even though they had no direct ancestral or cultural connection to the ceremonial ground.

Although the Poarch Band promised to preserve the Hickory Ground for the benefit of all Creek Indians, the Poarch Band exhumed Muscogee human remains and ceremonial objects to build the Creek Casino Wetumpka, with assistance from researchers at Auburn University.  The excavated human remains belong to the lineal ancestors of the Muscogee (Creek) Nation in Oklahoma, who hold Hickory Ground as sacred and oppose development on the ceremonial ground.

“The desecration of a tribal grave, burial or ceremonial place is a human rights violation,” says attorney Brendan Ludwick, who represents the Muscogee (Creek) Peoples in Oklahoma opposing the development.

Mekko George Thompson, who has served as a traditional Chief of the Oce Vpofa Muscogee Creeks in Oklahoma for 42 years, said, “Our ancestors and their burial objects, and our cultural items need to be returned where they were taken from, and the whole place needs to go back to nature.” 

The Muscogee (Creek) Nation is a federally recognized Indian tribe based near Okmulgee Oklahoma.  The Oce Vpofv Muscogee (Creeks) were forcibly removed from their historic, ceremonial and ancestral Hickory Ground near Wetumpka, Alabama, but retain their strong ties and obligations to their homelands and ancestors, along with their traditions and heritage language.  For more information and to find out how you can help save the Hickory Ground, please visit www.SaveHickoryGround.org.

Note: Video "BACK TO NATURE: The Battle for Hickory Ground" by Sterlin Harjo (Mvto)

** ALL FUNDS RAISED WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT THE UPCOMING PROTEST AT HICKORY GROUND IN WETUMPKA, ALABAMA.  JOIN US!!

story:
Help start carbon negative company!

The Dream:

What if we could take some of the millions of tons of wood waste decomposing in landfills, and turn it into a beneficial soil amendment that:

  • Saves water
  • Increases fertility
  • Increases beneficial microbes
  • sequesters carbon

An Ancient Secret:

Recently, an ancient secret was rediscovered. A secret poised to return to a world much in need of its benefits. A secret that comes to us from the lost cities of the Amazon, it’s now known as Biochar, and it's been called the true secret of El Dorado!

 Biochar?

Biochar is an agricultural grade charcoal made with the specific purposes of soil amendment and carbon sequestration. It can be made in many different ways from many different things. We want to concentrate on relieving stress on our landfills by diverting natural wood waste like brush, trees from land clearing, untreated lumber, and more, and then make it into Biochar. We want to start a small scale Biochar manufacturing facility focusing on a retail sized packages. The word needs to get out. Not enough people know about Biochar. It is essentially a new market. We believe that the home gardener is the best place to start.  From there, supply landscapers, bulk soil suppliers, farmers, golf courses… anyone who could benefit from better soil.

 

A product with a purpose:

This wood waste rescued from the landfill could now serve multiple purposes. Whether it be added to your landscape soil or raised bed in a back yard.  Every pound put into the earth not only works with nature to help plants thrive. It also stays in the soil for hundreds, or even thousands of years. It’s effectively removed from the carbon cycle. Biochar represents a true chance to significantly slow the buildup of carbon in our atmosphere. A truly carbon NEGATIVE business!

 

The Benefits:

Biochar has many benefits, for instance, it’s like a tiny natural sponge. Fertilizer runoff in our creeks is a growing and serious concern. Biochar keeps nutrients in the soil where the plants can use them, and out of the watershed. Because of this, Biochar permits the use of less fertilizer and less water. It holds moisture and releases it slowly.  One of its other major benefits is its large surface area. The honeycomb structures of the cells of the wood it was made from become hollowed out, and act as the perfect living space for countless types of beneficial bacteria, fungi, and other microorganisms that are all essential for plant health. And it can be rejuvenated, again and again. Its elegance is its simplicity. More and more, we are all learning that helping nature by giving it the building blocks it need is more productive and satisfying than dominating nature. Biochar needs to be a part of this awakening.

Responsibility:

There are some concerns. It must be made in a responsible way. Ancient charcoal making techniques were horrible polluters. The systems we’ve researched are clean burning, they are primarily powered by their own emissions.  Also, in some biochar made today, high levels of what are called P.A.H.’s are formed during the manufacturing processes which are considered carcinogenic. We believe that we are going to be the first company to take these types of considerations in to our manufacturing processes. 

 

The Plan:

Our plan is this. Raise funds through an awesome indiegogo viral campaign. Order the equipment we’ve selected, which will take close to two months to manufacture and ship. During that time, we will build our production facility on a wood recycling operation’s property. There we will have access to other equipment we’d otherwise have to purchase. For a relatively low startup cost, we’ll be up and running.   Then we will begin making Texas Biochar! We will receive our material as sawdust. From there, it will be dried to the proper moisture level and then processed in a special, clean burning furnace.  We’ll make a small potting soil size bag, and a larger home garden sized bag, also barrels will also be offered for bulk buyers.

Some Optimism:

 We’ve had success premarketing. Several stores are ready to carry and even help promote it.   Austin, TX is a perfect place to start.  It has savvy population that’s willing to support good things. They also love organic growing with multiple shops and nurseries specializing in organic gardening. Several large landscape companies are going all organic as well, and would benefit greatly by adding Biochar to their holistic approach.  We believe we’re a perfect fit. So again, please donate. Help us realize a dream, and help save the world too.  And if you can’t donate, please share!
story_txt:
Help start carbon negative company!
The Dream:

What if we could take some of the millions of tons of wood waste decomposing in landfills, and turn it into a beneficial soil amendment that:

Saves water
Increases fertility
Increases beneficial microbes
sequesters carbon
An Ancient Secret:

Help us realize a dream, and help save the world too.  And if you can’t donate, please share!

story:
Our Story

What are the Barclay Grounds?

The land now known as the Barclay Grounds has passed through a succession of owners.  In American pre-history, the region was occupied by the indigenous Lenni Lenape people. The first legal owner under British control was William Penn based on a royal charter from King Charles II in 1681. The land progressed though a series of agriculture uses, but was never built upon. In 1866 Joshua Hartshorne, an Assemblyman in the Pennsylvania legislature, purchased a 4.5 acre block on the northern edge of West Chester to create his estate, but he built his home on the norther portion of the land. Today the southern portion of the property is known as “The Barclay Grounds” – after the Society of Friends retirement home that occupied the old Hartshorne mansion from 1935 to 1997.

In 2002, the Hartshorne Estate was accepted into the National Register of Historic
Places. The lot contains many mature plantings, some of which appear to date from the use of the property as a nursery by John Rutter prior to the Hartshorne's. For the past 80 years the property belonged to a nursing home and and during that time the grounds have been open to the public. Enjoyed by generations of residents and visitors as urban open space, the grounds were identified in West Chester’s 1992 Parks and Recreation Plan as a “quasi park."  The grounds and plantings were cited as one of the four elements considered “essential” to its listing in the National Register of Historic Places.*

In 2013, a new owner of the property submitted plans to sub-divide the southern portion of the property into four building lots for the development of new houses. The plans made provision for most of the trees on the lots to be cut down to make way for the houses. After a public outcry the Borough of West Chester agreed to purchase the Barclay Grounds and preserve them as an open space if this could be done without creating an additional tax burden on the residential tax payers of the Borough.

What is the Barclay Grounds Preservation Alliance (BGPA)?

The Barclay Grounds Preservation Alliance (BGPA) is a group of citizens
from the West Chester, Pa area who recognized the significance of the Barclay
Grounds to West Chester  and the region. They formed a 501 (c) 3 corporation to raise funding to help the Borough purchase and preserve the Barclay Grounds. BGPA worked collaboratively with the Borough Council of West Chester, Mayor Carolyn Committa,  the Natural Lands Trust, the Brandywine Conservancy, State Senator Andrew Dinniman's Office, local state representatives, the Chester County Commissioners, PA state preservations agencies, and legions of volunteers to raise the necessary funds. To date the Alliance has been instrumental in obtaining over $1 million in public grants and private donations towards the $1.2 million purchase price.

What We Need

The deadline for "closing" on the Barclay property, by contractual agreement, was December 31, 2015.  To ensure that sufficient funds were available to complete the “closing” by the December 2015 deadline, the BGPA took on a loan of $144,000. This loan must be repaid within 2 years.

Helping us to repay this loan will prove that caring individuals can make a difference and save open space in our cities and towns for future generations. Your contribution will  secure this legacy. Funds raised beyond our goal will go directly to costs associated with the replenishing and maintaining the grounds which will become a public park. The Barclay Grounds Preservation Alliance is a nonprofit 501(c)(3) corporation and all contributions are tax deductible.

Whether you contribute $5,000, $500 or $50, land, trees, wildlife and a 335 year open space legacy will be preserved!
  • For this campaign we have identified $44,000 as our goal.
  • To recognize the commitment of our contributors, we can provide a number of recognition gifts to say "Thank You!"

What You Get

First and foremost, the Barclay Grounds will forever become a protected public park in the Borough of West Chester, entitled to the same care as other borough park lands and providing...

  • Sylvan views of stately oaks and flowering dogwoods
  • Study opportunities among natural life for young and old
  • Noise reduction from traffic and reduced traffic
  • Cool lawns to lounge upon and socialize
  • Places for children to play with pets and parents
  • Winter vistas and snowy fields
  • Tree plantings and DIY flower and shrub maintenance education
  • Staging grounds for organized activities and outdoor exercise
  • Wedding and graduation photography
  • And so much more .... in fact, with the approval of the Borough of West Chester, we are planning a celebratory concert on the grounds, featuring local talent, as a gift for all the contributors when we reach our goal. Come and join us - be sure to leave your contact information.

The Impact

As population growth increases both sprawl and density in our small cities and towns, the green open space that once defined America is becoming increasingly rare. Pressure from growing families and new citizens to live in convenient locations and healthy environments threatens to strangle the breathable, traditional wooded lands that people seek. Saving the Barclay Grounds is a step towards maintaining the BALANCE between a growing human world and a sylvan natural one,

  • We believe that action on the part of caring citizens to maintain environmental balance in the face of these pressure is responsible citizenship.
  • Our actions have been systematic and successful, convincing municipal, county, and state government to support preservation of our land trust. We are convinced these actions and those to follow are necessary and essential to the quality of life in our world.
  • If four houses had been built, there would have been no positive tax benefit for the borough's citizens and only a few additional living spaces, by preserving the land, we believe we have created shared living space for all citizens who desire to share its benefits.

Risks & Challenges

It is now clear that the Barclay Grounds will be saved forever.  Yet, while the majority of the necessary funds have been raised, there remains the need to demonstrate further public support for this noble endeavor by helping to pay off the loan, to date shouldered  by a few.  We need to demonstrate that support for this preservation project is broad and deep. That is our challenge. We believe that you will demonstrate this reality, so that future projects in our community can look to this success story as evidence of on-going community commitment to preservation of our wonderful community character!

You Can Help

  • We hope that you can find a way to support our cause financially, but if you cannot - please do share our vision with others.
  • Please get the word out and make some "noise" about Saving the Barclay Grounds. Direct others to this Indiegogo page or directly to our website at "savethebarclaygrounds.org " for updates and related information.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools or just pick up the phone and ask your friends and family to help. We're counting on you as our new friends and global neighbors.

Purchasing the Barclay Grounds as a public park serves all of us now and for generations to come.

Thank you for being part of this campaign!

*historical information drawn from various sources including: National Register of HIstoric Places Registration Form for Barclay Home, 2002.

story:
AS SEEN IN

OUR ADDICTION

We’re addicted to bottled water, and it’s a very costly habit. Bottled water sales topped $21 billion in the United States last year, finally surpassing those of soda. But what are we really getting every time we shell out $2 or more on bottled water? Glorified tap water and tons of plastic waste in our landfills and oceans.

 

BOTTLED WATER LIFECYCLE


THE SOLUTION

Reefill is a network of stations where members can fill their bottles with cold, filtered tap water on the go -- it’s a low-cost, eco-friendly alternative to bottled water.  Members have unlimited access to all stations for $1.99 per month, or the cost of just one bottled water.

 

HOW IT WORKS

 

 

TRACK YOUR GOOD

With the Reefill app, members can track how many plastic bottles they have saved from the landfill and how much money they have saved by avoiding buying bottled water.  They can also see the positive impact of members across the network.

 

THE SOLUTION WORKS

We currently have an 8-station pilot network around the Village in New York City, which was partially funded by a grant from New York University to help the NYU community reduce plastic waste. We’ve proven the infrastructure works and although we’ve already saved over 1,000 plastic bottles from the landfill, we know a larger network will have a much bigger impact!  With 100,000 people using Reefill, C02 is reduced and huge amounts of oil, energy, and wasted water will be saved by not manufacturing and transporting bottles.

 

YOUR NETWORK

 

We’re excited to expand the Reefill network throughout New York City and beyond -- that’s where you come in! By reaching our $30,000 goal we can build the Manhattan network beyond our pilot program and with more backers we can expand to outer boroughs as well.

$30,000 = 15 new locations!
When we reach our initial goal we will have funding for at least one station in neighborhoods across Manhattan including the Financial District, Tribeca, Chinatown, Soho, Lower East Side, East Village, West Village, Gramercy, Chelsea, Garment District, Murray Hill, Midtown East, Midtown West, Upper West Side, Upper East Side, Morningside Heights, Harlem, and Washington Heights.

$100,000 = 50 new locations!
Coverage throughout Manhattan with multiple locations in most neighborhoods.

$250,000 = 125 new locations!
When we top $100,000 we will start adding locations in the boroughs outside of Manhattan as well.

$500,000 = 250 new locations!
With locations across New York City you’ll generally be no more than a few blocks from a fill up.

$500,000+ = a new city!


THE PERKS

GIVE SAFE WATER

We’re thrilled to partner with Water.org, an amazing organization that has brought safe water and sanitation to more than 6 million people around the globe. When you back our campaign, you not only support a low-cost, eco-friendly bottled water alternative, but you also provide safe water to someone in the developing world. Every backer reward corresponds to a safe water donation through Water.org.

BYOWB!

Although we’re offering one-of-a-kind water bottles as perks, you can use any water bottle you want with Reefill.  It’s BYOWB!

 

TIMELINE

 

FUTURE GOALS

Helping New Yorkers ditch bottled water is just the first step. You are starting a movement that will bring Reefill to new cities across the nation and then across the globe. And as we add new products we will work toward the ultimate goal of making all single serve plastic bottles obsolete.

 

UNDER THE HOOD

Reefill stations combine state-of-the art water dispensers with advanced access control Bluetooth technology.  Much of the magic happens under the counter, where we house our filter and chiller, which ensure that the water dispensed is great tasting and ice cold.  UV sanitization occurs in the dispense area to make sure there are no germs or bacteria transferred from one user to the next.

WHAT PEOPLE ARE SAYING

THE TEAM

Jason Pessel, Co-Founder & CEO, Lifelong water drinker.

Andrew Betlyon, Co-Founder & Chief Design Officer, Recent convert.

Patrick Connorton, Co-Founder & COO, Funny-bone still hurts.

 

THE NAME

Are we just Reeeeeeally excited or something?  Well, yeah, that’s part of it, but Reefill is meant to evoke the coral reefs that are being decimated by climate change and ocean pollution.  We can help make our oceans clean and healthy again by ditching bottled water and using less disposable plastics.

 

FAQ

What’s wrong with bottled water?

Tons!  And we mean that literally!  Over 80% of plastic water bottles do not get recycled, meaning 2 million tons of plastic bottles pile up in our landfills and oceans each year.  The manufacturing and transportation of bottled water also wastes more than 17 million barrels of oil and creates more than 2.5 million tons of CO2 annually.  And for every liter of bottled water produced, 3 to 4 liters of water are wasted.  All of this for a product that is often just glorified tap water.  In fact, 50% of bottled water, including Coca-Cola’s Dasani and PepsiCo’s Aquafina, is sourced from municipal supplies.  More facts about bottled water can be found here and here.

Where can I find a Reefill station right now?

We currently operate an 8-station pilot network around the Village in New York City, with stations hosted in local favorites City Bakery, OCafe, the Uncommons, Kuku Canteen and more.  A full map is available at http://www.reefill.com/map.

What kind of filters do you use?

Reefill stations use carbon and sediment filters that meet the performance standards of NSF certification 42 (meaning they reduce specific aesthetic or non-health-related contaminants, including chlorine, taste, and odor) and NSF certification 53 (meaning they reduce specific health-related contaminants, including lead, Cryptosporidium/Cyst, and Giardia).

Are the stations clean?

Reefill stations are equipped with UV sanitization in the dispensing area to kill germs and microorganisms.  We also clean the stations regularly.

What if I forget my bottle?

With a dense network you'll never be far from a Reefill station and that means you can use smaller bottles that are easier to carry.  Through the Reefill app you will also be able to set reminders to help you remember to carry your bottle.

Am I paying for water?

The membership fee covers the infrastructure and maintenance of the network, including the chilling and filtering of the water.  We are not charging for the water and once you access a station, you can take as much as you’d like and fill up your friends’ bottles too! 

By backing us on Indiegogo you can get great deals on membership packages that we do not plan on offering again, including 5-year and Lifetime memberships that will automatically upgrade to any premium memberships we offer during that time period, such as for additional product offerings.

Can’t I just drink tap water from home, work, or school?

Of course!  We support any option where people drink tap over bottled water (which often comes from the tap too) but sometimes it can be tough to find places to fill up away from home, work, or school. That’s one of the reasons Americans spent $21 billion on bottled water last year. When you are on the go, Reefill provides quick and easy access to cold, filtered water with no need to wait in lines or bother store employees, and without the plastic waste of bottled water.  We are also coordinating with the New York City Mayor's office so that the Reefill app will show outdoor (free) bottle refilling stations around town.

What phones does the app work on and what are the system requirements?

The app is available for iPhone (iOS 9.0 or later) and Android phones (Android 4.4 or later).

Do I need to have a smartphone to use Reefill?

Yes, for the time being.  But we are developing access cards and RFID stickers (to put on your bottle!) so Reefill will be available to those without a smartphone and even more convenient for everyone.

Where specifically will your stations be?

That will depend on how much support we receive (and thus how many stations we can manufacture), where we see the greatest demand for the service, and where our host businesses are located.  That said, we will be adding Reefill locations throughout New York City so you won’t need to walk far to fill up when you’re on the go.

Can my business host a station?

We are always looking for interested locations!  Please send an email to info@reefill.com and we can discuss.

When will Reefill come to my city?

As soon as we possibly can, and with your support through this campaign, that could be as early as 2018!  For those of you who do not live in the New York area, the Reefill bottle is the perfect way to show your support for the mission.  If you have a friend in New York, you might also consider a gift membership.

Do I need to use a particular bottle, like the one in the video?

You can use any bottle you want!  The bottle in the video is available as a perk for those who back at certain levels (see the Perk section for details).  If you’ve got a favorite water bottle and want to let others know about it, post about it in the comment section!

Will any percentage of your proceeds go to charity?

Yes!  Through our partnership with Water.org, we use a portion of our proceeds to provide safe water to people in the developing world.  If you sign up for a one-year, five-year, or lifetime membership through Indiegogo, we will donate one year, five years, or a lifetime of safe water, respectively, to someone in the developing world.  We will also donate one day of safe water every day you use the app to fill your reusable bottle.

When will my membership start?

We will be sending backers an activation code to start their memberships.  You are free to wait until we have convenient locations for you before using the code.

THE SOLUTIONReefill is a network of stations where members can fill their bottles with cold, filtered tap water on the go -- it’s a low-cost, eco-friendly alternative to bottled water.  Members have unlimited access to all stations for $1.99 per month, or the cost of just one bottled water. HOW IT WORKS  TRACK YOUR GOODWith the Reefill app, members can track how many plastic bottles they have saved from the landfill and how much money they have saved by avoiding buying bottled water.  They can also see the positive impact of members across the network. THE SOLUTION WORKSWe currently have an 8-station pilot network around the Village in New York City, which was partially funded by a grant from New York University to help the NYU community reduce plastic waste. We’ve proven the infrastructure works and although we’ve already saved over 1,000 plastic bottles from the landfill, we know a larger network will have a much bigger impact!  With 100,000 people using Reefill, C02 is reduced and huge amounts of oil, energy, and wasted water will be saved by not manufacturing and transporting bottles. YOUR NETWORK We’re excited to expand the Reefill network throughout New York City and beyond -- that’s where you come in! By reaching our $30,000 goal we can build the Manhattan network beyond our pilot program and with more backers we can expand to outer boroughs as well.$30,000 = 15 new locations!When we reach our initial goal we will have funding for at least one station in neighborhoods across Manhattan including the Financial District, Tribeca, Chinatown, Soho, Lower East Side, East Village, West Village, Gramercy, Chelsea, Garment District, Murray Hill, Midtown East, Midtown West, Upper West Side, Upper East Side, Morningside Heights, Harlem, and Washington Heights.$100,000 = 50 new locations!Coverage throughout Manhattan with multiple locations in most neighborhoods.$250,000 = 125 new locations!When we top $100,000 we will start adding locations in the boroughs outside of Manhattan as well.$500,000 = 250 new locations!With locations across New York City you’ll generally be no more than a few blocks from a fill up.$500,000+ = a new city!
THE PERKSGIVE SAFE WATERWe’re thrilled to partner with Water.org, an amazing organization that has brought safe water and sanitation to more than 6 million people around the globe. When you back our campaign, you not only support a low-cost, eco-friendly bottled water alternative, but you also provide safe water to someone in the developing world. Every backer reward corresponds to a safe water donation through Water.org.BYOWB!Although we’re offering one-of-a-kind water bottles as perks, you can use any water bottle you want with Reefill.  It’s BYOWB! TIMELINE FUTURE GOALSHelping New Yorkers ditch bottled water is just the first step. You are starting a movement that will bring Reefill to new cities across the nation and then across the globe. And as we add new products we will work toward the ultimate goal of making all single serve plastic bottles obsolete. UNDER THE HOODReefill stations combine state-of-the art water dispensers with advanced access control Bluetooth technology.  Much of the magic happens under the counter, where we house our filter and chiller, which ensure that the water dispensed is great tasting and ice cold.  UV sanitization occurs in the dispense area to make sure there are no germs or bacteria transferred from one user to the next.WHAT PEOPLE ARE SAYINGTHE TEAMJason Pessel, Co-Founder & CEO, Lifelong water drinker.Andrew Betlyon, Co-Founder & Chief Design Officer, Recent convert.Patrick Connorton, Co-Founder & COO, Funny-bone still hurts. THE NAMEAre we just Reeeeeeally excited or something?  Well, yeah, that’s part of it, but Reefill is meant to evoke the coral reefs that are being decimated by climate change and ocean pollution.  We can help make our oceans clean and healthy again by ditching bottled water and using less disposable plastics. FAQWhat’s wrong with bottled water?Tons!  And we mean that literally!  Over 80% of plastic water bottles do not get recycled, meaning 2 million tons of plastic bottles pile up in our landfills and oceans each year.  The manufacturing and transportation of bottled water also wastes more than 17 million barrels of oil and creates more than 2.5 million tons of CO2 annually.  And for every liter of bottled water produced, 3 to 4 liters of water are wasted.  All of this for a product that is often just glorified tap water.  In fact, 50% of bottled water, including Coca-Cola’s Dasani and PepsiCo’s Aquafina, is sourced from municipal supplies.  More facts about bottled water can be found here and here.Where can I find a Reefill station right now?We currently operate an 8-station pilot network around the Village in New York City, with stations hosted in local favorites City Bakery, OCafe, the Uncommons, Kuku Canteen and more.  A full map is available at http://www.reefill.com/map.What kind of filters do you use?Reefill stations use carbon and sediment filters that meet the performance standards of NSF certification 42 (meaning they reduce specific aesthetic or non-health-related contaminants, including chlorine, taste, and odor) and NSF certification 53 (meaning they reduce specific health-related contaminants, including lead, Cryptosporidium/Cyst, and Giardia).Are the stations clean?Reefill stations are equipped with UV sanitization in the dispensing area to kill germs and microorganisms.  We also clean the stations regularly.What if I forget my bottle?With a dense network you'll never be far from a Reefill station and that means you can use smaller bottles that are easier to carry.  Through the Reefill app you will also be able to set reminders to help you remember to carry your bottle.Am I paying for water?The membership fee covers the infrastructure and maintenance of the network, including the chilling and filtering of the water.  We are not charging for the water and once you access a station, you can take as much as you’d like and fill up your friends’ bottles too! By backing us on Indiegogo you can get great deals on membership packages that we do not plan on offering again, including 5-year and Lifetime memberships that will automatically upgrade to any premium memberships we offer during that time period, such as for additional product offerings.Can’t I just drink tap water from home, work, or school?Of course!  We support any option where people drink tap over bottled water (which often comes from the tap too) but sometimes it can be tough to find places to fill up away from home, work, or school. That’s one of the reasons Americans spent $21 billion on bottled water last year. When you are on the go, Reefill provides quick and easy access to cold, filtered water with no need to wait in lines or bother store employees, and without the plastic waste of bottled water.  We are also coordinating with the New York City Mayor's office so that the Reefill app will show outdoor (free) bottle refilling stations around town.What phones does the app work on and what are the system requirements?The app is available for iPhone (iOS 9.0 or later) and Android phones (Android 4.4 or later).Do I need to have a smartphone to use Reefill?Yes, for the time being.  But we are developing access cards and RFID stickers (to put on your bottle!) so Reefill will be available to those without a smartphone and even more convenient for everyone.Where specifically will your stations be?That will depend on how much support we receive (and thus how many stations we can manufacture), where we see the greatest demand for the service, and where our host businesses are located.  That said, we will be adding Reefill locations throughout New York City so you won’t need to walk far to fill up when you’re on the go.Can my business host a station?We are always looking for interested locations!  Please send an email to info@reefill.com and we can discuss.When will Reefill come to my city?As soon as we possibly can, and with your support through this campaign, that could be as early as 2018!  For those of you who do not live in the New York area, the Reefill bottle is the perfect way to show your support for the mission.  If you have a friend in New York, you might also consider a gift membership.Do I need to use a particular bottle, like the one in the video?You can use any bottle you want!  The bottle in the video is available as a perk for those who back at certain levels (see the Perk section for details).  If you’ve got a favorite water bottle and want to let others know about it, post about it in the comment section!Will any percentage of your proceeds go to charity?Yes!  Through our partnership with Water.org, we use a portion of our proceeds to provide safe water to people in the developing world.  If you sign up for a one-year, five-year, or lifetime membership through Indiegogo, we will donate one year, five years, or a lifetime of safe water, respectively, to someone in the developing world.  We will also donate one day of safe water every day you use the app to fill your reusable bottle.When will my membership start?We will be sending backers an activation code to start their memberships.  You are free to wait until we have convenient locations for you before using the code.

story:
Cooperative 518 is committed to growing a healthier, more harmonious future

  • We are a growing collaboration of individuals with the shared vision of a holistically healthful environment for the benefit of all beings.  Cooperative 518 is committed to providing seasonal, nutrient-dense food to the surrounding communities using organic and bio-dynamic methods.  Through mindful practices, Cooperative 518 strives to harness resources efficiently and minimize waste produced. In addition to the farm, we aim to provide education on responsible living, build community, and strengthen the local economy. 

How will your donation help?

The first year of farming requires a great deal of resources.  We need your help to get our project off the ground.  Every donation gets us closer to our goal, no contribution is too big or small!

We are asking for $10,000 which will be allocated to one time farming expenses such as:

  • Greenhouse - $4,000
  • Fencing - $2,400
  • Farm Stand - $600
  • Cold Storage - $1,000
  • Seeds - $1,500
  • Hand Tools - $500

All of our Perks were designed to highlight the unique talents and skills of the  cooperative's core members.

The Big Picture

By creating a local culture around responsible agriculture, we hope to establish a model which can be easily emulated.  Growing up in an industrialized place and time, we see many problems arising in the world which need to be remedied.  

This is our solution.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you or anyone you know is interested in weekly shares of fresh produce from our farm, CSA shares are available for purchase through March 15th!

  • Visit our Website - Cooperative518

  • Spread the word and share this page!


Thank You for Your Support! 

Much Love and Light!

story:
Archangel Ancient Tree Archive is a non-profit organization that collects cuttings from ancient, iconic, and environmentally critical trees, propagates these cuttings, and replants identical copies of these trees to help save the gentics of these threatened trees, and to help reforest the Earth. These trees sequester carbon and are working to prevent the worst effects of global warming. Your support of our mission is more important than ever, and makes a direct impact on fighting climate change.

We really need your help today

We’re raising funds to build a greenhouse facility that will dramatically lower our costs every month, will save tremendous effort in the upkeep of our existing growing facility, will improve our growing operation by speeding up the production of our ancient trees, and will dramatically enhance our ability to reach our goal of growing millions upon millions of these iconic and environmentally important trees to be replanted into the environment.

View Our Greenhouse Video

Some Background

Our old growth forests are under tremendous stress, and when the oldest and most iconic of these trees are replanted around the globe in living archival libraries, the genetics from these trees can be saved for future study. Archangel is focused on the trees that are the world’s most important trees to clean our water and air, and that capture and store the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide to make the most progress in preventing the worst effects of global warming. We’re working hard on this, but can’t do it alone.

Our propagation & growing facility is located in Copemish, Michigan, a small town in Michigan’s northern lower peninsula. The growing facility we’re using is a converted windowless potato warehouse, built in 1968. Growing these trees, which have been collected from all over the world, requires certain conditions to maximize their growth including the correct amount of light, moisture, and proper temperature. We’ve created the ideal condition to grow these plants, but it comes at a great cost.

Old Potato Warehouse

The Difference You Can Make

The climate control of our old potato warehouse takes a substantial amount of energy to operate. The lighting bill alone is $1,000 per month. Cooling the warehouse in the warm summers, and heating the warehouse in the frigid winters averages $1,100 per month. This $2,100 monthly bill is a major expense for our operation, and is money we could use in other, more productive areas including collection trips, propagation management, and horticultural expenses. Not to mention the benefit of reducing our carbon footprint that we are creating every month.

Your Impact

We have determined that by erecting a large greenhouse on our property and taking advantage of natural lighting and ventilation, we could save approximately $1,760 per month, or $21,150 per year in our heating, cooling, and lighting expenses.

We have the experience to properly control the climate in a new greenhouse. We have estimated the cost to prepare the site, run water and electric, purchase and install a 34’ by 96’ greenhouse structure and special support system to endure our northern Michigan climate to be $65,000.

Your support is the lifeblood of our mission. Your generous donation will help us to reduce our operating costs, will lower our carbon footprint, and most critically will directly benefit our mission.

Never Before Offered

One of the most-asked questions we recieve is, "Can I buy a tree?" While we are certainly working toward that day where everyone can recieve an ancient tree, the clones we now have in our library are truly unique.

For the first time ever, we are able to offer a few clones of ancient Giant Sequoias, and the largest coast redwood trees that ever lived - they were propagated from stumps cut down over 100 years ago. Your substantial donation to this cause is important, and can come with great reward with a priceless tree.

Of course, we value your support at any level.

Other Ways To Help

If you’re unable to contribute to our fundraiser at this time, there are still important ways you can help. Share this fundraiser with your friends! Stay in touch with Archangel in the following ways:

Our Website

Archangel on Facebook

@archangeltrees on Twitter

Archangel on YouTube


Learn More About Archangel Ancient Tree Archive

Watch this video about everything we’re working to accomplish.


Learn more about our mission by visiting Our Website.

Our Mission

  • Propagate the world’s most important old growth trees before they are gone.
  • Archive the genetics of ancient trees in living libraries around the world for the future.
  • Reforest the Earth with the offspring of these trees to provide the myriad of beneficial ecosystem services essential for all life forms to thrive including releasing oxygen, sequestering carbon dioxide, providing beneficial aerosols and medicines, and to fight global warming.

 

Amplify Your Support

A valuable way you can help is to share this campaign using the share tools down below.

Thank you for your support!

Thank you for your support!

story:
Dear family and friends, 

 

As you may already know, I am currently working and living in Japan. While my time here is limited, with your help, I am attempting to make the biggest impact possible.

 

I will be running in the 2014 Tokyo Marathon on February 23. I have always loved to run and hope to achieve a personal goal. In the process, I will be raising funds for the charity, TSUNAGU, to help rebuild the areas affected by the Great East Japan Earthquake. I believe in the work TSUNAGU does and I want to actively participate in their efforts. I know I can count on your help. 

 

The Great East Japan Earthquake of 2011 was a magnitude 9.0 (Mw) undersea mega thrust earthquake off the coast of Japan that occurred at 2:46 pm JST on Friday, March 11, 2011, with the epicenter approximately 43 miles east of the Oshika Peninsula of Tohoku and with the hypocenter at an underwater depth of approximately 19 miles. It was the most powerful known earthquake ever to have hit Japan and the fifth most powerful earthquake in the world since modern record-keeping. 

 

On September 12, 2012, a Japanese National Police Agency report confirmed 15,883 deaths, 6,146 injured, and 2,654 people missing across twenty prefectures, as well as 129,225 buildings totally collapsed, with a further 254,204 buildings 'half collapsed,' and another 691,766 buildings partially damaged. Early estimates placed insured losses from the earthquake alone at US$14.5 billion to $34.6 billion.

 

With your generous contribution, together, we can make a difference. All donations will go directly to the charity.

 

ありがとう ございます (arigato gozaimasu), 

 

Gerardo Juarez

story:
Summary

My name is Seth Ezekiel West. I'm a 24 year-old mill worker, avid cross country runner, hiker, and endurance cycler. I grew up in the middle of the woods in a small town called Benson, North Carolina where I spent my youth amongst the trees and creeks and fields. My parents always told me that when I was a kid I used to always try to escape, first from my crib, then chasing geese for miles to find out where they were going, and as soon as I started driving I was going as far as I could to see the most beautiful sights nature had to offer. Unfortunately, the older I get and the longer I spend working, the more detached I feel from nature, even though I spend every chance I can outside, it still feels like something is missing. I've lost the dreams I used to have of the beautiful sights I would some day immerse myself in. After much deliberation on how to resolve this problem, I decided to leave modern life behind, sell my belongings, and walk across the United States from the Outer Banks of North Carolina to Big Sur in California. I'm not going to set a timespan or a goal for when I want to reach the west coast, honestly my goal is to stay in the wild as long as I can and when I reach Big Sur, I may only rest a few days and then carry on northward to see all of the rest of the beauty the northwest has to offer. I'll be keeping a journal of my adventure that I hope to send to a publisher or independently put out when I finish my journey.

What We Need & What You Get


  • I need to raise $6,000 to buy new, quality gear to replace my current setup which is for much shorter term trips. I am in the process of selling literally all of my possessions (car included. Seriously, I will have nothing left!) and I will be using all of that money to settle my debt (college loans and credit cards) but that will only allow me to break even and even though the goal is to be self-sustaining, I will initially need money for food as well as some emergency money in case something goes wrong. 
  • If I don't reach my fundraising goal, I'll still be going on this adventure, it will just be slightly more dangerous.
  • I'll be shooting photos with my gopro and I'll be posting updates from time to time on my facebook page (facebook.com/walkthewild) and my instagram (@walkthewild) when I pass through small towns and can find some wifi. I won't have a cell phone so I won't be able to post every day!

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • The more that technology and business evolve, the more we as humans forget about nature. We forget that we are still part of nature, and that our minds and bodies naturally crave the great outdoors. I hope that my posts and my writing can inspire people to get back outside and see the beauty that the wild has to offer, and even more importantly share it with their children who will become the stewards of our planets wilderness.
  • Although I have never attempted a hike of this scale, I have had many successful hikes and learning experiences in the wilderness, such as Big Bend National Park, the Colorado Rockies, the Appalachian Trail, and Acadia National Park.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this with anyone you can. I know it seems like a lot to ask, but if it reaches a large scale my chances are drastically increased for reaching my goal. This trip will be a dream come true no matter what, but the sooner I get funded the sooner I can start and every extra day that I wait is torture.

Thanks so much for your help!

story:
“So you’re going to live in that thing?” With a laugh, I beam “Yes!”  Throughout the last four years I have been quietly collecting tidbits of ideas and inspiration for my dream home. I spent a fruitless three days of looking for the price of an Ofuro (Japanese style compact tub) from an obscure South Korean company. An entire weekend disappeared into the customer reviews of tankless hot water heaters.  Countless moments have been devoted to its design … every cozy 150 square feet of the off-the-grid cottage house-on-wheels I lovingly refer to as the Wandering Turtle. I want to share my journey - from picking a flatbed trailer to sinking the first nail to the first night in my home.  I hope to show the world that you don’t have to sacrifice a full life in order to live with less. With rainwater catchment, gray water system, solar energy, and a homesteading mentality, I will declare my self-sufficiency.   

To keep costs low, I have scoured Craigslist, Freecycle, and HFH Restores. Upcycling and repurposing are integral to my design. Somehow, I got my mother's blessing to deconstruct her antique farmhouse kitchen table to repurpose as the built-in desk/crafting table. I've salvaged insulation from defunct commercial refrigeration units. Compact energy-efficient appliances are a must. This is where I need your help! All donations are going towards the purchase of energy efficient compact appliances. Specifically, I will be purchasing the following:

  • solar panel system
  • compact RV refrigerator
  • compact oven
  • induction cook surface (over 90% energy efficient!!)
  • water pump
  • potable water storage tanks
  • rainwater catchment system
  • radiant heat flooring
  • mini-split AC system

I have been saving what I can for two years to purchase the trailer and building materials. To raise money, I have also been creating jewelry and crafts to sell at farmers markets. I have already been able to purchase stabilization jacks, a low flow tankless toilet, a sink, four windows, and a tankless on demand water heater with money I raised at the market. 

Even if I don't reach my goal, I will still be able to purchase the most critical appliances for making the home livable and will continue to save and craft to raise the funds for the remaining appliances. 

Please help get the word out about my project! I love talking about green design and living small :) If you're local, I'd love to have you stop by during the build. 

You might wonder where I'm going to park this thing ... I'm pleased to say that I just found a beautiful piece of land in an orange grove. The farmer is providing me space in exchange for the care of his flock of hens. I had to relocate my hens when I moved so I am happy to have feathery fowl friends again! Once I'm completely settled into the Wandering Turtle, my next goal is food security. I will be raising goats, chickens, quail, and rabbits as well as tending an organic garden. That is in addition to my day job as a Chemistry teacher :D
story_txt:
“So you’re going to live in that thing?” With a laugh, I beam “Yes!”  Throughout the last four years I have been quietly collecting tidbits of ideas and inspiration for my dream home. I spent a fruitless three days of looking for the price of an Ofuro (Japanese style compact tub) from an obscure South Korean company. An entire weekend disappeared into the customer reviews of tankless hot water heaters.  Countless moments have been devoted to its design … every cozy 150 square feet of the off-the-grid cottage house-on-wheels I lovingly refer to as the Wandering Turtle. I want to share my journey - from picking a flatbed trailer to sinking the first nail to the first night in my home.  I hope to show the world that you don’t have to sacrifice a full life in order to live with less. With rainwater catchment, gray water system, solar energy, and a homesteading mentality, I will declare my self-sufficiency.   
To keep costs low, I have scoured Craigslist, Freecycle, and HFH Restores. Upcycling and repurposing are integral to my design. Somehow, I got my mother's blessing to deconstruct her antique farmhouse kitchen table to repurpose as the built-in desk/crafting table. I've salvaged insulation from defunct commercial refrigeration units. Compact energy-efficient appliances are a must. This is where I need your help! All donations are going towards the purchase of energy efficient compact appliances. Specifically, I will be purchasing the following:

solar panel system
compact RV refrigerator
compact oven
induction cook surface (over 90% energy efficient!!)
water pump
potable water storage tanks
rainwater catchment system
radiant heat flooring
mini-split AC system
I have been saving what I can for two years to purchase the trailer and building materials. To raise money, I have also been creating jewelry and crafts to sell at farmers markets. I have already been able to purchase stabilization jacks, a low flow tankless toilet, a sink, four windows, and a tankless on demand water heater with money I raised at the market. 
Even if I don't reach my goal, I will still be able to purchase the most critical appliances for making the home livable and will continue to save and craft to raise the funds for the remaining appliances. 
Please help get the word out about my project! I love talking about green design and living small :) If you're local, I'd love to have you stop by during the build. 
You might wonder where I'm going to park this thing ... I'm pleased to say that I just found a beautiful piece of land in an orange grove. The farmer is providing me space in exchange for the care of his flock of hens. I had to relocate my hens when I moved so I am happy to have feathery fowl friends again! Once I'm completely settled into the Wandering Turtle, my next goal is food security. I will be raising goats, chickens, quail, and rabbits as well as tending an organic garden. That is in addition to my day job as a Chemistry teacher :D

story:
Friends,

The Yasuni National Park is probably the most biodiverse part in the world, but is now threaten but oil activities. See our site for information (www.amazoniaporlavida.org).

We want to maintain the Yasuni-ITT proposal to keep underground 900 million barrels, to safe the forests, to respect the rights of indigenous people living in voluntary isolation and to contribute to fight climate change. This story as been covered by major media outlets all over the world like National Geographic

But the most important is that this is a first step to a postoil Ecuador and civilisation, and to safe our Pachamama (Mother Earth). And we need your help.

Unfortunatedly, the Ecuadorean government recently announced it will be drilling in this region of the Park, depite that more than 70% or the population wants to leave oil underground.

We are in the process to collect signatures to launch  a popular referendu, which is our right under Ecuadrean Constituton, yo safe yasuni.

The young group YASunidos (www.yasunidos.org - http://yasunidosinternacional.wordpress.com/ is leading this campaign and they need your support to buy 10 computers and 10 printers in order to achieve the difficult -but not impossible task to gather 600.000 signatures from ecuadorian citizens. That's the number of signatures we need to legally launch the referendum at a national level.

The computers and print/scanners will be used to process the forms with the signatures in the main cities of the country. After 6 months, the equipments will be given as a contribution to the young activists groups in Ecuador.

Together we can acheive this!

YASunidos

story:
Thank you to everyone who has pledged - we couldn’t have made it this far without you.  

We haven’t raised all we had hoped for, but the truth is, we’ve achieved much more than we imagined was possible and along the way, we’ve been building the very 'crowd' we need to make World Vasectomy Day on 18 October 2013 a fantastic success.  

The campaign on Indiegogo has finished but the project is still welcoming donations at http://worldvasectomyday.org and http://thevasectomist.net.  

So come on over and visit us - the more funds we continue to raise the more countries we can sign up to participate in the inaugural World Vasectomy Day!


Our goal

With your help, we aim to raise enough money to make the first ever World Vasectomy Day a hugely successful global event. Our goal is to raise awareness about the environmental impact of rising population on the planet, men’s role in family planning and vasectomy as a solution to prevent unintended pregnancies.

 

What is World Vasectomy Day?

On October 18, 2013 men all over the world, whose families are complete, will dedicate their vasectomy to Planet Earth in a world-first vasectomy-athon to launch the inaugural World Vasectomy Day (WVD).

1,000 men in 25 countries will take the ultimate snip to show they care about the growing strain that population is placing on the planet’s resources, their families and themselves.

For more information: www.thevasectomist.net

 

 

Why World Vasectomy Day?

WVD is a chance for men all over the world to make a very personal choice that has a profoundly public impact on our present and our future. We are asking men who do not want more children to join forces to shoulder the burden of family planning and in so doing, fight for their family, their community, their country and our planet.

WVD will be a world-class knowledge-sharing forum addressing critical science related issues within the context of a highly innovative and ambitious multiplatform public event. But we need YOUR HELP to get there.

 

What will happen on World Vasectomy Day?

Vasectomies performed: The world’s most prolific vasectomist, Dr Doug Stein will perform vasectomies in front of an audience at the Royal Institution of Australia (RiAus) – Australia’s national science hub – to launch the inaugural World Vasectomy Day.

Streamed live: The event will be the world’s first live-streamed vasectomy-athon. Dr Stein will field questions from both the live Adelaide audience and an international online audience.

Discussion: There will be a gathering of diverse thought leaders including population expert and author of The Population Bomb Professor Paul Ehrlich who will weigh in on the social, political, cultural and ethical issues raised by the event and Dr Stein’s mission to save the planet… one vasectomy at a time.

Multiple locations around the globe: While Dr Stein performs vasectomies live from the RiAus in an unorthodox ‘operating theater’, doctors around the world will also perform vasectomies, connected to the event via Skype and social media platforms.

 

What we’ve achieved so far

The good news is we’ve already accomplished an enormous amount so far to lay the foundations for making WVD a reality:

We've made a film: Our documentary film about Dr Doug Stein - THE VASECTOMIST is now complete after four years of devotion and will premiere in October as a part of WVD celebrations. 

We've got doctors: Vasectomy doctors around the world are signing up for WVD, eager to participate and commit their services to the cause. 

We've got speakers: We are rallying some of the smartest people in the world to come together to lead the conversation.

We've got webisodes: We’ve already made 21 webisodes that you can find on the homepage of our website to take you on the journey from where this project began through the experiences and realisations of both Doug and Jonathan, as well as learn a heck of a lot about vasectomies along the way.

We've got many of the logistics figured out: The venue, the partnerships, the date!

We just need some funds to pull it all off...

 

So here’s where you come in

We urgently need to raise another $50,000 to help us cover the costs of the human and physical resources required to make WVD happen. Your support will help us achieve:

Marketing and publicity including online marketing through social media to build our global audience.

Logistics support on the ground in each participating country.

Design and build of the WVD interactive website for online streaming.

Production and postproduction of another 10 webisodes covering the lead up to and realisation of WVD (shooting and editing).

 

What you get

Take a look at the right hand column and you’ll find we have all sorts of rewards for our contributors. We want to show our gratitude and appreciation to the community behind this cause by offering you things like DVDs, T-shirts, film screenings including Q & A with Jonathan and Doug, vasectomies (having a vasectomy is a serious decision, please read the fine print*), conversations, film project consultations with Jonathan, and even a short film made to order!

 

 

How did this all start?

World Vasectomy Day is the creation of Oscar-nominated and Emmy Award-winning documentary filmmaker Jonathan Stack, who while setting out to tell his own story about getting a vasectomy, met legendary Florida-based urologist Dr Doug Stein and together, ended up making a film about population on the planet – THE VASECTOMIST. But it didn’t stop there. The journey inspired them to create a movement to raise global awareness of: the dangers an ever-increasing population has on the planet’s finite resources; and vasectomy as a viable solution to prevent unintended pregnancies.

 

Who are we?

Coproduction partners New York-based Gabriel Films founded by Jonathan Stack, and Sydney-based Smith&Nasht founded by Simon Nasht, are companies focused on social issue storytelling. We have come together to create a new conversation about population and consumption, by asking men to take a very personal action to change the world. We believe that: vasectomy should be readily available to all men; it is the best option for men whose families are complete; it is the fair thing to do for our women and the right thing to do for our planet. And by eliminating fears of unintended pregnancies, it can even make your sex life better!

We know that talking about fertility is difficult. The consequence of denial is unacceptable. The good news – although we are the cause behind each challenge we face, we are also the solution.

 

Thank you!

We are deeply grateful for any support you can offer and value each and every one of your contributions equally; in whatever way you can support us. If you’re interested in what we’re doing and want to help us raise awareness through World Vasectomy Day, there are many ways you can contribute to help us build the community such as:

LIKE our Facebook page facebook.com/thevasectomist

FOLLOW us on Twitter twitter.com/thevasectomist

VISIT our website www.thevasectomist.net and SUBSCRIBE to our Campaign News to be the first to hear how we’re doing.

TELL YOUR FRIENDS - to join the conversation about population and our impact on the planet!

Thank you so much. We can’t achieve our goals without you!

 

 

*The Legal Stuff
If you choose the Have Your Own Vasectomy perk, you must be a consenting adult. You will be required to undergo standard counselling and assessment procedures and follow-up treatment. Dr Stein will have complete discretion to determine if the procedure should go ahead, and the schedule of the procedure. If for any reason he should decide not to proceed, you will be refunded your contribution.

story:
Every Gallon Matters!

Make Reversing Climate Change Everyone's Campaign!


Support Granite State Biofuels - a Woman owned producer of Biodiesel in the Capital Region of New Hampshire.

 While a replacement for diesel or jet fuel may not seem as cool as an intelligent road system or next-gen smart phone it plays a HUGE but largely transparent role in your personal lives and nearly all aspects are not very beneficial.


Diesel and Jet Fuels are the two fundamental energy fuels that drive the world. Nearly everything you can imagine is moved by them and so is the price we pay for those things.

We ask you to pause a moment to think about fuels that do not require us to send our friends and family around the world to die in defense of petroleum reserves that poison our environment and result in a third of the US debt we will pass on to our children's grand-children.

Imagine just for a moment the impact of not having our Military police oil supplies around the world.

 

Who We Are

Granite State Biofuels is a Woman Majority owned producer of Biodiesel in the Capital Region of New Hampshire.

Beginning in 2011 Lynda and John Maguire along with Andrew Hatch began the process of creation and innovation that has lead them to what is now a totally self-funded 3.75 million gallons per year Biodiesel production facility in Bow, New Hampshire. As a true innovator in Biofuels production, we have leveraged the Bio-Tech\Bio-Pharma rich environment of the Northeast to create a very compact, highly effective and energy efficient platform for manufacturing Biodiesel that can be easily distributed.

What We Will Do

Granite State Biofuels will continue to produce Biodiesel and refine its innovative Biotech manufacturing process as well as add much needed in-process lab testing to ensure the highest possible output quality. Upgrades to energy efficiency and product distillation will also continue in our ever-evolving efforts to lower production costs making Biodiesel more competitive without subsidies.

We need to purchase analytical equipment which will help us to refine our process in real time. Right now, independent testing labs take several days to report results and are expensive. This $40,000 investment will significantly increase our speed of development and lower our cost of production.

Help us grow the process that will restore and redefine community economics, aid our environment and reduce our dependence on fossil fuels by supporting our campaign and keeping an eye out for others like it. Remember smart roads are truly incredible but they are just a small part of the change we must have to grow the total spectrum of the new Alternative Revolution.

Help Granite State Biofuels continue to innovate Alternative Energy Solutions that impact communities, states, our Nation and our planet through the creation of  self-sufficient community scale Biodiesel Production Facilities.

The efforts of biofuel producers like GSB will be the disruptive force in re-distributing the wealth of energy from massively profiteering oil refineries back to communities.

Direct impact on the communities in which Biodiesel is produced include:

  • Increased tax base from entire Biodiesel value chain.
  • Jobs created for feedstock farming or collection of waste oils, production of Biodiesel and distribution by local outlets and distributors.
  • Skilled jobs created for Biodiesel production and distribution.
  • Jobs for Domestic oil burner technicians. Protection for small oil heat distributors against onslaught of natural gas conversions.
  • Income for local feedstock producers, collectors and refiners.
  • Healthier people and cleaner environments resulting from reduced emissions and non-polluting production methods.

By choosing biodiesel, consumers can elect to support a local, safe alternative. GSB can afford to supply consumers directly as they will buy 50 gallons or more at a time.

If we are fortunate to secure additional funding, we will use this to begin the process of establishing our second production facility. It has always been our plan to establish a source of clean renewable fuels suitable for marine and then jet applications. Biodiesel is truly biodegradable, it is less caustic than salt and biodegrades faster than sugar making it an ideal fuel for use on and around our precious oceans and fragile atmosphere. These industries know they need to have alternatives but they are simply not there in the quantities required. Numerous market research efforts are predicting very high demand and growth in these areas and we feel we have the technology to deliver in these markets.  

We will continue our efforts with researchers, industry groups and government agencies to further the growth of viable and scalable drop-in alternative fuel production methods. Next generation biofuels are in great demand by all industry users as they represent a direct and drop-in replacement for fossil fuels and GSB is dedicated and determined to play a role in their development and proliferation.

Technical Stuff

Our unique technology is based on process intensification of the reaction components, vegetable oil and methyl alcohol. The intensification of the reaction is the primary process in biodiesel production.

Intensification directly effects the reaction rate and the reaction completion.

If the reaction rate is increased ten times compared to classical biodiesel production technologies the equipment productivity is increased 4-5 times, thus reducing the plant cost 2-3 times making it very easy and economical to add plants at the community level where they can do the most good.

Biodiesel makes a strong case for being a contender in a form of positively disruptive economic change that will fuel innovation across a multitude of areas and promote continued growth of measures to ensure petroleum independence. Technology, agriculture, environment and manufacturing will all play major roles as the transition to renewable energy economics continues.

Why Indiegogo Gets It!

Danae Ringelmann set about making capital available to anyone with a Vision that could capture the imagination and inspire others to participate in and fund that Vision. She and her partners are delivering the Future of Finance!

Indiegogo represents a unique and powerful opportunity for funding change through the development and empowerment of ideas and beliefs. What we are seeking is not simply funding but kinship in the belief that Indiegogo communities are made up of like-minded and motivated individuals that want to support specific things and enact powerful change.  While large corporations, lobbying firms, supporters of special interests and government currently decide policy so many of us don't agree with, we are now being afforded the ability to cooperatively support efforts that we can believe in with crowdfunding communities.

Democratize the Monopoly of Petroleum as Indiegogo has done with Banking and Finance!

 All around the world the technology and the materials exist to bring about the change WE know must come about but WE must embrace and support the transition by supporting any and all credible efforts to ensure that change is seeded and cultivated.

Indiegogo community support can be that critical cooperative funding opportunity that banks simply can't offer.

 

Biodiesel Today

Biodiesel is crafted from locally available resources and usage provides a host of economic benefits for local communities. The community-based model of distributed Biodiesel production we have developed is particularly beneficial as available feedstocks are locally grown or collected, converted to biodiesel, then distributed and used within the community. This benefits the local economy by keeping energy dollars in the community instead of sending them to foreign oil producers and refineries outside the community.

 


Biodiesel makes a strong case for being a contender in a form of positively disruptive economic change that will fuel innovation across a multitude of areas and promote continued growth of measures to ensure petroleum independence. Technology, agriculture, environment and manufacturing will all play major roles as the transition to renewable energy economics continues.
