our plan to establish a source of clean renewable fuels suitable for marine and
then jet applications. Biodiesel is truly biodegradable, it is less caustic
than salt and biodegrades faster than sugar making it an ideal fuel for use on
and around our precious oceans and fragile atmosphere. These industries know
they need to have alternatives but they are simply not there in the quantities
required. Numerous market research efforts are predicting very high demand and
growth in these areas and we feel we have the technology to deliver in these
markets.  
We will continue our efforts with
researchers, industry groups and government agencies to further the growth of
viable and scalable drop-in alternative fuel production methods. Next
generation biofuels are in great demand by all industry users as they represent
a direct and drop-in replacement for fossil fuels and GSB is dedicated and
determined to play a role in their development and proliferation.

Technical Stuff

Our
unique technology is based on process intensification of the reaction
components, vegetable oil and methyl alcohol. The intensification of the
reaction is the primary process in biodiesel production.
Intensification directly effects
the reaction rate and the reaction completion.
If the reaction rate is increased
ten times compared to classical biodiesel production technologies the equipment
productivity is increased 4-5 times, thus reducing the plant cost 2-3 times
making it very easy and economical to add plants at the community level where
they can do the most good.
Biodiesel makes a strong case for
being a contender in a form of positively disruptive economic change that will
fuel innovation across a multitude of areas and promote continued growth of
measures to ensure petroleum independence. Technology, agriculture, environment
and manufacturing will all play major roles as the transition to renewable
energy economics continues.

Why Indiegogo Gets It!

Danae Ringelmann set about making capital available to anyone with a Vision
that could capture the imagination and inspire others to participate in and
fund that Vision. She and her partners are delivering the Future of Finance!
Indiegogo represents a unique and
powerful opportunity for funding change through the development and empowerment
of ideas and beliefs. What we are seeking is not simply funding but kinship in
the belief that Indiegogo communities are made up of like-minded and motivated
individuals that want to support specific things and enact powerful
change.  While large corporations, lobbying firms, supporters of special
interests and government currently decide policy so many of us don't agree
with, we are now being afforded the ability to cooperatively support efforts
that we can believe in with crowdfunding communities.
Democratize the Monopoly of Petroleum as Indiegogo has done
with Banking and Finance! 
 All around the world the
technology and the materials exist to bring about the change WE know
must come about but WE must embrace and support the transition by
supporting any and all credible efforts to ensure that change is seeded and
cultivated. 
Indiegogo
community support can be that critical cooperative funding opportunity that
banks simply can't offer. 

 



Biodiesel Today



Biodiesel is crafted from locally available resources and usage
provides a host of economic benefits for local communities. The community-based
model of distributed Biodiesel production we have developed is particularly
beneficial as available feedstocks are locally grown or collected, converted to
biodiesel, then distributed and used within the community. This benefits the
local economy by keeping energy dollars in the community instead of sending
them to foreign oil producers and refineries outside the community. 
 

Biodiesel makes a strong case for being a contender in a form of
positively disruptive economic change that will fuel innovation across a
multitude of areas and promote continued growth of measures to ensure petroleum
independence. Technology, agriculture, environment and manufacturing will all
play major roles as the transition to renewable energy economics continues.

story:
Palau is a small country with a huge idea: closing its waters to industrial fishing. No country has ever done it before. Palau would become the world’s first National Marine Sanctuary with one of the largest protected ocean areas on Earth. 

The result? A regenerative zone for sharks, whales, tuna, and countless other precious species approximately the size of France, and a model for other countries to follow.

The world’s oceans are in crisis: 

  • 90% of the world’s large fish stocks are gone

  • 80% of global fish stocks are now fully or overexploited

  • Up to 40% of fish caught today are caught by accident and wasted. Vulnerable sharks, dolphins, whales and sea turtles are killed in the process.

The time to act is now.

Stand with Palau in a quest to protect its environment and ignite a global movement to save the oceans.


Palau has been named National Geographic's “Last Great Places on Earth”, CNN Traveler's best island destination, and a top 10 Ethical Traveler destination for three consecutive years.


Palau's Rock Island Southern Lagoon is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Photo courtesy of David Clumpner


Palau's archipelago spans hundreds of islands spread across the north-western Pacific ocean, and is home to:

  • More than 1,300 species of fish

  • 700 species of coral

  • An estimated 130 species of rare sharks and stingrays

  • The world's only Jellyfish Lake, full of millions of stingless jellyfish 


Palau's pristine reefs support more coral fish and other invertebrates per square mile than anywhere else on Earth. Its waters contain one of the largest portions of endemic species in the world, seven of the nine known giant clam species, the most marine lakes per mile of territory, the most isolated Dugong (Seacow) population, and some of the world’s most extensive seagrass beds.





Nature magazine reports that the most successful sanctuaries are big, isolated, well managed, well protected, and enduring. 

1 – big -> Palau's ocean territory is 230,000 sq miles wide, which is approximately the size of France. 

2 – isolated -> Palau is an archipelago of hundreds of islands surrounded by thousands of miles of ocean.

3 – well managed -> Palau’s World Future Council award-winning Protected Areas Network is amongst the best in the world.

4 – well protected -> Palau has tested new drone technologies and is looking at other innovative ways to protect its waters. Friends have offered their help, but more will need to be done.

5 – enduring -> More than 100,000 people visit Palau each year. Your support and a foundation of eco-tourism will help ensure Palau has the resources to make the sanctuary endure.

Palau is home to tuna, sharks, and other species that swim in and out of its waters. The potential gains from creating one of the world’s largest ocean nurseries will spill over into neighboring waters. Everyone within and outside Palau stands to benefit from a National Sanctuary in Palau.


Palau declared the world’s first shark sanctuary in 2009. Today, 10 countries have followed Palau's lead, creating 4.9 million square miles of shark sanctuary and other important protections. Palau showed that it was possible. Its small spark ignited massive global action.

The idea of a National Marine Sanctuary is even more powerful. If one regenerative zone can work, why not others? Why not a network of areas all over the world that protect the most important and vulnerable marine life?

Countries are considering these questions at the United Nations right now. What they need is an example that shows it can work.



This campaign is brought to you by the Fund for a Sustainable Palau, a US-based 501(c)(3) charity devoted to sustaining Palau’s unique natural environment and promoting its international leadership.

It is led by diplomats, scientists, artists, scholars, philanthropists, foundations, and businesses with a personal connection to Palau and are devoted to the oceans.

$100K allows us to scale up a previously successful study that employed Palauan fishermen to collect baseline fisheries data for the Sanctuary

$250K allows us to conduct a detailed economic study to ensure that eco-tourism growth is environmentally sustainable

$500K allows us to use drone and other unmanned technology to monitor for illegal fishing in Palau's waters

$1M allows us to integrate that technology with a dedicated boat and crew to conduct research and surveillance in Palau's waters


'The Silent Medusa' Poster, by Photographer and Model Amber Arbucci


Art Tee


We will contact you for your size once the campaign has ended

Underwater Palau by photographer Jason Landis


I Stand With Palau Tee

We will contact you for your size once the campaign has ended

story:
Short Summary

Ven. Rev. Patrick McCollum is a world peace visionary and planetary activist. He has been invited to participate in several significant world peace events. His appearance and contribution at these next few events will be critical for peace and we need your help to make it happen. His story has been very interesting and magical.

Who Is Patrick McCollum?

Reverend Patrick McCollum is for now one of the best kept secrets in our world. Very few know that not only is he an interfaith chaplain and Wiccan Priest who carries the knowledge of the "Old Way," he has also been honored by spiritual leaders in many spiritual circles around the world. 

Patrick has been named as a "World Inner Peace Ambassador" by Buddhist spiritual leaders in Thailand. He was an honored guest speaker at the World Culture Forum in Kazakstan 2010 where he spoke to political and spiritual leaders from over 80 countries on the importance of our harmonious connection with Nature and with each other. He has been recognized as a Saint in India and has also been honored as the 'King of Peace' by the World Peace Foundation and renowned Tibetan Buddhist Rimposche, Lama Gangchen. He is known by Native Americans as, "He Who Speaks With the Mother" due to his work to secure indigenous sacred sites and his advocacy on behalf of native populations. In 2011 he was honored with receiving the Mahatma Gandhi Award for Religious Pluralism. He hand constructed a violin, which has become known internationally as the 'World Peace Violin' and he has been invited to share it at the UN's International Peace Day next fall. Last January, Patrick had the honor to lead the opening prayer at the Maha Kumba Mela in India, a spiritual gathering that attracted over 100 million people. 

Patrick is quickly becoming one of the foremost voices in our world on the topics of creating world peace and sustaining all people. His message inspires audiences to recognize our inherent interconnection through a common narrative, which gives us greater access to envisioning and creating a common goal: a world that works for everyone. He is changing the world by creating peace bridges between countries and people, inspiring youth, working to support women's rights, and religious equality around the world.

What is this opportunity?

Rev. McCollum will begin by opening the World Peace Concert at Lake Tahoe on September 7. In addition to speaking at the event, the internationally acclaimed World Peace Violin (more information here http://www.patrickmccollum.org/world-peace-viol...), created by Rev. McCollum, will be played by world renowned violinist, Scarlet Rivera.

Then Rev. McCollum will attend the International Day of Peace at the United Nations, where he is sponsoring a new youth representative to attend the UN as a part of the Patrick McCollum Foundation's youth leadership program.

Next, Rev. McCollum will speak at the International Vigil for Peace & Sustainability on stage at Central Park in New York on Sept 21st. Then Rev. McCollum travels to Atlanta Georgia, to open the Black Tie Gala ... World Summit of Nobel Peace Laureates, hosted by President Jimmy Carter and featuring eight Nobel peace prize recipients. 

Following that, Rev. McCollum travels to India, where he is the Keynote Speaker and Distinguished Guest for the International Festival on Yoga & Spirituality, speaking on a new sustainable narrative for a peaceful planet.

Rev. McCollum will finish his peace tour speaking by at the School of Management Sciences in Varanasi India where he will share with advanced international business students how they through responsible business practices, can contribute to world peace.

Why are we asking for financial support?

While Patrick's service and presence at these powerful events is clearly of high value, the organizers of the events do not have the financial means to provide for his airfare. Our desire is not only to get him there, but to insure his safe travels and maximize the outreach of the important messages he has to share.


What We Need & What You Get

We are aiming to raise $6,000 for this trip. What this would afford us are the round-trip tickets to India for Patrick and to have some money for other travel expenses. It will also be used to support the youth. If we receive more than our funding needs, the extra money will go towards the foundation and to supporting the various work that Patrick is a part of.

Everyone who gives at any level will receive a letter of thanks hand-signed by Patrick McCollum. They will also receive a recording of the live conference call where they will be among the first to hear the highlights of the trip.

Everyone who gives $100 will be invited to participate in a live conference call with Patrick to hear about the highlights of the trip.

Everyone who gives $500 will be given the opportunity to speak directly with Patrick on the live conference call.

Everyone who gives $1000 or more will receive everything above plus a personal Skype session with Patrick (lasting 30-45 minutes) to receive spiritual guidance and blessings.

We have special gifts designed by Patrick McCollum (who is also an award-winning professional leather and jewelry designer) for people who wish to give at a level of $5000 or more. For more information, please contact Patrick's Executive Director, Nell Rose Phillips, at NellRose@patrickmccollumfoundation.org.

The Impact

Your donation to this project is a donation to history in the making. We are at a critical time on our planet where every effort towards peace is critical to the outcome that we so desperately desire. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have money to share, but you've got friends, please spread the word! Join our email list at www.patrickmccollum.org. If you've got skills or other kinds of resources, please let us know. We are all in this together! All forms of support are received with gratitude!

story:
We are James, Jessica, and Zan, and together we make up One Small Steppe, a three-person Scottish-American team participating in the Mongol Rally 2013.  With your help, we hope to offset the travel costs of an epic 10,000 mile journey through the heart of Asia to raise funds and awareness for Cool Earth, a charity protecting the rain forest to combat climate change.

 

What Are We Doing?

We’re driving in the Mongol Rally!  The Mongol Rally is a small car charity rally in which teams from across the globe drive London, England, to Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia, in sub-compact vehicles with 1200 cc engines.  The Rally is run by a UK-based organization called The Adventurists (www.theadventurists.com) with the stated mission to “make the world less boring” by encouraging people to embrace the spirit of old-fashioned adventure rather than luxury travel.

The Adventurists are not just encouraging people to travel the world, but also save it.  To join their events, each team must raise a minimum of £1000 pounds (approximately $1600) for charity.  With seven other charity challenges, hundreds of vehicles and thousands of people participating every year, the Adventurists have raised over £3.7 million pounds (close to $6 million) in charity money since 2004.

 

What Is The Charity?

As of 2012, the official charity of all Adventurist challenges is Cool Earth (www.coolearth.org), a UK-based NGO which protects critically threatened areas of South American rainforest.  Founded in 2007, Cool Earth sets itself apart from other non-profits fighting climate change in many ways:

Cool Earth protects areas of rainforest that would otherwise be cleared within the next 18 months, making real-time impact

90% of all donations go directly to funding projects and only 10% go towards Cool Earth’s administration

Cool Earth does this not buy land, but empowers the communities already living on it to have the means and incentives to resist logging

Cool Earth does this by providing rainforest people with:

  • Education and health care within their own communities.
  • Renewable sources of income which leave the forest standing.
  • The means to patrol their land against illegal logging.

 

Why Does It Matter?

The destruction of the rainforest is a major environmental and humanitarian crisis.  Amazonian communities and governments often see no way to profit from their land other than to sell it for clearing.  This provides only very short-term benefits, while doing incalculable long-term harm to their traditional ways of life as well as the planet as a whole. 

Cool Earth gives many reasons why the rain forest is far more valuable standing:

  • In one year, the roughly one billion acres of standing rainforest absorb an amount of carbon dioxide equal to the entire CO2 emissions of the United States. 
  • One large rainforest tree stores about 30 tons of carbon – three times what the average person in a developed country produces in one year.
  • It is estimated that global rises in temperatures due to CO2 emissions would have progressed 10% faster without the Amazon rainforest carbon sink. 
  • 150 acres of rainforest are cleared every minute, equal to an area roughly the size of Los Angeles over the course of one mouth. 
  • Clearing one acre of rainforest releases 260 tons of CO2, the equivalent of driving a car around the world 32 times.
  • The rainforest is home to two-thirds of all the biodiversity on the planet.  Many species which live there, especially plants with potential medical value, have not been studied.
  • 1.6 billion people depend on rainforests for their livelihoods.
  • 350 million people live in the rainforest itself, a way of life which includes knowledge of many medical plants and their properties, and which is immediately threatened.
  • Cleared rain forest soils only remain useful for other activities such as cattle ranching for about two years, after which the soil is depleted and more new land must be cleared, continuing the cycle.

Since 2007, Cool Earth has saved 330,000 acres of rainforest (More since our video was filmed!  Cool Earth's mission is working in real time!), which serve as a barrier to 1.2 million more.  Between all their challenges combined, the Adventurists have raised almost $6 million for a variety of charities since 2004.  Cool Earth needs only about $100 to save an acre of rainforest.  Now the combined efforts of all Adventurists’ fundraising will go towards Cool Earth, a charity which impacts every adventure-hosting country, and every person on the planet.

 

Who Are We?

The team formed in 2009 when Zan learned about the Mongol Rally while in Mongolia doing volunteer work, and started planning to take on the challenge with Jessica, a long-time friend from middle school.  James came on board after meeting Zan through a student organization he headed in Edinburgh, Scotland where they were finishing their bachelor’s and master’s degrees, respectively, in the spring of 2012.  In July the team was christened One Small Steppe and signed up to participate in the Mongol Rally 2013.

As a team we bring a variety of skills to the Rally.  James, a biology graduate of Edinburgh University, has toured Oman by jeep; Jessica studied anthropology at the University of Cincinnati and is an online entrepreneur; while Zan has traveled extensively in Asia and speaks Russian and Mongolian, which she currently studies, along with Mongolian history and current affairs in the department of Central Eurasian Studies at the University of Indiana, Bloomington.

 

How Will It Work?

As a team participating in the 2013 Mongol Rally, One Small Steppe is obligated to raise at least $1600 which will be donated directly to Cool Earth.  We have also pledged to make personal donations to Cool Earth beyond the $1600 minimum to the amount which offsets the carbon footprint of our travel by air and overland.  To raise this direct charity money, we are organizing fund raising events in our communities. 

Apart from this, we are using Indiegogo to raise as much money as possible to offset the cost of our travel.  Our stated goal of $5000 is a bare minimum that would cover most car-related expenses, and we hope to raise money beyond this goal.

First and foremost this money would cover:

  • Buying a used car
  • Fuel
  • Car insurance
  • Fitting the car with van tires and a shield under the carriage to minimize wear
  • On-the-road car maintenance

Donating to our car expenses still contributes to charity indirectly, because when we arrive in Mongolia, our car will be auctioned to raise yet more funds for Cool Earth.

Other costs of the trip include:

  • Plane tickets for two of us to Britain and all of us back from Mongolia
  • Visas for countries we pass through
  • Travel insurance
  • Supplies
  • Possible emergencies

Any additional money we raise will make our trip that much more worry-free.  All left-over funds will be donated to Cool Earth.  And if for any reason we can’t participate in the rally at all, any funds we’ve already collected will go directly to Cool Earth.

 

Why Should You Help?

Our team believes that adventure and philanthropy go hand in hand.  By making the drive, we’ll spread the news about Cool Earth’s mission beyond our friends and family, to every country we drive through.  Via the internet, we’ll update from the road.  At the journey’s end, more funds will be raised for Cool Earth when our car is auctioned in Mongolia.  Connecting with the world and its peoples is crucial to caring about its future.  By supporting our trip fund, you can help make joining adventure and philanthropy a reality.

All the members of One Small Steppe are in our early 20’s and are, or until recently were, students.  Our families have all been extremely supportive of our ambitions, but we don’t want to burden them or put ourselves in debt to achieve them.  And because we realize that contributing money for spark plugs and spare tires doesn’t have quite the same intrinsic reward as donating directly to charity, we’re offering some great incentive gifts, some of which will come straight from Mongolia!*

$5000 may seem like a lot of money, but if all of our Facebook friends gave just $5, the total would reach $5020 without any one person spending more than the price of a few coffees.  You don’t have to make a large contribution to make a difference in our campaign.  Giving a little and spreading the word to your friends and on your social networks could help as much as giving a larger sum.  Help us do something great for the earth and have the time of our lives while we’re at it!

 

*Please tell us if you have any allergies or aversion to animal products such as wool, leather, horn, wool, bones, fur, or wool, with the understanding that virtually all authetic Mongolian crafts utilize some of these (did we mention wool?)

As of 2012, the official charity of all Adventurist challenges is Cool Earth (www.coolearth.org), a UK-based NGO which protects critically threatened areas of South American rainforest.  Founded in 2007, Cool Earth sets itself apart from other non-profits fighting climate change in many ways:
Cool Earth protects areas of rainforest that would otherwise be cleared within the next 18 months, making real-time impact
90% of all donations go directly to funding projects and only 10% go towards Cool Earth’s administration
Cool Earth does this not buy land, but empowers the communities already living on it to have the means and incentives to resist logging
Cool Earth does this by providing rainforest people with:

Education and health care within their own communities.
Renewable sources of income which leave the forest standing.
The means to patrol their land against illegal logging.
 
Why Does It Matter?
The destruction of the rainforest is a major environmental and humanitarian crisis.  Amazonian communities and governments often see no way to profit from their land other than to sell it for clearing.  This provides only very short-term benefits, while doing incalculable long-term harm to their traditional ways of life as well as the planet as a whole. 
Cool Earth gives many reasons why the rain forest is far more valuable standing:

In one year, the roughly one billion acres of standing rainforest absorb an amount of carbon dioxide equal to the entire CO2 emissions of the United States. 
One large rainforest tree stores about 30 tons of carbon – three times what the average person in a developed country produces in one year.
It is estimated that global rises in temperatures due to CO2 emissions would have progressed 10% faster without the Amazon rainforest carbon sink. 
150 acres of rainforest are cleared every minute, equal to an area roughly the size of Los Angeles over the course of one mouth. 
Clearing one acre of rainforest releases 260 tons of CO2, the equivalent of driving a car around the world 32 times.
The rainforest is home to two-thirds of all the biodiversity on the planet.  Many species which live there, especially plants with potential medical value, have not been studied.
1.6 billion people depend on rainforests for their livelihoods.
350 million people live in the rainforest itself, a way of life which includes knowledge of many medical plants and their properties, and which is immediately threatened.
Cleared rain forest soils only remain useful for other activities such as cattle ranching for about two years, after which the soil is depleted and more new land must be cleared, continuing the cycle.
Since 2007, Cool Earth has saved 330,000 acres of rainforest (More since our video was filmed!  Cool Earth's mission is working in real time!), which serve as a barrier to 1.2 million more.  Between all their challenges combined, the Adventurists have raised almost $6 million for a variety of charities since 2004.  Cool Earth needs only about $100 to save an acre of rainforest.  Now the combined efforts of all Adventurists’ fundraising will go towards Cool Earth, a charity which impacts every adventure-hosting country, and every person on the planet.
 
Who Are We?
The team formed in 2009 when Zan learned about the Mongol Rally while in Mongolia doing volunteer work, and started planning to take on the challenge with Jessica, a long-time friend from middle school.  James came on board after meeting Zan through a student organization he headed in Edinburgh, Scotland where they were finishing their bachelor’s and master’s degrees, respectively, in the spring of 2012.  In July the team was christened One Small Steppe and signed up to participate in the Mongol Rally 2013.
As a team we bring a variety of skills to the Rally.  James, a biology graduate of Edinburgh University, has toured Oman by jeep; Jessica studied anthropology at the University of Cincinnati and is an online entrepreneur; while Zan has traveled extensively in Asia and speaks Russian and Mongolian, which she currently studies, along with Mongolian history and current affairs in the department of Central Eurasian Studies at the University of Indiana, Bloomington.
 
How Will It Work?
As a team participating in the 2013 Mongol Rally, One Small Steppe is obligated to raise at least $1600 which will be donated directly to Cool Earth.  We have also pledged to make personal donations to Cool Earth beyond the $1600 minimum to the amount which offsets the carbon footprint of our travel by air and overland.  To raise this direct charity money, we are organizing fund raising events in our communities. 
Apart from this, we are using Indiegogo to raise as much money as possible to offset the cost of our travel.  Our stated goal of $5000 is a bare minimum that would cover most car-related expenses, and we hope to raise money beyond this goal.
First and foremost this money would cover:

Buying a used car
Fuel
Car insurance
Fitting the car with van tires and a shield under the carriage to minimize wear
On-the-road car maintenance
Donating to our car expenses still contributes to charity indirectly, because when we arrive in Mongolia, our car will be auctioned to raise yet more funds for Cool Earth.
Other costs of the trip include:

Plane tickets for two of us to Britain and all of us back from Mongolia
Visas for countries we pass through
Travel insurance
Supplies
Possible emergencies
Any additional money we raise will make our trip that much more worry-free.  All left-over funds will be donated to Cool Earth.  And if for any reason we can’t participate in the rally at all, any funds we’ve already collected will go directly to Cool Earth.
 
Why Should You Help?
Our team believes that adventure and philanthropy go hand in hand.  By making the drive, we’ll spread the news about Cool Earth’s mission beyond our friends and family, to every country we drive through.  Via the internet, we’ll update from the road.  At the journey’s end, more funds will be raised for Cool Earth when our car is auctioned in Mongolia.  Connecting with the world and its peoples is crucial to caring about its future.  By supporting our trip fund, you can help make joining adventure and philanthropy a reality.
All the members of One Small Steppe are in our early 20’s and are, or until recently were, students.  Our families have all been extremely supportive of our ambitions, but we don’t want to burden them or put ourselves in debt to achieve them.  And because we realize that contributing money for spark plugs and spare tires doesn’t have quite the same intrinsic reward as donating directly to charity, we’re offering some great incentive gifts, some of which will come straight from Mongolia!*
$5000 may seem like a lot of money, but if all of our Facebook friends gave just $5, the total would reach $5020 without any one person spending more than the price of a few coffees.  You don’t have to make a large contribution to make a difference in our campaign.  Giving a little and spreading the word to your friends and on your social networks could help as much as giving a larger sum.  Help us do something great for the earth and have the time of our lives while we’re at it!
 
*Please tell us if you have any allergies or aversion to animal products such as wool, leather, horn, wool, bones, fur, or wool, with the understanding that virtually all authetic Mongolian crafts utilize some of these (did we mention wool?)

story:
Do you love the earth? Puppies? Hyperbole? Of course you do! 

Then please take the time to give us $1 (or $5 or $250; that escalated quickly!) because it really will make a difference.

We are just a couple of farmers trying to save our farm from being repeatedly ravaged by thieves. We have spent the past 6 months building a sustainable living exhibit (performance art for farmers!) on a small farm just outside Dallas, TX. Thrice (that's right, thrice!), we have been pillaged! The last break-in was on Christmas day and the rogues took off with over $3000 in loot!

Although the insurance company paid for us to replace our belongings, they (for some odd reason) wouldn't pay for us to fortify our yurt and its surroundings, no matter how inventive our suggestions were. (C'mon, who wouldn't want to spring for a remotely-activated paintball gun hooked up to the wi-fi so that our friends could hunt trespassers, video-game-style.)

Instead we planned to get attack dogs who would happily rip thieves in twain... alas, we got sidetracked at the animal shelter and ended up with two adorable puppies who at worst would lick your effin' face off, as vicious a lickin' as you can imagine, I assure you.

Still, there's an urgent need for us to fortify the premises, our animals, and ourselves. Since our barbed wire fence hasn't deterred them and the dogs desperately need an enclosed area to romp in, we need to fence in our land. We also need to put up more/better security cameras and build a sturdier shed (we're thinking something along the lines of a fortress). 

The lesson we learned from this pillaging is theft is not sustainable, but what we hope to prove is that sustainable is attainable.

Since our finances are stretched between getting the exhibit ready for tours, new puppies, trying to start a family, and increased costs of our insurance, we could really use some help. We are hoping our community (that's you!: friends; family; small farm supporters; burners; Cracked readers; other weird people; citizens of the world) will band together to help make our exhibit an epic win! We want to prove that projects like this (that is, sustainable living) is not only attainable but successful! 

Become part of our exhibit by donating. Even $1 will help. Please share our story with your friends and family if you think they'd be interested in what we are trying to do. It is through your generosity and love that we will make sustainable attainable.

See where the money goes:

  • 400' horse fence with gate: $1618.55
  • 10x12 "unbreakable" shed: $830.21
  • security camera setup: $275.47
  • perks (see below): $375
  • Indiegogo fees: $300

Total of $3399.23

story:
UPDATE NOVEMBER 2013

We plan to resume fundraising for "river clean up" in the late winter and early spring of 2014!  Our apologies for not updating sooner.  The 2013 growing season came on full blast after the last freeze in late May!  We approach Thanksgiving with much gratitude to still be moving forward with an optimal transition of ownership at White Buffalo Farm.  THANK YOU ALL VERY MUCH FOR YOUR DONATIONS! 

In the farm's first Indiegogo campaign earlier in 2013, we successfully raised $1750 for seeds to launch our 2013 growing season.  Thanks to your contributions we are still sending out gorgeous heirloom and slicer tomatoes to our CSA members and other markets!  Thank you!

http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/seed-money-for-colorado-s-oldest-organic-farm-est-1974/x/2783243

Original Content >>

We need your  help to fuel this beast!  It's a 1950 1.5 ton truck Wayne maintains for hauling so that we can keep fleet costs low for the farm.  May Day is the last day to contribute!

After our seed money campaign to keep things flowing, we need money to clear out the river front near the farm buildings.  By contributing to this project, you are part of ensuring a fine transition for oldest organic orchard in the state of Colorado.   We are well known around Colorado for our fine fruit!  And many on the Western Slope love our greens and cage-free eggs!  In addition, your help will ensure the tastiest and freshest squash and tomatoes on the Western Slope.

White Buffalo Farm epitomizes the hopes of so many now drawn to the organic farm movement. Wayne Talmage, the farm's owner, dedicated his last 40 years to making organics a reality in Colorado...and we can honor him by helping to make this year his best ever!  Wayne started the farmer's market in Telluride, served on Gov. Romer's Organics commission, keynoted a talk to western slope growers on organics in 1984 (to good effect as we all know), and was the first to sell pears to Earth's Best Baby Food and other well-known brands in organics, like Whole Foods and Natural Grocers!  Wayne grows using his own organic methods many varieties of pears, asian pears, cherries, apricots, plums, apples, greens, and all kinds of vegetables!

This campaign was created on Indiegogo by me, the Communications and Development Director for White Buffalo Farm.  I have been helping Wayne,since 2010.   We are steering a transition for the farm to new ownership as Wayne needs to retire and would like to hand over the farm to a new management team. The farm needs to be refinanced to optimize its potential in a flourishing organic environment.  We hope to create the condition for a farm-based ecovillage to flourish on this beautiful location.

PLEASE TELL YOUR FRIENDS and anyone you know that is a strong supporter of the organic food movement!  THANK YOU.

Budget for Cleaning up the River Front ~

We will fund projects in the order shown based on the amount of funds we receive. 

We need $750 for fuel to haul materials as needed durng 2013 growing season and to remove existing recyclable materials. 

We need $750 for materials and repairs for a space- efficient, fenced, waste triage center to hold items before they are re-used on the farm, or transported to thrift stores, metal salvage, recycling and as a very last resort, the landfill. 

Whatever we can not recycle locally, we will haul to Denver. Either we will run a campaign to repair our big cooler delivery truck that needs a new engine for $5k. OR we will contract to have these materials hauled. Cost to be determined.  We may pull funds from the following two projects to ensure clean up.

We need $500 for basic landscaping along the river.

We need $250 to set up worm bins for compost  near our wash station and community kitchen. 

Fees:  4% to Indiegogo plus 5% if we don't reach our goal. 

We may need more money than estimated as we go through the process of cleaning up the river front. We will keep you posted. 

Be on the lookout for our next fundable projects: Contracting to haul remaining materials to Denver; repair of our cooler delivery truck; solar projects for hot water on the farm;  $2000 to move our garage facility away from the river and pour a pad for mechanical repairs; a new garage.

The Impact

Cleaning up the farm is important as a river restoration project,  for agro-tourism and for the benefit of all those that visit the farm either as interns and apprentices and for our CSA community and other visitors.  The farm is an ideal location for workshops, a farm stand, a B&B and even a cafe. 

Wayne is holding on until he finds the right buyer.  Whiel I work on the farm sale, he needs to tend the orchards and plant the fields until it sells and in preparation for a fine hand-off!  Wayne and I, along with the farm's long list of supporters, would like to ensure a transition in keeping with the years of hard altuistic work Wayne and many others have offered in service for so many years.

We are actively working towards transferring ownership of the farm.  We hope to create the conditions for a farm-based ecovillage.  Such a village would benefit from the current owner's years of caretaking of this special land with senior water rights and 40 years organic, highly-vitalized soils along the North Fork of the Gunnison River.  The clay soil is also perfect for cob construction and we plan to host our first cob workshop summer 2013!

Make this year a special one!  You will make this year a special one for the last free-roaming, organic farmer of his generation in Colorado!  The early organic pioneers of Colorado!  All the others have given up or gone bankrupt!  Wayne is a living legacy in Colorado's organic movement aka Mr. Organic and godfather of organics! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word. We only have a few weeks to reach our goal!  THANK YOU!  Use the share tools in Indiegogo, make phone calls, send emails.  Simply remember us in your conversations this week.  Thank you!

UPDATE ON OUR LAST CAMPAIGN:  Thank you to all of our fine supporters! We received over $2000 in our last campaign for seed for tomatoes and squash and to bring in the beekeeper!    The tomatoes are being seeded this week!  Squash are started next month.  The bees will buzz this month as the flowers are just starting to blossom all over the orchard, first with the apricots which started to open last week!

For friends less likely to go online, let them know they can contribute by mail directly to the farm.  Checks only by mail, thank you.  White Buffalo Farm, 16877 Grange Road, Paonia, CO 81428  970 422 1373 for questions.

 

Please use the following link to spread the word about our fundraiser on FB! THANK YOU!

It let's you ask your friends to join in and maybe contribute or share it, too!  It feels good and real, like all things farming!                                                                       

Like the farm at    https://www.facebook.com/WhiteBuffaloFarm/

www.whitebuffalofarm.org

This iconic farm was in the New York Times on 2/3/13  We love you Wayne!!!

http://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/03/us/colorado-communities-take-on-fight-against-energy-land-leases.html

story:
***AS OF NOVEMBER 11, 9:20pm.  ALL NEW FUNDING WILL BE DONATED TOWARDS RELIEF IN THE PHILIPPINES.  THE FUNDING WILL BE GIVEN TO FRIENDS OF OURS WHO ARE CURRENTLY AND WILL CONTINUE TO   ASSIST IN THE RELIEF EFFORTS***  


KYLE WILL BE IN THE PHILIPPINES Nov 22nd - Dec 19th AND WILL ENSURE/UPDATE EXACTLY WHERE THE MONEY GOES.  IT WILL HELP FILIPINO'S IN NEED.



THE 295 POUNDS TO DATE RAISED WILL GO TO THE PREVIOUSLY ALLOCATED CHARITIES, UNLESS YOU CONTACT US SAYING YOU WOULD PREFER TO ALLOCATE IT TO OUR NEW CAUSE.  

THANK YOU,  

MILES OF SMILES TEAM



Hey World!

We are three guys who love adventure! Our pursuit of adventure led us to spontaneously sign up to "The Rickshaw Run", a cross India epic adventure driving a traditional "glorfied lawnmower" on wheels!...Also known as a Indian Rickshaw.  

Basically the three of us are going to cram into a rickshaw and drive 3500km in 14 days from Jaisalmer to Kerala (North to South).   Stupid? Daring? Fun?... Maybe a bit of everything, but one thing is for sure along the way we are going to need the help of random strangers!  We are going to need HELP to successfully complete this journey! 

Realistically we realized there is no way we are going to be able to succesfully complete this unless along the way random people help us out.  So we began to think of different times in our lives while adventuring when random people have helped us in times we needed it.  Whether it be the smallest simplest thing, or something massive!  We began to think how could we give back for all the times people have helped us out, and made us happy while adventuring!

This is where YOU come in!  We are raising money for these charities...  

Frank Water (India)

FRANK Water saves lives through funding innovative and sustainable clean water projects in developing countries. Communities are provided with safe, clean water by employing ultra violet and reverse osmosis technology to filter water and remove diseases causing both chemical and biological contaminants.

Cool Earth

Cool Earth works with local rainforest communities to protect rainforest from being cut down.  Rainforest destruction is a massive contributor to climate change and yet every minute 100 acres of rainforest is cleared. If this continues it will not only have a devastating affect on our climate and water supplies but will threaten millions of species of plants and animals.

We are already "Sharing Happiness" in India delivering Smile Packages along our rickshaw run... 

Check out our Facebook Page:  www.facebook.com/milesofsmilesadventures

Check out our Website:  www.milesofsmilesad.com

and we are really excited to raise some money for these two charities!

Thank you for your support!  Every donation inspires us!

Oh!... and we also have a few "Perks" for people who donate certain amounts of money!  Check them out on the page!  

BIG SMILES,

Kyle, James, and Anthony

story:
ATTENTION BACKERS:

We have over 30 different perk items we would like to offer for this campaign. They include signed CDs and Vinyl, House Concerts, Instruments, and Artwork! See below for a list of some of the donors who have made this incredible campaign possible! As perks are purchased, and new perks are offered throughout the campaign, please check in regularly to find exciting offerings of all kinds! 

Any donation made to our campaign, either through overpaying on a perk or donating to us outright, will be honored as a tax deductible donation as we are a 501c3 non profit organization! Please allow us 30 days after the conclusion of this campaign to contact you about this!

TO LEARN MORE ABOUT FEATURED DONORS VISIT this website!

From all of us at Clearwater, thank you very much for considering participating in this campaign!

The Clearwater Hudson River Sloop Story

Clearwater was founded by Pete Seeger, legendary musician, singer, songwriter, folklorist, activist, environmentalist, and peace advocate, and one of the most influential people of the twentieth century. In 1966, in despair over the pollution of his beloved Hudson River, Seeger announced plans to “build a boat to save the river.”  At the time, the Hudson was rank with raw sewage, toxic chemicals and oil pollution; fish had disappeared over many miles of its length. Seeger, along with many other concerned individuals, believed a majestic replica of the sloops that sailed the Hudson in the 18th and 19th centuries would bring people to the river where they could experience its beauty and be moved to preserve it. Inspired by that vision, the organization began with the launch of the sloop Clearwater in 1969 —a majestic 106-foot long replica vessel.

The sloop Clearwater is recognized as America’s Environmental Flagship and is among the first vessels in the United States to conduct science-based environmental education aboard a sailing ship, creating the template for environmental education programs around the world. More than half a million people have experienced their first real look at the Hudson River estuary’s ecosystem aboard Clearwater. In 2004, the sloop Clearwater was named to the National Register of Historic Places for its groundbreaking role in the environmental movement.

Today, Hudson River Sloop Clearwater, Inc. and the iconic sloop Clearwater are carrying forward Pete Seeger’s legacy by partnering with Hudson Valley schools and community leaders to raise the bar of environmental education and encouraging youth to become involved as active stewards of their environment and the Hudson River. Through the organization's multiple environmental education programs, youth empowerment programs, environmental action campaigns, Green Cities initiatives, and unique approach to public outreach, the sloop Clearwater is recognized as a symbol of grassroots action through hands-on learning, music, and celebration.

We Value Your Donation & Will Put It To Good Use

Starting March 1st, Clearwater will be launching a crowdfunding campaign on Indiegogo, the worldwide leader in crowdfunding. This is a great opportunity to make contributions to Clearwater and receive a wonderful reward for your help! We are fundraising in conjunction with our celebration of Clearwater's 50th year and the 100th anniversary of Pete Seeger's life. If you would like to support Clearwater's ongoing educational and activist initiatives please consider participating in this campaign!

You will be able to purchase incentives that have been generously donated to Clearwater on the campaign site. Every week will have new incentives! The incentives include incredible autographed guitars by artists such as The Indigo Girls, Ani Difranco; private house concerts from James Maddock, Aztec Two-Step, Vance Gilbert and Cliff Eberhardt; signed albums by folks like Tom Paxton and Dar Williams; signed artwork by Ani Difranco, Elliott Landy, and Bob Gruen; an incredible one of a kind banjo signed nearly all of the folk royalty you can think of, AND SO MUCH MORE!  YOU help Clearwater and get rewarded for your generosity with something wonderful in exchange.

Your Support Means Continued Environmental & Social Advocacy and Education

"Participation - that’s what’s gonna save the human race.” These are the inspiring words of our founder, folk music icon and environmental activist, Pete Seeger, and they embody the spirit of Clearwater, both as an organization and a community. Through this Indiegogo campaign, we ask that you consider participating, as we celebrate two milestone anniversaries this year. We’ve succeeded in so many ways, thanks to you!

On May 17th, we commemorate the 50th anniversary of the launch of our namesake educational vessel and America’s environmental flagship, the sloop Clearwater. Clearwater has become the symbol for grassroots activism and environmental education in the Hudson Valley.

On May 3rd, we also celebrate the 100th anniversary of the birth of Pete Seeger. It was Pete’s vision and determination to clean up the Hudson River that paved the way for today’s environmental movement.

Over the last fifty years, Clearwater has educated hundreds of thousands of passengers about issues that threaten the Hudson River and the species living in and around its waters.

From the beginning, music has the way in which we celebrate the River and the work that we do to inspire others to participate. What started out as a small folk picnic to help raise funds for the building of Clearwater, has become the country's oldest and largest music and environmental festival. This year’s Great Hudson River Revival will take place on June 15th and 16th at Croton Point Park in Westchester County, NY.

Clearwater has been involved in many advocacy campaigns including PCB remediation in the Hudson River and the closure and safe decommissioning of the Indian Point Nuclear Power Plant. The organization has also undertaken an Article 78 lawsuit against the NY State Public Service Commission to stop the $7.6 billion mandatory subsidy to keep four aging nuclear power plants in operation when they should be shutting down.

Without your support we could not have achieved so many victories over the past fifty years. The next 50 years will be hugely important for this planet. Now, more than ever, we need to keep educating and advocating for the environment.

By contributing to this Indiegogo campaign, you’ll have the opportunity to receive unique incentives. We’ve gathered dozens of items to reward our donors, including signed CDs, artwork, house concerts by popular bands, and signed instruments from friends of Clearwater and Pete Seeger.

In the spirit of participation, we ask you to join us, make a contribution, roll up your sleeves, come aboard, and become a part of our mission to preserve and protect the Hudson River.

Help Us Spread The Word

IndieGoGo campaigns are only as strong as the community it is exposed to! If you are inclined to help us promote this campaign please consider sharing it on social media such as Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, and Google. We sincerely hope you will join us in the effort to fund our educational and advocacy campaigns going forward through this site and to share it with everyone who you feel would be willing to support us!


Thank you very much!

- Hudson River Sloop Clearwater Staff and Board of Directors

story:
" There is no rain this season. My community is waiting for rain and we are very worried that without it, there will be problems for the entire upcoming year. We are experiencing a drought that will impact our health, economic situation, our planting season and affect our animals."

Agripina, Peru

About the book

Stories from the front lines of climate change summarized in a vibrant hardcover book, includes portraits from more than 20 different countries confronting the realities of a warming planet while resisting fossil fuels extractions, mobilizing and fighting for solutions.
Titled after rising temperatures and rising resistance, 1*C Rising covers stories from the worlds largest coal mines in Colombia and Germany, the toxic rivers of Nigeria to fjord mining resistance in Norway. From community energy revolution led by people in Scotland to the snowcapped mountains of Kilimanjaro all the way to the rapidly melting Arctic.

1*C Rising is a journey that travels across all corners of the world, magnifying the connection between people and planet, giving communities a platform to share their experiences and the possibility to reach the hearts and minds, inspire action and responsibility and understanding that a different future is not only possible but necessary.
 


 

What Is The Book like?

The book will cover more than 25 stories from 20 countries from around the world collected since 2010. Each story will have an introduction text written together with someone from the community/campaign, followed by interviews, quotes and reflections from community members, activists and author. We have designed 5 book covers based on 5 areas from 1*C Rising: Dirty Energy, Impacts, Solutions, Forests, People Power!  

All of the stories in 1*C Rising have been collected over the years.  The book will go to print in September 2018.  Therefore, we have some space to add a few more stories and allow more voices to rise!
 

“They came here without consulting the community. We did not get any job opportunities. It seems as if the community has no rights … We used to be safe here. It was peaceful. There was no conflict. Today, we get in trouble for demanding that the [mining] company respects our rights. We are even chased by the police.”

Pa Yusep, Indonesia


These are the stories :

  • Toxic river - Niger delta, Nigeria
  • Living around coal mine in Colombia
  • Bangladesh solar school
  • Resisting oil and gas on Lofoten Islands, Norway
  • Indonesia coal secret
  • Disappearing Arctic
  • Cloudmaker, Kosovo
  • Resisting fracking in Lancashire, UK
  • Grassroot power - Food solution, Croatia
  • Fracking impacts, Groningen, Netherlands
  • Blocking largest coal mine in Germany
  • Balkan flood
  • Bosnia rivers - saving Blue Heart of Europe
  • Coal story from Bangladesh
  • Climate voices from Latin America
  • Grassroots brining Climate Justice to the UNFCCC
  • Last Penan of Borneo forest
  • Social forest, Cameroon
  • Ken Saro lives!, Nigeria
  • People powered revolution in Scotland
  • Saving fjords in Norway
  • Oceans
  • Fracking victory in Northern Ireland
  • Mudslide, Sierra Leone
  • Fossil Free Adriatic
  • Last snows of Kilimanjaro

Titles of the stories might be changed in the book. Some more stories might be added before the book will go to print at the beginning of September 2018.  If you wish to be a part of adding more a stories to 1*C Rising, see Campaign Perk opportunities. (link)


What does the book look like?

  • Dimensions: 210 x 270 mm
  • Photos: more than 250 full-colour photos 
  • Hardcover in 5 different versions ( You pick the one you like!)
  • Pages: 300
  • Language: English

 


The Impact

1*C is a journey of the realities in which we are currently living and speaks the truth of the difficulties we are facing while sharing important messages from front line communities in resistance, struggle and hope.  This book truly connects all corners of the world, magnifying the connection between people and planet, giving communities a platform to share their stories and the possibility to reach the hearts and minds, inspiring action, assuming responsibility and ensuring that a different future is not only possible but necessary.

Photos, interviews and visits to the communities have been completed with the exception of a few.  Now it’s time to share these incredible stories of struggles and victories.  We need your support to get this Book out, designed, printed and send it into the world so that it can be shared widely.


 

Where will your money go?

We appreciate every dollar we get from you, and we would like you to know how we will spend it. If we reach our goal ($ 15 000), this is how it will be distributed:

$11000  -  Print of at least 500 books

$2500   -  Book design and final text proofread

$600     -  Indiegogo fee

$900     -  Additional book distribution costs or adding one more story 



 

One World. One Struggle. 

The aim of the book is to support communities and initiatives all around the world by showing them they are not alone in their struggles. The more books we print and send out to the world, the more impact we will have and the more people we will empower.

We hope stories from this book will be heard, ideas and tactics will be shared, influence will be made and people will rise! 




About author
 

Over the past 8 years, Luka Tomac visited at least 20 countries and collected more than 25 stories of resistance and solutions, followed by photos and interviews of people on the front lines of climate change. 1*C Rising - Stories from the front lines of climate change is his fourth book in which elevates the voices of the local communities fighting for climate justice.  Luka Tomac is the author of three published books and several social art interventions.

Hidden Moslavina, 2012 

Arctic Reflections, 2012

Keepers, 2014 

Angry, 2017 - Mural in Bosnia and Herzegovina


For more information visit  www.lukatomac.com


Support us your way!

Every voice counts in our struggle for climate justice. If you can not buy a book, there are other ways you can support this story. 

Raise your voice and be loud about this campaign: talk about stories from the front lines of climate change among your friends, share our posts and your support on social media, Join the voices for climate justice!

Follow our story on Facebook and Instagram

Thank you for your support!


*Book layout may slightly change in a final design.

story:
Short Summary

We are a few neighbors and composters who wish composting were easy in our city.  We've found it is hard to compost in Aurora, Colorado!  That's why we want to set up 1, 2, or 3 free leaf drop off days in the fall.  They will be open for half of the day on City of Aurora land, ready for leaf drop off in paper or compostable bags.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to make it happen:

  • Each compost roll off bin costs $350 to rent for a day, and we need a bit more to cover campaign fees and transportation costs.
  • If we earn $1300 or more, we will have one in October, November, or December.
  • The City of Aurora is providing the land and infrastructure for the drop offs.  If we can fundraise for the containers, they can do the rest!

What you'll get:

  • With a small donation, you'll help bring this event to life!
  • With a large donation of $50 or more, we'll give you 5 tulip bulbs for your garden
  • With a grand donation of $200 or more, our sponsor Wompost Coop will pick up your leaves from your house at your convenience.

The Impact

  • We will directly divert this biodegradable waste from the landfill, and it will go to Alpine Waste's composting facility to be turned into black gold.
  • Not only does this reduce methane emissions from the landfill, it can reverse climate change (on a small scale). When compost is used in the soil, it literally pulls carbon dioxide out of the air and locks it safely underground.
  • Helping the environment should be easy and free.  If this pilot project is successful, we will likely get funding to expand drop off days from the City of Aurora.

Risks & Challenges

From the popularity of Aurora's trash days, canceled a few years ago, we are worried that this program will be TOO popular, and we will fill up the roll off containers right away!  If we can raise enough funds, we can call for backup on the day of the event.

If we don't raise enough for a roll off on one day, we will have to cancel the event.

Other Ways You Can Help

We could use lots of other help if contributing is too much! 

  • Please get the word out by posting on NextDoor and Facebook.
  • You can volunteer to help direct traffic on the day of the drop off(s).  Contact wompostcoop@gmail.com with subject line "Volunteering"

Thank you SO MUCH

Event Sponsored by Wompost: Aurora's Compost pickup service www.wompostcoop.com, and the City of Aurora Parks Department.

story:
WHO I AM

I am a Brazilian guy from a city named Lages, in South Region, state of Santa Catarina. I always liked cycling and my dream was to live on a sailboat. I am lover of the sea and nature so I can´t see all these things happening without do anything. I will make the difference. Everyone can make the difference. We need to take care about the amount of waste dropped inside the oceans.

My first biketrip was in Northeast Brazil. When I heard several stories that identified myself and led me to decide go chasing my dreams and don't delay them anymore, I am responsible for making this happen. That is when I decided to quit my job and I started planning this project.

World Coast Journey 

The project will aware the people around the World by cycling and sailing the World Coast for the Preservation of the Seas. The journey is split in 8 parts around the globe.

  1. Mediterranean Sea = 16.000 km and 17 countries
  2. Europe = 15.500 km and 14 countries
  3. South America = 25.500 km and 8 countries
  4. Central America=12.000 km and 13 countries
  5. Australia (still under construction)
  6. Africa (still under construction)
  7. Asia (still under construction)
  8. North America (still under construction)

With Europe, Mediterranean, South and Central America the journey already have almost 70.000 km crossing 52 countries.

The first stage will be Mediterranean Coast where I'm going to start in the middle of March 2015.

The inspiration for the project "World Coast Journey for the Preservarion of the Seas" started knowing friend's stories about life on the road in my first big biketrip in Northeastern Brazilian Coast. The route was from Fortaleza to Salvador. On my way to Morro de São Paulo where came the idea about the Preservation of the Seas. I have joined a social and ecological project called "Ecovila Mãos de Luz" that works with children teaching them about the recycling of waste, sharing with people and importance of nutritious food like fruits and vegetables. Side by side with this project we developed a Stand Up Paddle using plastic bottles (PET bottles) to reforce the cause about Reduce, Reuse and Recycle.

 I have always wanted to travel, to see new places, learn new cultures, meet new people and mainly spread where I cross the awareness about the Preservation of the Seas. I gathered all these wills with the dream of living on a sailboat and the story of a friend who made the crossing of the Atlantic ride working on a sailboat to finally walk my way on this project.

What We Need & What You Get

The plan is to make the World Coast Cycling and Sailing, the first stage will be the  Mediterranean Coast. It will be almost 16.000 km in the coast of Mediterranean through 17 countris in 8 months. The average cost per day I'm putting € 10, so I need € 2.400 for this part of the journey. 

The Impact

Marine debris impacts the environment, economy, and human health and safety. The extent of the impacts is determined by the type of marine debris and where it settles in the ocean (e.g., submerged, floating, or within a sensitive habitat). Fishing nets, plastic bags, and tires can sink to the ocean floor and break and smother coral reefs. Fishing line can float along the ocean surface and catch vessel propellers causing costly damage. A syringe can wash up on the beach and be stepped on by a beachgoer resulting in a wound and possibly an infection. Regardless of the type or the location of the marine debris, it can have serious impacts.

It is now believed that there are 5.25 trillion pieces of plastic debris in the ocean. Of that mass, 269,000 tons float on the surface, while some four billion plastic microfibers per square kilometer litter the deep sea. (1)

Hundreds of thousands of sea turtles, whales, and other marine mammals, and more than 1 million seabirds die each year from ocean pollution and ingestion or entanglement in marine debris. Marine debris is manmade waste that is directly or indirectly disposed of in oceans, rivers, and other waterways.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  1. Reduce, Reuse and Recycle the waste

  2. Be a Sponsor or Partner of this journey

  3. Like us on our Facebook page and Instagram

  4. Follow us on Twiter

  5. You can help simply by spreading the message using Facebook using the hashtag #WorldCoastJourney and aware the greatest number of people about it.

  6. See 10 Things You Can Do to Save the Ocean from the National Geographic site

  7. Spread the Preservation of the Seas

  8. Raise aware greatest number of people you can

Access our Website here.
story_txt:
WHO I AM


I am a Brazilian guy from a city named Lages, in South Region, state of Santa Catarina. I always liked cycling and my dream was to live on a sailboat. I am lover of the sea and nature so I can´t see all these things happening without do anything. I will make the difference. Everyone can make the difference. We need to take care about the amount of waste dropped inside the oceans.
My first biketrip was in Northeast Brazil. When I heard several stories that identified myself and led me to decide go chasing my dreams and don't delay them anymore, I am responsible for making this happen. That is when I decided to quit my job and I started planning this project.

World Coast Journey 


The project will aware the people around the World by cycling and sailing the World Coast for the Preservation of the Seas. The journey is split in 8 parts around the globe.


Mediterranean Sea = 16.000 km and 17 countries
Europe = 15.500 km and 14 countries
South America = 25.500 km and 8 countries
Central America=12.000 km and 13 countries
Australia (still under construction)
Africa (still under construction)
Asia (still under construction)
North America (still under construction)


With Europe, Mediterranean, South and Central America the journey already have almost 70.000 km crossing 52 countries.
The first stage will be Mediterranean Coast where I'm going to start in the middle of March 2015.


The inspiration for the project "World Coast Journey for the Preservarion of the Seas" started knowing friend's stories about life on the road in my first big biketrip in Northeastern Brazilian Coast. The route was from Fortaleza to Salvador. On my way to Morro de São Paulo where came the idea about the Preservation of the Seas. I have joined a social and ecological project called "Ecovila Mãos de Luz" that works with children teaching them about the recycling of waste, sharing with people and importance of nutritious food like fruits and vegetables. Side by side with this project we developed a Stand Up Paddle using plastic bottles (PET bottles) to reforce the cause about Reduce, Reuse and Recycle.
 I have always wanted to travel, to see new places, learn new cultures, meet new people and mainly spread where I cross the awareness about the Preservation of the Seas. I gathered all these wills with the dream of living on a sailboat and the story of a friend who made the crossing of the Atlantic ride working on a sailboat to finally walk my way on this project.

   What We Need & What You Get The plan is to make the World Coast Cycling and Sailing, the first stage will be the  Mediterranean Coast. It will be almost 16.000 km in the coast of Mediterranean through 17 countris in 8 months. The average cost per day I'm putting € 10, so I need € 2.400 for this part of the journey.

Marine debris is manmade waste that is directly or indirectly disposed of in oceans, rivers, and other waterways.   
Other Ways You Can Help

 Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:


Reduce, Reuse and Recycle the waste
Be a Sponsor or Partner of this journey
Like us on our Facebook page and Instagram
Follow us on Twiter
You
	can help simply by spreading the message using Facebook using the
	hashtag #WorldCoastJourney and aware the greatest number of people
	about it.
See 10 Things You Can Do to Save the Ocean from the National Geographic site


	Spread
	the Preservation of the Seas 
	



	Raise
	aware greatest number of people you can



Access our Website here.

story:
Overview

For more than 10 years, the Sierra Student Coalition’s Summer Training Program (SPROG) has been empowering young leaders with the tools they need to start movements, run campaigns and create the world they want to live in:

  • We are the Northwest Regional SPROG team.
  • For one week this summer, youth will come together to learn, share, and devolop into the empowered leaders of tomorrow. 
  • Participants learn how to work with the media, facilitate a meeting, recruit members to their cause, meet with decision makers, promote anti-oppression, and much more through fun interactive trainings. Then they are able to apply all of their new skills in a simulation training where a new coal plant is being proposed.
  • "At SPROG, I formed a community with passionate people, where I felt I could return to my other communities to create the change I wanted to see in the world, knowing that I had the support of fellow SPROG parcipants and the skills to make an impact." -Terra Smith, NW SPROG 2010

Your contribution will go towards providing scholarships so that all youth who are interested can attend SPROG, no matter their financial circumstances. With your donation you will be investing in the soul of the youth climate movement.

Funding Details

  • We are raising $2,000 ($1,000 online and $1,000 through events) to provide scholarships to participants to cover their tuition costs. The tuition covers lodging, food, and training materials, which is $350 per person.
  • All training is done completely by volunteers, the majority of which are previous SPROG participants.
  • We think that everyone should have an equal opportunity to come to SPROG and with your contribution we can ensure that the next visionary leader will not be turned away due to lack of funds.

The Impact

  • SPROG provides an oppturtunity for youth to develop their leadership skills and gives them the tools to create positive change. These youth will become leaders in the future.
  • Past SPROG participants, such as Nathan Jones, founder of the Cascade Climate Network and the Northwest Institute for Community Enrichment, have gone on to become important, influential and inspiring leaders.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word and make some noise about our campaign! Let friends and family know about this opportunity to help youth reach their full potential as leaders! 
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools too!
  • Encourage youth you know to attend a SPROG! (bit.ly/sprogapplications2012)

story:
Background

My name is Ditte I am a biologist and conservationist. Since 2010 i have been working pro bono as project support for Niels Mogensen, a lion researcher working in Kenya's famous Maasai Mara area.
 
Niels is passionate about conservation of lions. So passionate that he has spend the last year and a half in a small dome tent, in the middle of Naboisho Conservancy.
 

Saving lions 

As many may not know, lions are getting ever closer to becoming an threatened   species. In less than 20 years there may not be free-raning lions in Kenya and much of Africa anymore. 
 
Niels is trying to change that. He is working tirelessly to save lions and cups from poisoning and spearing in conflicts with close by communities - AND he spend the last 1,5 years sleeping in a small dome tent. 
 
Let's buy him a proper canvas tent! We can get that for 2000 USD ... 

I know that

Niels has spend his entire savings on buying the project car. He is not paid any wages and work solely off the dedication and passion he has for free-ranging lions. Therefore I would love to surprise him with the nice tent, that I know he is dreaming about - and you can help me : ) 
 
Of course no amount is too small. Hey that's the whole point here.. we don't have for contribute a whole lot - but if enough of us care to show the support and chip in, we can provide the basic comfort of a proper tent...

story:
It takes a village...To save the land???

I have a goal.  I am a father.  I want this world to be a better place.

As I ponder just what I can do on my own, it all seems very improbable that my visions or goals will ever be reached.  So I started looking at the village.  You.  Us.  Everyone that reads this and feels an ounce of responsibility to make this sick world a better place.

Here is a quick outline

  • Buy the land.
  • Save the land forever.
  • Work the land and teach the children.
  • Show the village it can be done and give us all hope.
  • Finally we stay connected and figure out how to do it again.

I'm doing the above outline with or without your help.  Your donation will just allow us to protect more land, teach more people and give more in our village hope in this crazy messed up world.

I want to not only become 100% sustainable...I want to show others how we did it and help anyone that wants to go get it.


What We Need & What You Get

Break it down:

  • I have saved 10,000 dollars on my own.  I am asking you for 25,000 more.
  • At the one dollar level I will help promote your cause, twitter and FB.
  • 10 dollar level we will send you a postcard with a picture of the land.
  • Every person contributing more than 35 dollars gets a Tie Dye Shirt!
  • If we do not make it to 25,000 then the money will still be used to protect the land in a land trust.  The land purchased will be protected forever.

The Impact

The main impact will be this.  More money will lead to a larger land purchase.  More land purchased means more land will be protected for all time.

What do we plan to do an the land?.

  • The land will be protected in a land trust.
  • Our family will work the land to create a sustainable lifestyle.
  • We will be recording these projects to offer advice and assistance to others.
  • Most of all I want to teach others and show others that going green is possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Follow my twitter account https://twitter.com/greenlifegoal
  • Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/Family.Land.Conservation.Project

  • See some of the items we are selling with all money going towards this project on our ebay page http://www.ebay.com/sch/lifetimegoals/m.html?item=131093853125&ssPageName=STRK%3AMESELX%3AIT&rt=nc&_trksid=p2047675.l2562

Send me a personal email with any ideas or comments lifegoals2014@gmail.com
