story:
The Challenge

Remember Hurricane Sandy?

You likely saw graphic footage of how badly it affected New York. What you might not know is that two days earlier, the same hurricane tore through Cuba destroying hundreds of thousands of homes and leaving three million people without gas, electricity, or water.

Alarmingly, scientists predict that hurricanes like Sandy will become bigger and more intense in the coming years due to increases in the ocean’s temperature.  It's just one of the many negative impacts of climate change that islands like Cuba must grapple with.

In Cuba, you see, climate change is not just two words that represent a remote concept.

For Cuba, climate change threatens to alter the make-up of everyday life. 

And it’s not just hurricanes.  Dengue fever is on the rise.  Thousands of people from many communities must now be relocated due to sea level rises and coastal flooding.  Climactic changes are impacting almost every sector of the Cuban economy, from agriculture to the health and tourism sectors.

The Context

Cuba can do little to halt actual climate change. What it can do is be proactive in how to adapt.

Thus far, Cubans have had to be inventive. Despite severe limits on how NGOs can access international funds, many experimental and creative initiatives have sprung up around the country.

But great ideas and good intentions will not be enough.  There remains a general lack of education and awareness about climate change and its challenges amongst the Cuban people.  The various initiatives that are underway are not connected to one another in any meaningful way, and their knowledge is not being shared or scaled around the country. 

At this moment, no platform or space exists for collaboration among specialists, local governments and community leaders, all of whom are working to address this serious issue. Worse, many of the public policies that do exist regarding how to adapt to climate change have not encouraged civil participation at the community level.

More needs to be done.  

There is a great opportunity to work, right now, to leverage the great work on climate change adaptation that is happening across Cuba.  There is an opportunity not only to ignite community -and especially youth- participation in tackling this challenge, but also to create a forum that can facilitate capacity building and learning between different stakeholders, a platform that creates opportunities for best practices on climate change adaptation to be shared widely across the country.

 

Our Solution

We are Gioel and Handy and we need your help.

Handy is an environmental activist from Cuba. He has a decade of experience working at the community level on environmental issues including climate change adaptation in Cuba. 

Gioel is the Director of Recrear (www.recrearinternational.org), an organization that works around the world to help young people become active agents in community development.

We met in Montreal as part of the Sauvé Scholars program and we want to bring our expertise together to take action to help Cuba adapt to climate change. 

Our mission is to connect Cubans working on climate change adaptation, especially youth, to help them find and share solutions to this daunting problem.

Our Project

We have designed a project to collect the experiences and best practices of Cuban youth environmental leaders so that they can be documented, shared, and more easily implemented across the country at various community levels. 

We plan to bring together a group of 50 activists with different expertise related to climate change from 13 communities including Havana, Santiago de Cuba, Varadero and others. 

We will implement the project with several local partners, including universities and other organizations including:

  • Cuban Society for the protection of the Environment (ProNATURALEZA)
  • Universidad Central de las Villas. www.uclv.edu.cu
  • CEMZOC-Universidad de Oriente. www.cemzoc.edu.cu
  • Teatro Los Elementos. www.teatroloselementos.cult.cu
  • Caribbean Youth Environmental network. www.cyen.org 

Here is a quick breakdown of the activities we will be coordinating:   

- Design workshop (5 days): This will allow 25 youth environmental leaders to take part in defining and finalizing the design of the entire project.  

- Participatory Research (3 months): We are organizing three months of workshops with 25 young leaders to explore and study their experience and have them share and collaborate on ideas. We will create an open, secure, and creative space - to do so we are utilizing fun, engaging techniques like theatre, photography, creative writing, and debates.   

- Consulting Internships (3 months):  We will be selecting 3 youth leaders to work with us and form a team to advise our local partners on the curriculum design. The interns will be paid a small stipend and will be trained on project design while they work as consultants for our local partner.

- Nationwide consultation (2 weekends): A group of 25 youth environmental leaders from all around Cuba will be reviewing and improving the work of the consulting team.  

The Impact

At its core, our project looks to provide young Cubans a space and platform to work together to develop climate change adaptation strategies and to bring knowledge and experience back to their communities.  The project will provide 50 young environmentalists robust educational training on climate change adaptation, project design and participatory techniques for community involvement.  

Our end goal is to design an easily accessible manual on climate change adaptation; one which documents all that was learned through the project.   The manual will be designed not only for environmental activists and specialists, but with the intent of bringing awareness to educators, government and other stakeholders about best practices and innovations, and which offers guidance on how to replicate and scale adaptation projects at a local and regional level.

We will also seek to use this project to establish a climate change adaptation network that includes young professionals, students and specialists. This will enhance the sustainability of the project and promote continued dialogue and collaboration among all those involved.

Our deliverables

  • Curriculum design consultation with local partners 
  • A manual on best practices to cope with climate change 
  • A video explaining the process 
  • Regular blog entries 
  • A photo book of the project 
  • A manual describing the techniques that have been used in this project 

What We Need & What You Get

The total budget of our project is $48,670 CAD. We have applied for a grant (fingers crossed) to cover half of that (24,900 CAD).

Thus, we are looking to raise $23,770 CAD to cover the second half of the budget.

We will be publishing our final report of the project and will share regular updates on Recrear's website at www.recrearinternational.org.

As an extra boost, we have some awesome perks for you (see side panel).

Other Ways You Can Help: 

Can't make a donation? Don't worry. We still need your help!

Please share our video and campaign, like Recrear on Facebook, follow us on Twitter and let others know about our work.

If you have ideas, suggestions, or want to get involved email us at: recrearinternational@recrear.info.

If you are in Montreal, or Cuba – please contact us and we'll hang out.

Gioel: gioel@recrear.info 

Handy: handy@climacoop.org

 

With great thanks and appreciation,

Handy, Gioel and the Recrear Team

story:
We are a group of paleontologists, archaeologists and geologists, working at the University of Ferrara (Italy), studying the first human peopling. We need your support to continue our research and excavation on Pirro Nord in Southern Italy (Puglia), the one of the most important prehistoric site in Eurasia.

THE PIRRO NORD SITE

 

The Pirro Nord site represents the oldest  testimony of the human peopling in Europe. In fact, after the Out of Africa 1,8 millions years ago, our ancestors went on to colonize the rest of the World  and arrives in Europe 1.5 million years ago as suggested by the results of the excavations conducted on site of Pirro Nord.

 

During the previous excavations we discovered stone tools associated to animals bones like saber-toothed tigers, elephants, deer, horses, baboons, buffalo, hyena and many other. These stone tools give us information about the first human technology  showing the high IQ rate some of our earliest ancestors dated 1,5 million years ago.

Hundred of researchers, students and volunteers came from all around the world (Italy, France, Spain, Portugal, Serbia, Mexico, USA, Brazil, Colombia, Senegal, Namibia, Indonesia, Philippines, India) to join us in this fabulous adventure  form 2004 to 2012.  

The site is locate on the wall of an active quarry at 80 m from the ground. For this reason we are excavating hung like salami having the spectacular view of the landscape and the seaside!

But the site location, inside an active marble quarry, forces us to speed our work in order to rescue all remains and information before the irreversible destruction of the site.

The actual economic situation of Italy doesn’t allow us to have enough funds to continue the excavation.  We need your help to continue the excavation, to continue to form young researchers, to continue to study our archaeological findings and to understand the first human behavior!

 

 

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

Your contribution will help:


- To increase the equipment for the digitalization of data during the excavation in order to accelerate the post-excavations activities;

- to take care of accommodation and feeding of all the team during the excavation campaign (we promise not to eat so much and that we will not have a swimming pool!);

- to promote the excavation results by scientific publications, events, experimental archeology, etc;

 

- to finance the young researchers which  will devoted themselves to the study of the archeological and paleontological material found during the campaign;

- to restore the animal’s bones;

-to cover expenses related to transportation, power generator, the excavation activities, etc;

- to renew the via ferrata to ensure the safety of our team;

 

- to feed the excavation’s dog (our mascot)!

- to organize the “end of excavation” party!

IF YOU CONTRIBUTE YOU MAY TAKE PART TO THIS UNIQUE EXPERIENCE!!!!

 

 

 

HOW THE EXCAVATION WORKS?

We excavate the sediment on the cliff. When something interesting is found, thanks to a total station we are able to record the exact position of the remain in the excavation area, which thanks to specific software will be useful for the reconstruction of different sedimentation processes. This special findings are then bring to the base camp where they are washed carefully, restaured and consolidated for a optimal conservation.

 

The sediment excavated in the site is collected and send by handmade Tyrolienne to the bottom of the quarry where another team is waiting to wash it in order to remove the mug and the dust. After drying, the sediment remain is sieved as to find micro fragment of bones which could belong to small animals. This lead us to the paleoclimatic reconstruction of the area.


When the excavation campaign ends, all the material is bring at the university for detailed study about paleontology, taphonomy, lithic technology, Palynology, sedimentology and so on.

 

 

 

 

ANOTHER WAY TO HELP!

You can share this link with your friends, family and whoever may be interested by this project!

 

 

 

Learn more

Visit our website: https://sites.google.com/a/unife.it/pirro-nord/

Read the essential bibliography

ARZARELLO M., PAVIA G., PETRONIO C., PERETTO C., SARDELLA R., 2012. Evidence of an Early Pleistocene hominin presence at Pirro Nord (Apricena, Foggia, South Italy): p13 site . Quaternary International, 267: 56-61 

PAVIA, M., ZUNINO, M., COLTORTI, M., ANGELONE, C., ARZARELLO, M., BAGNUS, C., BELLUCCI, L., COLOMBERO, S., MARCOLINI, F., PERETTO, C., PETRONIO, C., PETRUCCI, M., PIERUCCINI, P., SARDELLA, R., TEMA, E., VILLIER, B., AND PAVIA, G., 2012. Stratigraphical and palaeontological data from the Early Pleistocene Pirro 10 site of Pirro Nord (Puglia, south eastern Italy). Quaternary International, 267: 40-55

ARZARELLO, M., PERETTO, C., 2010. « Out of Africa : les premières évidences de l’occupation de l’Italie » Quaternary International, Vol.223-224: 65-70.

ARZARELLO M., F. MARCOLINI, G. PAVIA, M. PAVIA, C. PETRONIO, L. ROOK, R. SARDELLA, 2009. L'industrie lithique du site Pléistocène inferieur de Pirro Nord (Apricena, Italie du sud) : une occupation humaine entre 1,3 et 1,7 Ma.L’Anthropologie 113: 47-58.

M. ARZARELLO, F. MARCOLINI, G. PAVIA, M. PAVIA, C. PETRONIO, M. PETRUCCI, L. ROOK, R. SARDELLA, 2007 “Evidence of earliest human occurrence in Europe: the site of Pirro Nord (Southern Italy)” Naturwissenschaften, 94: 107-112.

story:
7th Annual PINNACLES CLIMBER APPRECIATION DAYS
Friday October 18th - thru Sunday Oct 20th, 2019

It is time once again to give something back:

Volunteer to help restore trails and improve climber access paths and staging areas at Pinnacles.

Join together with Friends of Pinnacles, Mud n Crud (Masters of Mud), Pinnacles National Park Foundation, the Access Fund, the American Alpine Club, Pacific Edge and Mountain Tools to support the Pinnacles Trail Crew at Pinnacles National Park.

You will learn skills, make some friends and have a lot of fun!

Saturday evening: Social/Food/Drinks, & Live Auction.

A registration fee ($15 for adults and $10 for children/students) covers Park admission, group camping, Saturday evening food and drinks, Gear Auction (1 ticket included, more can be purchased), commemorative T-Shirt and climbing on Sunday.

Don’t miss a great opportunity!

We (and the park) are spread a little thin this year, so the event will be slightly different than in past years. There will only be one work day (Saturday the 19th) and the number of participants will be limited to fifty (50). Group campsites will still be available both nights (Friday and Saturday).

Pass this along to your climbing partners and friends!

Join us for some rewarding work and fun!!!

story:
Help to Save The Honeybee

         Introduction to the Project By Dr. Joseph A. Resnick, Professor Emeritus

I'd like to Thank You for your concern and for caring about the Planet and for the life forms that inhabit same, especially, the Honey Bee.  The planet, and the Honey Bee are "fragile" and we, as 'Steward's of the Planet', have a duty to protect both.

I'd like to 'qualify' this project and demonstrate how critically-important this issue is by reminding you that "Every third bite of food that you consume is due to pollination by the Honeybee or other Pollinators".

Man must stop using chemicals, e.g., nicotinoids, and other lethal pesticides, in his food supply.  Research has proven that these lethal chemicals are  known to 'be a contributing factor in Colony Collapse Disorder', can cause genetic mutations and could potentially alter Man's genetic profile.  We must find alternatives and stop using conventional pesticides!  And we have done that and we need your help to get this technology to the Beekeepers, worldwide!  Take a look at this presentation by Marla Spivak...excellent presentation about the Pollinators: http://www.ted.com/talks/marla_spivak_why_bees_are_disappearing.html?source=facebook#.UnBYCo7IL7B.facebook

This Project involves and impacts every living thing on this planet!  I request that you start at this link where you can find out more about me, but more importantly this project and where it's heading.  We need your support to achieve our objectives.  Please start by taking a look at the information found on the following link: http://contest.techbriefs.com/2013/entries/sustainable-technologies/by-views/3266-saving-the-honeybee-low-toxicity-integrated-pest-management-product

What We Need

We need $150,000 Dollars so that we undertake an intense Field Study of the LTIP product leading toward certification and marketing.  Funds will be used to pay stipends to our academic research teams (at two colleges) to do field research; to provide teams with new beekeeping equipment (Garments/gloves; Nuc's, Gum's, Super's, etc.); to expense the supply of filtered beeswax; to pay for machine time; to pay for the costs of state and Federal filing fees required to obtain certification so these can be sold in the USA and exported to global markets.  We will also set-aside 10% of all funds donated to establish an educational fund that will provide basic beekeeping equipment and learning materials (books, etc.) to inner-city school programs that provide classes in Beekeeping (i.e., the Loyola Urban Beekeeping Project, 4-H Clubs, and HOPE OFIRIHA developed Onura, Sudan).  Read more at http://www.ehow.com/list_7516763_beekeeping-projects.html#ixzz2fe67WC23) and http://www.ehow.com/list_7516763_beekeeping-projects.html . We are doing this because we believe that we must teach our children about this situation or there might not be enough food to feed them and their children in 10 or 20 years.

One of our goal's is to make the product less costly and easier to obtain than present beekeeper supplies and pesticides.  Our pricing structure will be based on the 'spot price' for filtered beeswax, and we will purchase at the time of year when the price of beeswax (from commercial sources, e.g., Dadant & Sons Apiaries or Brushy  Mountain Bee Farms) is at the seasonal low.  The large chemical companies, that have unlimited financial resources, have a (literal) 'strangle-hold' on the apiculture industry (and agriculture, in general) and they are just too large and fiscally-powerful to engage them (or 'fight' them), directly. 

The only way to really impact the industry is to make a product that is 'more eco-friendly, better and easier to use, and less expensive' than the products that Beekeeper's are 'forced' to use, today (e.g., bee cakes, bee strips, or powdered products).  And we have done that: Our tests prove it!  Take a look at a recent article I published in a leading, international scientific Journal regarding "LTIP" at: http://www.rmannco.com/low-toxicity-ipm-products.html and at Page 1. at http://www.pluralidade.info/Eindex.html . The paper was peer-reviewed and was published by our colleagues in Brazil where Beekeeping is a billion-dollar industry.

                                       

                                 This is what happens when a hive 'swarms'

We realize that we're attempting to raise a lot of money through donations.  In today's economy even colleges and universities are finding it difficult to raise money to support basic research, and we recognize the potential that we may not reach our funding goal.  But, even if we don't every dollar donated will go directly to support research and nothing else.  We can't and don't expect the researchers to work, Pro Bono, and new beekeeping supplies cost a lot of money.  So we're hoping that everyone who reads this information, and anyone who 'eats-food', will realize just how very, very important this project truly is and help us in one way or another. If everyone who reads about this issue and would donate just One Dollar, we'd reach our benchmark very quickly.  If you can't afford to donate, you can help in other ways, like, posting our link on your Facebook Wall, posting a news 'blurb' about the project to your Twitter-family/friends, your favorite Blog, or sharing news about us F2F with your friends, and even contacting us to 'get a story/interview' for an article you might be writing, or a school Science paper?  If you want to write a paper about this subject for a school or college class (extra-credit), Dr. Resnick would be happy to help you (just ask or contact him!).  Word-of-mouth is one of the best ways to help any good cause and you can help us that way, too!

 What You Get

We have some really exciting 'Perk's' for our supporters.  Everyone who donates $1.00 or more will receive a copy of one of two musical CD's provided by one of our major supporter's, Guitarist, Cheryl Alexander. 

                                                  

You can see more info about these perk's at https://itunes.apple.com/us/artist/cheryl-alexander/id60320476 or http://www.cdbaby.com/artist/cherylalexander .  Cheryl has also written a companion lyric/poetry book with a reflection on each song or poem. Some of the songs in “Reflections” are on recordings that have not yet been published or they are on previous limited edition recordings. Her book can be viewed or purchased at: http://www.lulu.com/spotlight/69LPCustom .  Supporters at the $10.00 level will receive all three of the above perk's. 

We also have the CD's and a one-pound Jar of the Best Sourwood Honey from our growers in North Carolina for a donation of just $20.00!  And for $50.00 you'll get all the underlying perk's, plus a matching hat and Tee-shirt showing that states: "I Helped to Save The Honey Bee".  You can see our other perk's in the column on the right hand side of this page.  We really need your financial and moral support for this project, and we can't do it without your help.  So, you are a 'Stakeholder' in this project, too.

Project Impact

Since 1996 Dr. Resnick has been concerned with onset of parasitic infestations in feral bee populations in the USA and has experimented with several methods aimed at addressing this problem.  Since 2006-2008 studies have identified a condition termed, ‘Colony Collapse Disporder’, in which parasitic infestation(s) play some role and have been determined to be a contributing factor in the decrease of domestic honey production and imparting negative impact to crop pollination/production, in
general.  Our studies (above) have revealed that there are additional contributing factors that promulgate CCD and these are not found in any of the literature.

Studies, such as those found at http://www.ars.usda.gov/is/br/ccd/ccd_actionplan.pdf and http://www.epa.gov/pesticides/about/intheworks/honeybee.htm,
indicate that additional research is needed to better identify and define
causes and develop potential remedies, while following recommended guidelines
in the ARS’ Action Plan.  More recently, the USDA published this update
which points out major concerns with efforts to save the Honeybee. I had
no hand in authoring this paper, but, as you'll see...what the USDA is stating
is needed to offer viable solutions to this problem, is precisely what I've
developed, i.e., a new, sustainable/renewable way, and a low-toxicity pesticide
that will destroy the varrowa mite...but not kill the honeybee...and that's
exactly what I've done!!!  Read this report: http://www.usda.gov/documents/ReportHoneyBeeHealth.pdf .

In 2012 Dr. Joe Resnick commenced efforts to produce next-generation treatment modalities utilizing a proprietary microencapsulation process and instrumentation, developed in cooperation with NASA/JPL-MSF and tested aboard STS-41 and STS-43, with objective toward advancement of an IPM (Integrated Pest Management) protocol designed to address the recalcitrant problem of parasitic infestation in bee
colonies by the Varroa mite (V. destructor) and trachea mites.  Additional embodiments were considered with attention to developing second generation treatment methods for at least two aspects of colony collapse disorder (“CCD“), more specifically, Varroatosis, and infestations by the Parasitic Phorid Fly, Apocephalus boreali. The secondary consideration was to utilize Coumaphos (camphorated oil) as a possible adjuvant as opposed to Fluvalinate which has been found to be ineffective in ARS’s Phase II experimental paradigms.

 

These efforts had clear objectives with defined goals being:

1.To identify, qualify/quantify, natural substances best suited for use in the creation of new products for use in the prevention/treatment of varroa mite infestation;

2.To create eco-friendly (natural) chemical countermeasures that comprise a low-toxicity delivery system and components;

3.To create next-generation products that are:

A. Highly effective;

B. Quick~Easy to use (deploy/apply/re-treat);

C. Capable of reducing stressors to individuals comprising the colony by making the product manufactures more readily-accessible with manufactures being made in sizes between 5um to 150um and with control of molecular polarity resulting
in easier transport by worker bees.

Field Trials in Progress

We have three (3) field trials in progress where the 'LTIP' product is being evaluated by members of our research team.  The first project was commenced in June 2013 in Santa Rosa, CA by Mr. Sherman Hahs who is widely known in the Greater Santa Rosa Area as, 'The Bee Whisperer'.  Sherm operates an apiary at his farm in Santa Rosa and performs (emergency) bee/wasp removals in his 'spare time'. Sherm has used the product in 5 of out test-hives with outstanding outcomes.  A paper is planned for publication in which details of the study will be subjected to Peer Review prior to publication.  Here's photo of Sherm's Apiary in Santa Rosa.

 

                    

Sherm's  initial studies undertaken on a small scale at a Beta Test Site located in Santa Rosa, California have shown promising results to date in terms of accomplishing the above goals.

We also have a project in place in Lenoir, NC where we are culturing next-generation Queen Bees.  The NC-study focuses on pre-treatment of the queen-breeder combs so that if the queen varroa mite lays an egg in the queen-egg cell-comb the egg is 'neutralized' by the eco-friendly pre-treatment method using the LTIP product.  Here's a photo of our project in NC.  Master Beekeeper, Mr. Dan Kirby, (shown holding one of the new queen-egg cell-combs in his left hand) who has been a member of the NC Beekeeper's Association for more than 60 years, has oversight of the project in NC('Thanks, Dan!').  Dr. Joe Resnick is shown below right completing final assembly of 2 'Nuc's' that Mr. Kirby is using to culture the new queen bee broods.

          

     

We have fellow beekeepers in China and India who are anxious to be able to obtain the new LTIP Products.  Although CCD has not spread to some regions in China and India, 'prevention' is the desired approach to preventing occurrence and spread of this syndrome.  Below are photographs of our colleague in India using his own 'Super' made from all natural (local) woods.  You'll notice that the Indian Bee Box looks nothing like those used in the Western World.  The photo of our Chinese colleagues shows how experienced Beekeepers can 'have fun' with their bees!

 

Risks and Challenges

I have made every effort toward minimizing the risks to success in completing this project. I have the time, expertise, equipment needed to produce the products for field testing, and have a Beta-tests site already in place where preliminary testing
has proven successful. Mr. Sherman Hahs has reported that his initial application and use of the new L-Tip product has performed 'outstandingly' and that his bees are free of all mites of any kind.

The greatest 'challenge', as we see it, will be to move the product through the 'red-tape' commonly associated with getting a new 'pesticide' product into the market place and obtaining the requisite state and Federal approvals under existing laws that will enable me to do that. To that end I have taken extreme care to solicit the involvement and guidance from the appropriate state and Federal agencies and officials tasked with oversight of such products and will comply with all requirements necessary under ARS Guidelines enabling me to bring this product to market.

I don't think I'll have much trouble getting the necessary approvals, as the materials I'm using are natural, organic substances that are already in widespread use in the marketplace (this is called, "Grandfathering" or obtaining approvals under a 'Grandfather Clause'). To make my product I use 100% natural Beeswax to create the microcapsules (manufactures) that are about the same size as a grain of pollen which is easy for the bee/pollinator to carry back to the hive (reducing 'stressors'). The substances I use are available, worldwide, which can be purchased at just about
every retail store in the Free World. The significance of what I am doing is to make the substances more readily-accessible to the Worker Bees by making the adjuvant 1) easier for the bee to carry back to the hive and to the place inside the hive (frames) where the honeycombs are built and into which the bees place nectar/pollen; 2) reduce the 'stressors' that worker bees experience when other kinds of (bee-cakes or wafer-strip type products) are used to treat the colony for diseases or infestations by mites/moths/flies. Read this article, which speaks exactly to the need to reduce stressors as being beneficial and helpful to the effort to save the honeybee: http://www.usda.gov/documents/ReportHoneyBeeHealth.pdf

I truly don't anticipate any problems in registering this product with the USDA, as,
'technically', I could take the product to market...today (if I had the funding to do so)! The product is common beeswax and an essential oil that anyone can purchase anywhere on the planet.  Again, what makes this product so different and unique is how I create it and make the manufactures comprising the product and how I put the active ingredient(s) inside the microcapsule: That's what 'separates the wheat from the chaff'.  When I do this the result is a product (microsphere-containing adjuvant) that is absolutely 'unique' and has never been used before as a method of treating parasite infestations in pollinators.

FAQ's

Q.  What's your Track Record?

A.  I've been an Applied Scientist/Inventor for >40 years and hold 26 Patents, 12 of which are not in the Public Domain.  And I am a member of the North Carolina Beekeepers Association and the Caldwell County Beekeepers Association.

Q.  Do you have a presence on FaceBook?

A.  Yes. You can find me at https://www.facebook.com/Dr.Joe.Resnick

Q.  If I want to contact you how can I get in touch with you?

A.  I'm very 'accessible' on the internet.  Best way to reach me is through the email portal at www.rmannco.com or www.vansforvets.org .  Either of those should get you to me.

This Project involves and impacts every living thing on this planet!  I request that you start at this link where you can find out more about me, but more importantly this project and where it's heading.  We need your support to achieve our objectives.  Please start by taking a look at the information found on the following link: http://contest.techbriefs.com/2013/entries/sustainable-technologies/by-views/3266-saving-the-honeybee-low-toxicity-integrated-pest-management-product
What We Need 
We need $150,000 Dollars so that we undertake an intense Field Study of the LTIP product leading toward certification and marketing.  Funds will be used to pay stipends to our academic research teams (at two colleges) to do field research; to provide teams with new beekeeping equipment (Garments/gloves; Nuc's, Gum's, Super's, etc.); to expense the supply of filtered beeswax; to pay for machine time; to pay for the costs of state and Federal filing fees required to obtain certification so these can be sold in the USA and exported to global markets.  We will also set-aside 10% of all funds donated to establish an educational fund that will provide basic beekeeping equipment and learning materials (books, etc.) to inner-city school programs that provide classes in Beekeeping (i.e., the Loyola Urban Beekeeping Project, 4-H Clubs, and HOPE OFIRIHA developed Onura, Sudan).  Read more at http://www.ehow.com/list_7516763_beekeeping-projects.html#ixzz2fe67WC23) and http://www.ehow.com/list_7516763_beekeeping-projects.html . We are doing this because we believe that we must teach our children about this situation or there might not be enough food to feed them and their children in 10 or 20 years.
One of our goal's is to make the product less costly and easier to obtain than present beekeeper supplies and pesticides.  Our pricing structure will be based on the 'spot price' for filtered beeswax, and we will purchase at the time of year when the price of beeswax (from commercial sources, e.g., Dadant & Sons Apiaries or Brushy  Mountain Bee Farms) is at the seasonal low.  The large chemical companies, that have unlimited financial resources, have a (literal) 'strangle-hold' on the apiculture industry (and agriculture, in general) and they are just too large and fiscally-powerful to engage them (or 'fight' them), directly.  
The only way to really impact the industry is to make a product that is 'more eco-friendly, better and easier to use, and less expensive' than the products that Beekeeper's are 'forced' to use, today (e.g., bee cakes, bee strips, or powdered products).  And we have done that: Our tests prove it!  Take a look at a recent article I published in a leading, international scientific Journal regarding "LTIP" at: http://www.rmannco.com/low-toxicity-ipm-products.html and at Page 1. at http://www.pluralidade.info/Eindex.html . The paper was peer-reviewed and was published by our colleagues in Brazil where Beekeeping is a billion-dollar industry.
                                       
                                 This is what happens when a hive 'swarms'
We realize that we're attempting to raise a lot of money through donations.  In today's economy even colleges and universities are finding it difficult to raise money to support basic research, and we recognize the potential that we may not reach our funding goal.  But, even if we don't every dollar donated will go directly to support research and nothing else.  We can't and don't expect the researchers to work, Pro Bono, and new beekeeping supplies cost a lot of money.  So we're hoping that everyone who reads this information, and anyone who 'eats-food', will realize just how very, very important this project truly is and help us in one way or another. If everyone who reads about this issue and would donate just One Dollar, we'd reach our benchmark very quickly.  If you can't afford to donate, you can help in other ways, like, posting our link on your Facebook Wall, posting a news 'blurb' about the project to your Twitter-family/friends, your favorite Blog, or sharing news about us F2F with your friends, and even contacting us to 'get a story/interview' for an article you might be writing, or a school Science paper?  If you want to write a paper about this subject for a school or college class (extra-credit), Dr. Resnick would be happy to help you (just ask or contact him!).  Word-of-mouth is one of the best ways to help any good cause and you can help us that way, too!
 What You Get
We have some really exciting 'Perk's' for our supporters.  Everyone who donates $1.00 or more will receive a copy of one of two musical CD's provided by one of our major supporter's, Guitarist, Cheryl Alexander. 
                                                   
You can see more info about these perk's at https://itunes.apple.com/us/artist/cheryl-alexander/id60320476 or http://www.cdbaby.com/artist/cherylalexander .  Cheryl has also written a companion lyric/poetry book with a reflection on each song or poem. Some of the songs in “Reflections” are on recordings that have not yet been published or they are on previous limited edition recordings. Her book can be viewed or purchased at: http://www.lulu.com/spotlight/69LPCustom .  Supporters at the $10.00 level will receive all three of the above perk's. 
We also have the CD's and a one-pound Jar of the Best Sourwood Honey from our growers in North Carolina for a donation of just $20.00!  And for $50.00 you'll get all the underlying perk's, plus a matching hat and Tee-shirt showing that states: "I Helped to Save The Honey Bee".  You can see our other perk's in the column on the right hand side of this page.  We really need your financial and moral support for this project, and we can't do it without your help.  So, you are a 'Stakeholder' in this project, too. 
Project Impact
Since 1996 Dr. Resnick has been concerned with onset of parasitic infestations in feral bee populations in the USA and has experimented with several methods aimed at addressing this problem.  Since 2006-2008 studies have identified a condition termed, ‘Colony Collapse Disporder’, in which parasitic infestation(s) play some role and have been determined to be a contributing factor in the decrease of domestic honey production and imparting negative impact to crop pollination/production, ingeneral.  Our studies (above) have revealed that there are additional contributing factors that promulgate CCD and these are not found in any of the literature.
Studies, such as those found at http://www.ars.usda.gov/is/br/ccd/ccd_actionplan.pdf and http://www.epa.gov/pesticides/about/intheworks/honeybee.htm,indicate that additional research is needed to better identify and definecauses and develop potential remedies, while following recommended guidelinesin the ARS’ Action Plan.  More recently, the USDA published this updatewhich points out major concerns with efforts to save the Honeybee. I hadno hand in authoring this paper, but, as you'll see...what the USDA is statingis needed to offer viable solutions to this problem, is precisely what I'vedeveloped, i.e., a new, sustainable/renewable way, and a low-toxicity pesticidethat will destroy the varrowa mite...but not kill the honeybee...and that'sexactly what I've done!!!  Read this report: http://www.usda.gov/documents/ReportHoneyBeeHealth.pdf .
In 2012 Dr. Joe Resnick commenced efforts to produce next-generation treatment modalities utilizing a proprietary microencapsulation process and instrumentation, developed in cooperation with NASA/JPL-MSF and tested aboard STS-41 and STS-43, with objective toward advancement of an IPM (Integrated Pest Management) protocol designed to address the recalcitrant problem of parasitic infestation in beecolonies by the Varroa mite (V. destructor) and trachea mites.  Additional embodiments were considered with attention to developing second generation treatment methods for at least two aspects of colony collapse disorder (“CCD“), more specifically, Varroatosis, and infestations by the Parasitic Phorid Fly, Apocephalus boreali. The secondary consideration was to utilize Coumaphos (camphorated oil) as a possible adjuvant as opposed to Fluvalinate which has been found to be ineffective in ARS’s Phase II experimental paradigms.
 
These efforts had clear objectives with defined goals being:
1.To identify, qualify/quantify, natural substances best suited for use in the creation of new products for use in the prevention/treatment of varroa mite infestation;
2.To create eco-friendly (natural) chemical countermeasures that comprise a low-toxicity delivery system and components;
3.To create next-generation products that are:
A. Highly effective;
B. Quick~Easy to use (deploy/apply/re-treat);
C. Capable of reducing stressors to individuals comprising the colony by making the product manufactures more readily-accessible with manufactures being made in sizes between 5um to 150um and with control of molecular polarity resultingin easier transport by worker bees.
Field Trials in Progress
We have three (3) field trials in progress where the 'LTIP' product is being evaluated by members of our research team.  The first project was commenced in June 2013 in Santa Rosa, CA by Mr. Sherman Hahs who is widely known in the Greater Santa Rosa Area as, 'The Bee Whisperer'.  Sherm operates an apiary at his farm in Santa Rosa and performs (emergency) bee/wasp removals in his 'spare time'. Sherm has used the product in 5 of out test-hives with outstanding outcomes.  A paper is planned for publication in which details of the study will be subjected to Peer Review prior to publication.  Here's photo of Sherm's Apiary in Santa Rosa.
 
                     
Sherm's  initial studies undertaken on a small scale at a Beta Test Site located in Santa Rosa, California have shown promising results to date in terms of accomplishing the above goals.
We also have a project in place in Lenoir, NC where we are culturing next-generation Queen Bees.  The NC-study focuses on pre-treatment of the queen-breeder combs so that if the queen varroa mite lays an egg in the queen-egg cell-comb the egg is 'neutralized' by the eco-friendly pre-treatment method using the LTIP product.  Here's a photo of our project in NC.  Master Beekeeper, Mr. Dan Kirby, (shown holding one of the new queen-egg cell-combs in his left hand) who has been a member of the NC Beekeeper's Association for more than 60 years, has oversight of the project in NC('Thanks, Dan!').  Dr. Joe Resnick is shown below right completing final assembly of 2 'Nuc's' that Mr. Kirby is using to culture the new queen bee broods.
           
      
We have fellow beekeepers in China and India who are anxious to be able to obtain the new LTIP Products.  Although CCD has not spread to some regions in China and India, 'prevention' is the desired approach to preventing occurrence and spread of this syndrome.  Below are photographs of our colleague in India using his own 'Super' made from all natural (local) woods.  You'll notice that the Indian Bee Box looks nothing like those used in the Western World.  The photo of our Chinese colleagues shows how experienced Beekeepers can 'have fun' with their bees!
  
Risks and Challenges 
I have made every effort toward minimizing the risks to success in completing this project. I have the time, expertise, equipment needed to produce the products for field testing, and have a Beta-tests site already in place where preliminary testinghas proven successful. Mr. Sherman Hahs has reported that his initial application and use of the new L-Tip product has performed 'outstandingly' and that his bees are free of all mites of any kind. 
The greatest 'challenge', as we see it, will be to move the product through the 'red-tape' commonly associated with getting a new 'pesticide' product into the market place and obtaining the requisite state and Federal approvals under existing laws that will enable me to do that. To that end I have taken extreme care to solicit the involvement and guidance from the appropriate state and Federal agencies and officials tasked with oversight of such products and will comply with all requirements necessary under ARS Guidelines enabling me to bring this product to market. 
I don't think I'll have much trouble getting the necessary approvals, as the materials I'm using are natural, organic substances that are already in widespread use in the marketplace (this is called, "Grandfathering" or obtaining approvals under a 'Grandfather Clause'). To make my product I use 100% natural Beeswax to create the microcapsules (manufactures) that are about the same size as a grain of pollen which is easy for the bee/pollinator to carry back to the hive (reducing 'stressors'). The substances I use are available, worldwide, which can be purchased at just aboutevery retail store in the Free World. The significance of what I am doing is to make the substances more readily-accessible to the Worker Bees by making the adjuvant 1) easier for the bee to carry back to the hive and to the place inside the hive (frames) where the honeycombs are built and into which the bees place nectar/pollen; 2) reduce the 'stressors' that worker bees experience when other kinds of (bee-cakes or wafer-strip type products) are used to treat the colony for diseases or infestations by mites/moths/flies. Read this article, which speaks exactly to the need to reduce stressors as being beneficial and helpful to the effort to save the honeybee: http://www.usda.gov/documents/ReportHoneyBeeHealth.pdf
I truly don't anticipate any problems in registering this product with the USDA, as,'technically', I could take the product to market...today (if I had the funding to do so)! The product is common beeswax and an essential oil that anyone can purchase anywhere on the planet.  Again, what makes this product so different and unique is how I create it and make the manufactures comprising the product and how I put the active ingredient(s) inside the microcapsule: That's what 'separates the wheat from the chaff'.  When I do this the result is a product (microsphere-containing adjuvant) that is absolutely 'unique' and has never been used before as a method of treating parasite infestations in pollinators.
FAQ's
Q.  What's your Track Record?
A.  I've been an Applied Scientist/Inventor for >40 years and hold 26 Patents, 12 of which are not in the Public Domain.  And I am a member of the North Carolina Beekeepers Association and the Caldwell County Beekeepers Association.
Q.  Do you have a presence on FaceBook?
A.  Yes. You can find me at https://www.facebook.com/Dr.Joe.Resnick
Q.  If I want to contact you how can I get in touch with you?
A.  I'm very 'accessible' on the internet.  Best way to reach me is through the email portal at www.rmannco.com or www.vansforvets.org .  Either of those should get you to me.

story:
Our Vision for 2018 and beyond...

We are launching NatureSong 2018! A music festival that truly WORKS with Nature! Our Mission Statement is very simple. We will leave this place in better condition than we found it!

Imagine a festival that is like a small sustainable village...

-  safe for children to wander and for parents to explore

-  powered entirely by clean and renewable sources of energy

-  with locally sourced food, zero-waste and without producing any garbage

- outhouses that are 100% compostable, semi-hidden in nature, built by local carpenters/artists as unique pieces of art

- music and art will be shared with the highest considerations to wildlife and with great joy for the human ear.

www.facebook.com/events/1679256992356763

Musicians, multi-disciplinary artists and engineers who are passionate about the environment and ecology, are invited to participate.

There will be an opportunity for every member in our community to participate in this unique endeavour.

To get this project started, please make a contribution that makes you happy!

It will make a difference!   ​http://natureboyproject.com/​​

While applying for a grant of $65,000, it made sense to demonstrate that our community can raise $10,000 in this upcoming fundraiser.  

This campaign will help kick-start our projects and will pave the way to our new Eco-Art festival - a musical project called "NatureSong" 2018!

By making a contribution you are taking the first step towards making this dream a reality!

Thank You!  http://www.facebook.com/events/822076551291744

Here is how your money will be allocated:

$5,000 will go directly to musicians and artists who have committed to take part in the NatureSong Festival 2018!

$5,000 will go to carpenters, engineers and designers to develop and build the infrastructure for NatureSong 2018!

https://www.facebook.com/NatureBoyProject/

Here are some estimated costs for NatureSong Project:

Renewable Energy - $25,000 - $30,000
- hydro-kinetic under water turbine is € 9,500 
- pre-wired off grid electrical is € 6,500

Food & Kitchen - $15,000 - $20,000
- locally sourced organic food: $8,000
- filtration system for water: $2,000
- kitchen & equipment: $7,000

Village - $30,000 
(teepees, tree-houses, outhouses, safety)

Music/Art/Workshops - $40,000 
(musicians, artists, sound & technicians)

Design - $10,000

Total: $120,000 - $130,000

The guidelines of the BC Music Fund, indicates that under the live music program, we are eligible to apply for a grant to cover up to 25-50% of project expenses. We are applying for a grant of $65,000! 

We already have 40% of our budget on hand and in the coming months we'll be seeking sponsorship and launching a fundraising campaign to help further support The NatureSong Project!

story:
www.clearwater.org 

Hudson River Sloop Clearwater  was launched in 1969 by musician and activist Pete Seeger to bring attention to a very polluted Hudson River in New York.  In the past 45 years,  over 500,000 people of all ages have experienced the Hudson River estuary aboard Clearwater and the river has become a cleaner, healthier watershed as a result.  However, Clearwater's mainsail and boom need to be replaced.  

Clearwater is a membership-supported environmental organization offering educational programs, environmental action initiatives, a yearly eco-music festival and much more.  Clearwater seeks to raise $25,000 to help replace the mainsail and boom.  (The total cost of the project is $40,000.)  

Your support will:  

  • Keep Clearwater sailing 
  • Keep the Hudson River clean
  • Enable groups of all ages to experience the beautiful Hudson.

story:
This project is about saving lives year after year. In order to make an impact on as many people as possible, we are humbly asking for your support to launch the Save5 Foundation - an organization to support living donors and their families.

We will be documenting the first steps of creating the foundation through YouTube, Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram as we follow the very first living donor and recipient duo; me and my brother John.

Recently, John found out that he has liver cancer. As his younger brother and an exact blood type match (O positive), I make a great candidate for a living donor liver transplant. Not only do we have the same blood type, but because we are siblings there is less chance that John’s body will reject part of my liver transplanted into him. This is the best-case scenario for saving John's life.

Living donor transplants involve physical risk for both the donor and the recipient, but more concerning is another issue that faces most families considering this option; how to pay the bills. Research suggests that the recipient’s insurance should cover the cost of the surgery and hospital stay for both individuals. However there are travel expenses, post care considerations, and lost wages that are not covered by insurance.

I began to wonder how many people could be saved every year if financial support is available. It occurred to me that I had more to give than a lobe of my liver to my own brother. That’s when I made a pledge to myself, and now the world, that I would start a foundation dedicated to helping save the life of five people before December 31, 2013.

This is where I need your help, because I can’t save those lives alone. I’m asking for a modest pledge of $25 to help me cover expenses and launch the Save5 Foundation. The foundation’s mission is as elegant as it is simple; to save five lives each year by offering financial and emotional support to living transplant donors. It’s not often that we have an opportunity to save one person’s life and now you have a chance to help save five. Each year after 2013, we’ll continue our endeavor to save five more lives.

Please take a few moments to donate $25 to Save5, and share this with your own friends and family. We are accepting donations of any size, so please feel free to give what your situation and heart will allow. Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

       You can't go wrong with homegrown veggies and herbs. I want to use my passion for horticulture and use it to help out the very person who entertained me to the idea, my grandmother. When I was twelve years old my grandmother taught me about reciprocity and how we should respect ourselves, each other and nature. That was fifteen years ago and horticulture has become a hobby of mine ever since. My friends and family endearingly think of me as a "tree hugger" and a "hippy". I am passionate about the environment and love work on my vegetable/herb garden. I also feel it is important to inform others of the benefits of agriculture as it is the foundation for a healthy livelihood. 

       My grandmother owns a small apartment complex which is family and pet friendly. There is a large community yard which is in desperate need of maintenance for both safety reasons and curb appeal. With my love for horticulture and experience in landscaping I feel it would be a great asset to the community and her business to create a small herb/vegetable garden in the yard which is accessible to everyone. 

      The reason I am putting my campaign on Indiegogo is primarily due to the lack of funds. I help my grandmother with the business as much as I can after my grandfather passed but she is struggling. I am currently enrolled in college full time for an anthropology degree and work part time. Neither she nor myself have the funds to maintain curb appeal primarily because maintaining the inside of the units takes financial precedence.  There are also two dead pine trees that are a gust away from falling onto the apartments themselves. This urgent tree removal alone has been estimated at $1,800.00. This campaign would be beneficial to everyone in the community and help a wonderful women in need.

I am looking to raise 3,500 for gardening supplies such as;

Soil, fertilizer, seeds, plants/trees, irrigation supplies, compost, weather covers, wood, paint, hand tools, table and chairs, row covers, ect. to cover 3,000 sq.ft. Along with a professional tree removal service.

      I have been personally working on this project for my grandmother with the help and interest of neighbors for almost a year and I am short on funding to complete the project.

story:
Why the Campaign? 

The Continental Divide Trail (CDT) needs you.  This campaign is a focused crowd sourcing effort to rally outdoor and environmental communities across the country towards supporting the future of this incredible national scenic trail.  Federal funds for land preservation are slowly being restricted due to sequestration and federal spending cuts. The trail corridor and its preservation is falling through the cracks, and is facing great capacity difficulties in maintaining what so many have worked so hard to build.  Dollars from this campaign will directly support much needed advocacy and protection efforts, map making, data collection, and volunteer trail building.

From 1995 to early 2012, the primary supporter of the Continental Divide Trail was the Continental Divide Trail Alliance (CDTA).  The CDTA ceased operations in January of 2012, leaving a large gap in trail stewardship, advocacy and support.  Passionate trail management professionals and volunteers have made it their mission to continue building and sustaining the CDT through this new organization, the Continental Divide Trail Coalition (CDTC).

CDT Gap Map

Take a look at this map of the areas where the CDT remains unprotected and vulnerable. Nearly 30% still needs us to finish the job and not let this nationally significant experience falter under our watch.

Urgency to Support the CDT:

While 72% of the Trail is complete, there are still 800 miles in need of construction, reconstruction to national trail standards, moved off of roads, or managed to meet standards of a National Scenic Trail

There are still 200 plus miles of the CDT on Roads with major sections in the Carson National Forest in New Mexico and the Muddy Pass area of Colorado

  • The Forest Service Budget is shrinking (17% in 2013 ) and this is impacting how the Trail is managed and supported by the Agency.  There needs to be, a voice advocating for this not to happen to say it is worth public funds to keep the progress moving forward on the CDT

  • There are numerous threats around  the Trail Corridor due to energy projects such as powerlines and wind farms in view from the Trail Corridor or other activity such as clear cuts or open-pit mines that have potential to negatively impact the Trail Experience

  • The cost of completion for the CDT including land acquisition, trail construction and management activity are estimated at $27 million dollars
  • Deteriorating Trail conditions need our attention including replacing infrastructure like bridges on dangerous river/stream crossings and potential loss of the maintained route

  • The need for a free informational map of the CDT with information about its protection, partners and uses, is needed all along the Trail. We have the map, now we need the text
  • There are threats of losing protection for all headwaters in the United States which start on the Continental Divide due to loss of Trail Corridor protection which will affect all downstream drinking water for all U.S. citizens

Campaign Coverage:

Mountain Magazine Online: Bridging the Divide

Silver City Daily Press: Coalition to Protect Trail

Reddit & CollaborativeFund

 
Video Updates:

Why Suppoort the CDT? / CLICK HERE to watch interview with Pamela Underhill With out a strong national non-profit partner, the Continental Divide Trail is at risk of being left behind. Pamela Underhilll, former NPS Appalachian Trail Park Office Superintendent, shares why the CDT needs the same kind of partner as the Appalachian Trail Conservancy has been for the Appalachian Trail and why supporting this campaign helps make that happen.

Watch Mark Flagler's "Finding My Way on The Continental Divide" video!

 

What is The Continental Divide National Scenic Trail (CDT)? 

The CDT is one of the most significant trail systems in the world, spanning 3,100 miles from Canada to Mexico. In 1978, Congress established a 50-mile wide corridor on either side of the geographic Continental Divide in which to build the CDT.  The CDT connects countless communities along its spine across Montana, Idaho, Wyoming, Colorado and New Mexico traversing three national parks, one national monument, 25 national forests, and eight BLM areas.  It is one of the three National Scenic Trails belonging to the ‘Triple Crown’ (along with Pacific Crest Trail and Appalachian Trail) and is typically noted within the thru-hiking community as being the highest and wildest. 

Who is the Continental Divide Trail Coaltion (CDTC):

CDTC formed to establish strong community-based relationships through activities that support the construction, maintenance and support of the CDT. The organization feels that cultivating local relationships with communities adjacent to the Trail and involving volunteers on the ground is the most powerful way to build our movement and preserve and protect the CDT.  Through these networks of individuals, groups, and local communities, we will build a strong and healthy voice for the CDT that will help promote the vision for the CDT and ensure it remains a national landmark for generations to come.

Plans for 2014:

  • Maintenence of 300 miles of CDT in Colorado
  • Sponsor 10 volunteer construction projects trail wide
  • Develop an additional 5 miles of new CDT
  • Coordinate public advocacy efforts to protect CDT
  • Update CDT map and line data for public use
  • Participate in national trail advocacy efforts

CDTC Mission & Vision: The CDTC seeks to create a community committed to construct, promote, and protect in perpetuity the CDT. Our vision is that the CDT becomes a renowned and revered natural resource for you to connect with friends and family, draw inspiration, and create outstanding personal experiences.

Major Partners:

Volunteers of Outdoor Colorado, Leave No Trace and Appalachian Trail Conservancy and American Hiking Society

Sustaining and building a quality organization and program is dependent on strong public and private partnerships across the country.  We are so thankful to all of our campaign partners and sponsors!

*see below for other partners and sponsors

 

The Perks:

$5 / Elk Bugle You are awesome ...and because you're awesome, we're going to give you a once in a lifetime 'elk bugle' style shout-out on our website and social media accounts thanking you for your support! ; )

 $15 / Trail Angel Here's our rockin' water bottle.  Slick, smooth, classy, lightweight and easy to attach to just about anything!  

 

                                   

$20/ Honoring Jim Wolf  We're rallying the CDT community to gift one CDT trailhead sponsorship to someone who for years has given so much to this trail and its community.  He is responsible for making the CDT thru-hiking experience a successful one for so many through publishing the first set of CDT guides. Contribute $20 now to honor Jim Wolf!

$25 / Sip it, Stick it, Shout-out CDT goodie bag: mug, patch, trail marker, stickers and elk bugle style shout-out. ; )

$50 / The Dreamer You will get a 2014 CDT calendar, Mark Flagler's 'Walking the Great Divide' DVD and CDT goodie bag!

 

$75 / Beer Lover Tumbler You will receive a limited edition handmade CDT branded Beer Tumbler made high in the Rocky Mountains.  Goodie bag included!

$100 / Map Book Genie Pick the map book of your choice!  Choose from Montana, Idaho, Wyoming, Colorado and New Mexico.  We will contact you shortly after our campaign to check which Map Book you would like.  Goodie bag included!

$200 / Honor and Heart Limited edition commemorative wooden brand sign to show a sincere commitment to protecting and honoring the heart and treasure that is the CDT.  One beer tumbler and goodie bag included!

$500 / Thru-Hiker For the route planners, adventure seekers and long-distance trail supporters - the ultimate perk!  All CDT map books, CDT map, CDT calendar, One Beer Tumbler, one wooden commemorative CDT branded sign, one CDT branded water bottle and goodie bag included!  (See images above for visuals of what's included!)

$1,000 / Trail Head Sponsor In recognition of your contribution your name will be placed at one of five trail heads as the official sponsor showing the world how much you love the CDT.  Trail head locations willbe across the entire trail and you may even help us install the Trailheads. Trailheads will be installed in 2014.  Your support will hit the eyes of thousands as they walk this wild and incredible trail.  Beer tumbler and goodie bag included!

$1,750 / Pie Town to Grants Ramble Take a guest and join us for a fun 5 day excursion in either May or September of 2014 traveling and walking along unique roadways and CDT environs throughout Pietown, The El Mal Pais and Grants, New Mexico. Meet locals, connect with the CDT and eat pie.  Transportation from Albuquerque will be proivded.  Accomodations will be camping and hostel style,  but opportunities for some hotelling will be possible. You'll need your own personal gear and the rest of the trip is on us.  Beer tumbler, commemorative pie plate, and goodie bag included!


$3,100 / Brewers for a Day & More! We have an exclusive opportunity for 3 lucky people to be "Brewers for a Day" with the AC Golden Brewing Company in Golden, CO.  This will come in the form of a certificate and you can schedule the tour when it suits your party of 3.  AC Golden Brewing Company only offeres tours to special guests!  Plus you'll receive a case of Colorado Native, 3 limited edition CDT beer tumblers, wooden commemorative CDT sign, map book, DVD, calendar and goodie bag!

 

Major Sponsors:

A huge thank you to our event and campaign sponsors!

The Trail Show, AC Golden Brewing Company - Colorado Native, Great Harvest Bakery, Whole Foods Governor's Ranch, Wildfire Pottery, ULA Equipment, Walk2Connect and Bear Creek Survey Service, Pie-o-neer Cafe

Campaign & Communications Partners:

Thank you to our communication and social sharing partners!

Pacific Crest Trail Association (PCTA), Partnership for the National Trail System (PNTS), Colorado Trail Foundation (CTF), American Hiking Society (AHS), AC Golden Brewing Company - Colorado Native, Continental Divide Trail Society (CDTS), Mark Flagler of Flagler Films

Other Ways You Can Help:

Become a CDTC Member! Consider becoming a long-term supporter and friend with the Continental Divide Trail Coaltion as we work to preserve and protect this incredible corridor and trail.  See here for details!

Be a campaign sharing champion! We need ALL the help we can get in regards to sharing this campaign with all who have benefited from being on our beautiful trails.  Please consider doing one or all of the following throughout our 45 day campaign!

Share our campaign:

- On Facebook / with a photo of the CDT
- On Twitter / use #hikecdt & include @CDNST1
- In emails to your friends and family
- With any hikers, writers, bloggers, outdoor magazines & publications
- Create photos and flyers and post at local retail shops / ask us for the QR code!

Hiked on the CDT? Share your photos and stories with us!  You can email them to info@continentaldividetrail.org

Video & Image Credits:

Music Creation: John Hildreth
Video Editing: Jenny Gomez and Kerry Shakarjian (Teresa Martinez, Jonathon Stalls and John Hildreth)
Photo Credits: Eric Herbst, Paul Magnanti "pmags", Jon Pierson, Kerry Shakarjian, Jerry Brown, Anneliese Ring, Teresa Martinez, David Dolton, Stephanie Friday-Allen, CDTC stock images
story_txt:
Why the Campaign?  
The Continental Divide Trail (CDT) needs you.  This campaign is a focused crowd sourcing effort to rally outdoor and environmental communities across the country towards supporting the future of this incredible national scenic trail.  Federal funds for land preservation are slowly being restricted due to sequestration and federal spending cuts. The trail corridor and its preservation is falling through the cracks, and is facing great capacity difficulties in maintaining what so many have worked so hard to build.  Dollars from this campaign will directly support much needed advocacy and protection efforts, map making, data collection, and volunteer trail building.

From 1995 to early 2012, the primary supporter of the Continental Divide Trail was the Continental Divide Trail Alliance (CDTA).  The CDTA ceased operations in January of 2012, leaving a large gap in trail stewardship, advocacy and support.  Passionate trail management professionals and volunteers have made it their mission to continue building and sustaining the CDT through this new organization, the Continental Divide Trail Coalition (CDTC).
CDT Gap Map
Take a look at this map of the areas where the CDT remains unprotected and vulnerable. Nearly 30% still needs us to finish the job and not let this nationally significant experience falter under our watch.

Urgency to Support the CDT: 

While 72% of the Trail is complete, there are still 800 miles in need of construction, reconstruction to national trail standards, moved off of roads, or managed to meet standards of a National Scenic Trail
There are still 200 plus miles of the CDT on Roads with major sections in the Carson National Forest in New Mexico and the Muddy Pass area of Colorado


The Forest Service Budget is shrinking (17% in 2013 ) and this is impacting how the Trail is managed and supported by the Agency.  There needs to be, a voice advocating for this not to happen to say it is worth public funds to keep the progress moving forward on the CDT

There are numerous threats around  the Trail Corridor due to energy projects such as powerlines and wind farms in view from the Trail Corridor or other activity such as clear cuts or open-pit mines that have potential to negatively impact the Trail Experience

The cost of completion for the CDT including land acquisition, trail construction and management activity are estimated at $27 million dollars


Deteriorating Trail conditions need our attention including replacing infrastructure like bridges on dangerous river/stream crossings and potential loss of the maintained route

The need for a free informational map of the CDT with information about its protection, partners and uses, is needed all along the Trail. We have the map, now we need the text




There are threats of losing protection for all headwaters in the United States which start on the Continental Divide due to loss of Trail Corridor protection which will affect all downstream drinking water for all U.S. citizens

story:
Meet the green team. 

Stefano, born in Mexico, loves all living things.  He shows us where our food comes from.

Susie, Harry Potter fan, recycles everything!  She takes us to the transfer station and the dump.

Mateo, champion break dancer, turns up the beat as he turns off the lights.  He walks us through the power plant.

Hawthorn, the artist, paints us a picture of the water treatment plant.

 

Together, they took their community by storm with their documentary (www.youtube.com/watch?v=RlcNdOo5ZzU).  Now they want to go national.  Project Learning Tree, a project of the American Forest Foundation, has invited them to do just that in February.  

 

Florida will host this year’s National Green Schools Convention, and the kids want to be a part of it.  The green team plans to present their documentary and talk about their experiences to hundreds of conference attendees from around the country.  They will also listen to other presentations, participate in workshops, and learn new skills.

 

Now, they’re only lacking the means to get there.  You are the key.  You can open the door to these four kids, allow them the meet the nation, and send them home with valuable knowledge and experience that will inspire their peers and community to protect our planet.

 

We plan on setting up bake sales and car washes to finish funding the project in case our Indiegogo proposal does not meet its goal.  We appreciate any kind of moral or monetary support.  Thanks for telling your friends about our goal as well, using the Indiegogo share tools.

Stefano, born in Mexico, loves all living things.  He shows us where our food comes from.
Susie, Harry Potter fan, recycles everything!  She takes us to the transfer station and the dump.
Mateo, champion break dancer, turns up the beat as he turns off the lights.  He walks us through the power plant.
Hawthorn, the artist, paints us a picture of the water treatment plant.
 
Together, they took their community by storm with their documentary (www.youtube.com/watch?v=RlcNdOo5ZzU).  Now they want to go national.  Project Learning Tree, a project of the American Forest Foundation, has invited them to do just that in February.  
 
Florida will host this year’s National Green Schools Convention, and the kids want to be a part of it.  The green team plans to present their documentary and talk about their experiences to hundreds of conference attendees from around the country.  They will also listen to other presentations, participate in workshops, and learn new skills.
 
Now, they’re only lacking the means to get there.  You are the key.  You can open the door to these four kids, allow them the meet the nation, and send them home with valuable knowledge and experience that will inspire their peers and community to protect our planet.
 
We plan on setting up bake sales and car washes to finish funding the project in case our Indiegogo proposal does not meet its goal.  We appreciate any kind of moral or monetary support.  Thanks for telling your friends about our goal as well, using the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
2017 EMGS Young Scientist Award

Environmental Mutagenesis and Genomics Society

Ever wonder what things in the environment do to your genes? We are the Environmental Mutagenesis and Genomics Society (EMGS), scientists in academia, government, and industry working to understand the genetic impacts of environmental exposures to promote human health. Through research we learn how genes in your body respond to the environment, how changes impact health and get passed to your children, and what we should do about this.

EMGS Young Scientist Award

EMGS is committed to helping young scientists - our future - make critical career transitions. At our Annual Meeting, we feature the EMGS Young Scientist Award, a chance for a new investigator embarking on an independent scientific career to give a plenary talk. Don't underestimate this honor! Face-to-face communication is one of the most important ways we learn, network, and make our science better.

You Pick the Winner

The EMGS Young Scientist Award is based on YOUR support and YOU will choose the winner from the candidates below! Please view their competition videos via the links, above. 

Voting has closed for 2017 but you can continue to contribute to the Young Scientist award Funding.

Contestants are screened by EMGS and invited to participate. All are just finishing their education and training or within 3 years of establishing an independent scientific career. This is a unique opportunity to participate in science and support a promising young scientist.

  • Bogdan Fedeles: is a research scientist at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, in the department of Biological Engineering and Center for Environmental Health Sciences (CEHS), working in the lab of the CEHS director Dr. John Essigmann. The overarching goal of Dr. Fedeles’ research is to develop a unified framework for decoding the mutational records of cells, which would enable early cancer diagnosis, better exposure risk assessment and insights into disease etiology. To study mutagenesis, Dr. Fedeles utilizes a multidisciplinary approach, which includes biological chemistry to construct site-specific nucleic acid lesions and analogs, chemical and spectroscopic tools to study lesion biochemistry, and molecular biology and genetics experiments to assess the contribution of the genetic background to mutagenic outcomes. His current work investigates the mutagenic consequences of inflammation, and their contribution to the mutational burden observed in many inflammation-dependent human cancers. 
  • Ludmil Alexandrov: completed his PhD in 2014 at the University of Cambridge and since then he has been an Oppenheimer Fellow in Theoretical Biology at Los Alamos National Laboratory. Ludmil’s research has been focused on understanding the mutational processes in human cancer through the use of mutational signatures. Ludmil developed the first comprehensive map of mutational signatures in human cancer and demonstrated the applicability of mutational signatures to cancer prevention and cancer treatment. Ludmil has more than 55 publications in well-respected scientific journals and he has won multiple awards for his work on mutational signatures, including:  listed as “30 brightest stars under the age of 30” by Forbes magazine; a Harold M. Weintraub Award by the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center; Prize for Young Scientists in Genomics and Proteomics by Science magazine; Carcinogenesis Young Investigator Award by European Association for Cancer Research. Ludmil is currently one of six co-investigators leading the Mutographs of cancer, a project that seeks to understand the unknown cancer-causing factors across the globe by examining mutational signatures from 5,000 cancer patients from 17 countries across five continents.
  • Nikolai Chepelev: has developed strong and diverse expertise in toxicogenomics during postdoctoral training at the Genomics Laboratory of Health Canada, led by Dr. Carole Yauk. For this work, he has received three awards: two from Risk Assessment Specialty Section of the Society of Toxicology (e.g., Best Published Paper Advancing the Science of Risk Assessment - 2015) and one from the Environmental and Molecular Mutagenesis (EMM; New Investigator Best Paper Award - 2016). Nikolai showed how toxicogenomics can benefit health risk assessment by providing mechanistic information to explain neurotoxicity and carcinogenicity of benzo[a]pyrene as an example. He has recently joined Genetic Toxicology Laboratory at Health Canada (Leader - Dr. Paul White), where he is applying both traditional toxicity tests (bacterial mutagenicity and transgene mutation assays) and toxicogenomics. His goal is to develop high-throughput platform for in vitro Genetic Toxicity Assessment of chemicals that will rely on both traditional and emerging technologies. These efforts will facilitate our movement towards improved 21st century approaches in toxicology and health risk assessment.

  • Natalie Saini: is currently a postdoctoral scientist in Dr. Dmitry Gordenin’s lab at the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences.  She is working towards establishing herself as an independent researcher in the near future.  Dr. Saini’s overarching research goal is to determine the range of genome-wide mutation loads and to identify the mutation signatures in the cells of healthy individuals to decipher environmental and genetic causes of genome instability.  She utilizes simple model organisms like yeast to understand how environmental agents affect DNA stability, and to apply this knowledge in more complex human research.  Her combinatorial approach enables her to answer key questions regarding the impact of environmental damage on mutagenesis in humans, resulting in important insights into how these factors affect human health.

The Rules

Anyone making a tax-deductible donation of any amount gets a vote (you may donate/vote as many times as you'd like). The candidate with the most votes wins.

Up to $2,500 will go toward hosting the award winner's attendance at the meeting and a small honorarium. Additional contributions will support the travel of more young scientists to the annual meeting in Raleigh, NC.

The 48th Annual Meeting of the EMGS

Environmental toxins and toxicants impact human physiology and biochemistry by altering or modifying DNA, RNA, proteins and metabolites. Across the spectrum of scientific inquiry, we are challenged with understanding the mechanisms which respond to or modulate these genotoxic effects. Furthermore, the development of tools for analysis, as well as, for evaluation of these biological endpoints are critical for the promotion and protection of human health. By forging a bridge to bring scientists studying exposures, mechanisms, and regulatory sciences, the 2017 Annual Meeting of the Environmental Mutagenesis and Genomics Society (EMGS) will provide a venue for stimulating cross-disciplinary research and discovery. We will learn how environmental agents impact genomic, proteomic and metabolic signatures, and how we can use this knowledge base to develop informed biomarkers and improved regulatory policies that address human health concerns related to environmental exposures. Join us as we cross this bridge, find common ground in our advances in the study of Environmental Health Sciences, and bring together our efforts on Exposure, Mechanism and its impact on Public Health.
