These efforts will facilitate our movement towards improved 21st century approaches in toxicology and health risk assessment.
Natalie Saini: is currently a postdoctoral scientist in Dr. Dmitry Gordenin’s lab at the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences.  She is working towards establishing herself as an independent researcher in the near future.  Dr. Saini’s overarching research goal is to determine the range of genome-wide mutation loads and to identify the mutation signatures in the cells of healthy individuals to decipher environmental and genetic causes of genome instability.  She utilizes simple model organisms like yeast to understand how environmental agents affect DNA stability, and to apply this knowledge in more complex human research.  Her combinatorial approach enables her to answer key questions regarding the impact of environmental damage on mutagenesis in humans, resulting in important insights into how these factors affect human health.
The RulesAnyone making a tax-deductible donation of any amount gets a vote (you may donate/vote as many times as you'd like). The candidate with the most votes wins.Up to $2,500 will go toward hosting the award winner's attendance at the meeting and a small honorarium. Additional contributions will support the travel of more young scientists to the annual meeting in Raleigh, NC.The 48th Annual Meeting of the EMGSEnvironmental toxins and toxicants impact human physiology and biochemistry by altering or modifying DNA, RNA, proteins and metabolites. Across the spectrum of scientific inquiry, we are challenged with understanding the mechanisms which respond to or modulate these genotoxic effects. Furthermore, the development of tools for analysis, as well as, for evaluation of these biological endpoints are critical for the promotion and protection of human health. By forging a bridge to bring scientists studying exposures, mechanisms, and regulatory sciences, the 2017 Annual Meeting of the Environmental Mutagenesis and Genomics Society (EMGS) will provide a venue for stimulating cross-disciplinary research and discovery. We will learn how environmental agents impact genomic, proteomic and metabolic signatures, and how we can use this knowledge base to develop informed biomarkers and improved regulatory policies that address human health concerns related to environmental exposures. Join us as we cross this bridge, find common ground in our advances in the study of Environmental Health Sciences, and bring together our efforts on Exposure, Mechanism and its impact on Public Health.

story:
Short Summary

I am an environmentalist at heart, concerned for the planet since I was very young. I have been looking for solutions to the crisis our generation inherited; and found what I consider to be the most effective and holistic solution to modern day problems, and it not only solves problems and reveres crisis, but also brings us closer to a better version of ourselves, it certainly has for me.  

  • We can reverse ecological degradation with our collective high vibration by being better humans.  
  • If we achieve the funds to produce this event, we can prove to the world that there is a much more effective way of addressing today's problems. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • I need $20,000 USD to produce an online event.
  • With the funds I will contact experts,  interview them, create the web site, upload and share the event live for free. 
  • I did the research and found experts that can shed light on a subject so relevant to our times.
  • I will be transparent to how the money will be spent on the Summit website. 
  • People who subscribe, will receive the interviews for free during a limited time period. 
  • If you donate to the cause, you will get access to the entire summit so that you can watch it whenever you want. 
  • If I do not reach my goal, I will produce the event with what I accumulate and will contribute from my own pocket to get the event done. 

The Impact

This campaign's purpose is the raise the funds necessary to produce an online event to start a movement that calls to a better version of humans. Your contribution can make a difference in the future of our species:

  • Imagine reversing deforestation, drought, plastic islands, coral reefs, endangered species with pure intention and vibration, without physical intervention and with little or no costs at all. 
  • This project can shift the future of humanity, expand consciousness and make us better human beings in a healthier planet. 
  • My most successful projects have been ones where my pure spirit has guided me.
  • If this project succeeds, I want to travel the world and heal areas with environmental challenges. I have absolute faith that we can collectively reverse environmental problems with love and intention. 

Risks & Challenges

I want to be transparent with the risks and want to share some of them with you.

Solving environmental issues with our vibration and pure loving intention may need people with previous knowledge and personal growth for the intention to work. 

  • This issue can be solved by working with them and sharing today's latest discoveries about human frequency, meditation, nutrition, relationships, etc. so that the intention has better effect inside and outside. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you like the project, the movement we are promoting and find yourself with difficulty to contribute, there are other ways you can help. 

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
(English translation follow)

Qu'est-ce que TerraVie?

TerraVie est un organisme de conservation sans but lucratif et une œuvre de bienfaisance qui a pour mission de démontrer à l’aide d’exemples concrets qu’une intégration harmonieuse des activités humaines avec l’environnement naturel est possible. Nos deux principales activités sont donc la protection à perpétuité des milieux naturels et la réalisation à proximité de projets écologiques respectueux de l’environnement, tels l’habitation écologique, des éco-gites verts, des aménagements botaniques et d’écotourisme. Le troisième volet de l’action de TerraVie qui complète sa mission est l’éducation environnementale. Ce concept global a mérité le prix Phénix de l’environnement en 2007 dans la catégorie « développement durable ».

Ce que nous avons déjà accompli

En 2006, grâce d’une part à un programme gouvernemental et, d’autre part, aux efforts de financement d’une équipe de bénévoles, TerraVie a acquis un terrain de 288 acres dans la municipalité de Montcalm, dans la MRC des Laurentides. Depuis, ce terrain a fait l’objet de nombreux aménagements et de constructions créatives

Depuis son acquisition, la majeure partie du terrain a d’abord été constituée en aire protégée et ensuite en Réserve naturelle du Lac-du-Brochet protégeant à perpétuité de nombreuses espèces vulnérables. Pour pouvoir ouvrir officiellement ce site au public, TerraVie doit développer écologiquement des aménagements récréatifs et éducatifs et des installations écotouristiques. 



Notre équipe de bénévoles a déjà entamé les aménagements du centre d’accueil situé dans la réserve naturelle comprenant : une passerelle d’accès, 600 mètres d’un sentier pédestre accessible aux visiteurs en fauteuils roulants, des affiches signalétiques, un cabanon, des toilettes à compost dont une pour les personnes à mobilité réduite, un abri vert éducatif démontrant diverses techniques de construction écologique, un jardin de plantes indigènes et le début de l’aménagement de plusieurs kilomètres de sentiers en forêt.


De plus, une yourte traditionnelle de Mongolie est installée dans la section du grand jardin communautaire dont les bassins d’eau sont irrigués par une pompe bélier.

Un four à pain en argile y a été monté lors d’ateliers éducatifs.

La fréquentation du lac est facilitée grâce à des quais installés aux trois différents points d'accès.


Actuellement, nous travaillons sur la construction de notre premier bâtiment permanent, le Centre d’interprétation de la nature, pour lequel nous sollicitons votre aide.


L’objectif de cette campagne : construction du Centre d’interprétation de la nature

Le Centre d'interprétation de la nature à l'entrée de la zone d'accueil de notre réserve naturelle sera un lieu de rassemblement pour les visiteurs ainsi qu’un centre éducatif sur l’environnement et le développement durable où seront présentés des formations, des ateliers, des conférences, des expositions artistiques ainsi que des évènements thématiques incluant la vente de produits et services divers. (Pour plus de détails sur les activités éducatives de TerraVie, veuillez suivre le lien suivant www.terravie.org ). Le Centre contiendra un petit cinéma des bois, une bibliothèque verte et une terrasse de dégustation de produits de la forêt.



Le bâtiment du Centre de la nature est conçu selon les principes des 3RV : réduction, réemploi, recyclage et valorisation.

Il servira de modèle de construction écologique. Il comprendra différents systèmes intégrés : système de recyclage des eaux grises par les plantes, gestion de l’eau de pluie, pompage de l'eau du lac à l’aide de vélos, « Rocket Stove » et poêle à bois pour le chauffage et la cuisson, système d'énergie solaire, etc.  En mettant de l’avant des approches et des technologies écologiques innovatrices qui sont à la portée de tous, TerraVie veut démontrer qu’il est possible d’intégrer des infrastructures publiques en nature en réduisant considérablement notre empreinte écologique.


En somme, par cette initiative, nous souhaitons:

  1. permettre aux gens d’accéder aux milieux naturels tant pour des fins récréatives qu’éducatives
  2. les inspirer à adopter les technologies vertes assurant la santé des écosystèmes et des collectivités présentes et futures
  3. et collaborer aux activités de revitalisation des petits villages avoisinants.




Voici une liste des activités envisagées du Centre :

  • Accueil des visiteurs et renseignements, vente de produits (cartes du site, fiches éducatives, articles promotionnels, etc.), visites guidées;
  • Exposition en images des essences d’arbres et des espèces d’animaux de la réserve;
  • Sensibilisation du public aux habitudes et aux actions écologique grâce à des conférences et ateliers divers;
  • Projection de films traitant des questions environnementales;
  • Organisation d’évènements de célébration et de campagnes de financement divers;
  • Création d’une bibliothèque sur divers sujets concernant la protection de l’environnement et les alternatives en construction et en énergie;
  • Location du lieu pour différentes sessions prolongées de thérapie ou d’art en nature (yoga, Qigong, musique, peinture, sculpture, photographie, etc.) en lien avec les futurs éco-gîtes.

Atelier de crépi à la chaux


Avancement du projet et votre support

À l’heure actuelle, ont déjà été réalisés : les piliers de fondation, la charpente, les murs extérieurs, la toiture et l’isolation du toit, certaines fenêtres et portes, quelques panneaux solaires, le tableau de contrôle électrique, le plancher pour l’installation du « Rocket stove »

Nous avons besoin de votre support pour parachever le bâtiment, ce qui veut dire les matériaux pour :

  • l’isolation à la cellulose des murs,
  • la finition  des murs intérieurs,
  • certaines fenêtres/portes,
  • le revêtement des planchers,
  • l’escalier intérieur,
  • tous les aménagements intérieurs et le système de chauffage,
  • les batteries,
  • la finalisation des installations électriques avec l’éclairage aux DEL,
  • la terrasse,
  • la récupération de l’eau de pluie,
  • un chauffe-air solaire,
  • la chambre mécanique, etc….

Les bénévoles sont bienvenus.
L’argent reçu servira à acheter ces matériaux et à assurer ses installations.

Le ministère  québécois des Affaires municipales et de l'Occupation du territoire versera, dans le cadre du Programme d'infrastructures en entrepreneuriat collectif (PIEC), l'équivalent de 30 % du montant amassé sur Indiegogo.

Notre objectif est d’inaugurer le bâtiment le Jour de l’an 2015.


D'autres façons d'aider

Nous vous remercions grandement et nous vous invitons à parler de ce projet avec vos amis et votre famille.


Au plaisir de vous voir en ce lieu que l’on crée tous ensemble.


What is TerraVie ?

TerraVie is a community land trust, a non-profit charity organization and a land conservancy whose mission is to show with concrete examples, that harmony can be achieved between human activities and nature. Our two main activities are the preservation of the natural area, and the realization of local environmental projects, such as ecological housing, eco-gites, botanical gardens and ecotourism. The third element in TerraVie’s action plan which also fulfills their mission, is environmental education. This initiative earned them the Phoenix prize for the environment in 2007, under the catagory of "sustainable development".

What we have already achieved

In 2006, with the help of a government funding program, and through the fundraising efforts of a team of volunteers, TerraVie acquired 288 acres of land in the Municipality of Montcalm, in the MRC des Laurentides. Since then, this land has undergone numerous modifications and innovative constructions.


Since its acquisition, most of the land has been located within the Lac du Brochet nature reserve, where many endangered species will be protected forever. In order to officially open this site to the public, TerraVie will develop ecological recreational, educational and ecotourism facilities.

 



Within the reserve, our team of volunteers has already begun the construction of a visitors center as well as a foot bridge, 600 meters of a wheelchair accessible walking trail, information posters, a shed, composting toilets-- one of which is accessible for the handicapped, an educational “green” shelter showing various ecological building techniques, a native plant garden and the beginning of several kilometers of forest trails.


A traditional Mongolian yurt was also installed near the large community garden, which is equipped with water basins supplied by a ram pump. A clay bread oven was built during one of the educational workshops, and there are three docks giving access to the lake.


Currently, we are working on our first substantial building, the Nature Interpretation Center, and we need your help


The campaign objective: construction of the Nature Interpretation Center

At the entrance to our nature reserve, the Nature Interpretation Center will welcome visitors and serve as a gathering place and educational center for environmental and sustainable development subjects. Training courses, workshops, artistic and theme events including the sale of various products and services, and conferences (for more information on TerraVie’s educational activities, check out their web site at www.terravie.org ). The center will also include a small “cinema in the woods”, environment related library and a “tasting terrace” of forest products.



The Nature Center building was designed in accordance with the 3RV principles reduce, reuse, recycle and valorize and will serve as a model of ecological construction. It will include various integrated systems, such as gray water recycling for plants, rain water management, pumping lake water with a modified bicycle, a 'Rocket Stove', a wood stove for heating and cooking, and a solar energy system, etc. By using innovative ecological technology, TerraVie is demonstrating how to significantly reduce our ecological footprint in the integration of our infrastructures.

In short, through this initiative TerraVie hopes :

  1. to facilitate access to nature, for recreational and educational purposes,
  2. inspire its visitors to adopt green technology, thereby ensuring healthy ecosystems and communities, now and into the future,
  3. to spread the word to small neighbouring villages.




Here is a list of the activities planned for the Center :

  • Welcoming and informing visitors, product sales (site maps, learning cards, promotional items, etc.) and guided tours;
  • A presentation on the trees and animals found in the reserve;
  • Conferences and workshops to increase public awareness of an ecological way of life;
  • Film presentations on environmental issues;
  • Fundraising events and parties;
  • Building a library on various environmental protection issues, alternative construction and energy;
  • Therapy and art in nature sessions (yoga, Qigong, music, painting, sculpture, photography, etc.) and in future, eco-cottages sessions


Project development and your support

Presently, the following have been completed: the foundation posts, framing, exterior walls, roof and roof insulation, some windows and doors, some solar panels, electric control panel, and the floor for the « Rocket stove »

We need your support to complete the building, namely, :

  • cellulose insulation for the walls
  • finishing the interior walls
  • some windows and doors
  • finishing the floors
  • the interior staircase
  • interior finishing
  • the heating system
  • les batteries,
  • completing the electrical installations and LED lighting
  • the terrace
  • the rainwater recovery system
  • a solar air heater
  • mechanical room, etc.

Volunteers are welcome. Any money received will be used to buy materials and installations for the completion of these facilities.

The ministry Affaires municipales et de l'Occupation du territoire pay, under the Programme d'infrastructures en entrepreneuriat collectif (PIEC), equivalent to 30% of the amount raised on Indiegogo.

Our goal is to inaugurate the building on New Year's Day 2015.


Other ways to help

Thank you very much. We invite you to share this project with your friends and family, and we hope to see you soon in this very special place that we are creating together.

In short, through this initiative TerraVie hopes :

to facilitate access to nature, for recreational and educational purposes,
inspire its visitors to adopt green technology, thereby ensuring healthy ecosystems and communities, now and into the future,
to spread the word to small neighbouring villages.







Here is a list of the activities planned for the Center :

Welcoming and informing visitors, product sales (site maps, learning cards, promotional items, etc.) and guided tours; 
A presentation on the trees and animals found in the reserve;
Conferences and workshops to increase public awareness of an ecological way of life;
Film presentations on environmental issues;
Fundraising events and parties;
Building a library on various environmental protection issues, alternative construction and energy;
Therapy and art in nature sessions (yoga, Qigong, music, painting, sculpture, photography, etc.) and in future, eco-cottages sessions






Project development and your support 

 

Presently, the following have been completed: the foundation posts, framing, exterior walls, roof and roof insulation, some windows and doors, some solar panels, electric control panel, and the floor for the « Rocket stove » 
We need your support to complete the building, namely, :

cellulose insulation for the walls
finishing the interior walls
some windows and doors
finishing the floors
the interior staircase
interior finishing
the heating system
les batteries, 
completing the electrical installations and LED lighting
the terrace
the rainwater recovery system
a solar air heater
mechanical room, etc.

Volunteers are welcome. Any money received will be used to buy materials and installations for the completion of these facilities.

The ministry Affaires municipales et de l'Occupation du territoire  pay, under the Programme d'infrastructures en entrepreneuriat collectif (PIEC), equivalent to 30% of the amount raised on Indiegogo.

Our goal is to inaugurate the building on New Year's Day 2015.Other ways to help


Thank you very much. We invite you to share this project with your friends and family, and we hope to see you soon in this very special place that we are creating together.

story:
The Borneo Rainforest Project

Twenty years ago, as a budding biologist, I had the privilege of working in Danum Valley, north Borneo. What I found there was the most incredible, magnificent Disneyland of wildlife imaginable. For the next two decades, Danum Valley remained in my mind, and all I wanted was to return and experience it again.  When I finally got the chance, I was struck by the landscape of devastation I saw as I flew over the island.  My goal became to find a way to contribute to the conservation of this unique area.  I went to Danum Valley Field Centre (DVFC), tracked down other biologists who shared my vision, and we teamed up to form the Borneo Rainforest Project.

Our team origins are at University of Sheffield.  We'd all worked at Danum previously, and we all knew what a special place it was. The forest here has been evolving for 130 million years. It teems with life: orang-utans, clouded leopards, gibbons, slow loris, linsang, giant pythons, crazy insects, countless spectacular birds, and the last of the Bornean banteng, pygmy elephants, and Sumatran rhinos. 

  

So ancient and so fragile, the forests of Borneo have been logged and cleared for palm oil plantations at an alarming rate, leaving less than an estimated 20,000 km2 of intact, unlogged forest. 

With so little forest left, the question of whether logged forest can recover to the point where it supports the original intricate and complex faunal communities is vital.  If we can demonstrate the value of naturally regenerating forest, we can advocate for its protection.  That's what our study does.

  

Birds are our study taxon.  They are ideal for this: well understood; sensitive to ecological impacts and so good barometers of change; and they are commonly used as indicators of biodiversity, so we can use them in this way as well. Our dedicated team of ornithologists and behavioral ecologists shares a passion for the work, for the birds, and for the rainforest. 

How We're Funded and What Your Donations Do

We have a small equipment grant from Idea Wild and have applied for other small grants, and the University of Sheffield supports some of our research assistants. Once we have about 5 years of data, we hope to obtain a large grant for the final 5 years. For now, we get by on volunteerism and donations.  Your donations are needed to cover lodging and food (bought on the cheap at the local markets), pay the field centre fees (which help keep the field centre afloat), cover vehicle costs, and hire the occasional local assistant to help with the dirty work.  We are always in need of gear (nets are covered by other grants, but we often must replace poles, rope, pliers, pisolas, clipboards, rulers, calipers, and other field tools).  We are always just one elephant herd away from total destruction of our set-up!  The van to town to get food is quite costly (and no one ever wants to leave work to go!), but vital.  I'd love to cover in-country flights for the research assistants as well, if I can. 

Our wish list includes a new field camera, since I pretty much drove my personal camera to an early grave with overuse, and a field laptop (again, my personal one gave out shortly after last season). These are absolutely necessary for recording morphological features, identification and documentation purposes, and of course data management.

Our one-year total budget for accommodation, food, gear, station fees,  all travel, local assistants, and vehicle costs (with 5 research assistants) is about $20,000.  That's the actual cost to run the project with no salaries but all expenses covered.  For now, we're still depending on volunteers for the bulk of it and asking for your help in covering some of the necessities.  If we can bring in more than our goal, I will be able to cover more of our expenses and equipment.  If we bring in less, well... the show must go on, so we'll hold bake sales, busk (if only we had talent), or plant a money tree.  We are always applying for grants along the way, of course, and everyone on the team contributes what they can.  Please help us exceed our goal!

To thank you, we are very happy to offer our fantastic perks - they are all beautiful Bornean handicrafts!  See a few of them below.  We'll try to get the exact items listed, but it depends on availability. You can email me with preferences if you like (don't be shy!).

 

 

  

  

 

The Impact - Your Contribution to Conservation

The quantification of bird community responses to logging impacts and the measurement of observable changes within logged forest as it regenerates will help to define the role of Bornean logged forest in sustaining avian species richness and diversity. Thus, the results of this study will bring to light the potential value and contribution of regenerating logged forest to overall biodiversity.

Presently, conversion of both primary and logged forest to low biodiversity habitats such as oil palm plantations continues at high rates. By determining both the importance of primary forest reserves and the retained value of regenerating logged forest, this work aims to promote consideration of all forest values in land use decision making. Land use and conservation actions taken in response to this work will benefit all native forest species, beyond the taxon we address here.

  

Finally, by employing and training local assistants and students, this work strives to foster both a sense of stewardship and the talent and knowledge to perform ongoing forest conservation work in the local community.  The local assistants hold permanent positions at DVFC and will have future opportunities to pursue ecological projects on site, and to share their knowledge and experience with the many students and other visitors that come to the Centre for courses and training.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone can contribute, but you can still help. Please spread the word by sharing this campaign with friends, family, and organizations who share our mission.  Let's make some noise!!

(We'll also take a camera or laptop if you have a spare.)

Thanks!!

story:
After three years of traveling back and forth from Haiti to Orcas, Rosedanie Cadet has decided to spend the next year on just one island.

“The skills that I have to offer are skills that many people on Orcas have, but my skills are needed in Limbe [Haiti],” she said. “It’s hard to leave, but it’s time to go.”

After being gone from her country for 37 years, Cadet visited her homeland in 2009 just weeks before Haiti was devastated by the 7.0 earthquake that left more than 300,000 residents dead. In the following months, 6,000 died of cholera.

Her cousins survived but their house was destroyed and Cadet’s life was irrevocably changed. She eventually founded the nonprofit Helping Hands Noramise in the northern town of Limbe, which provides social and developmental programs for income, pride and social activism. Cadet said it’s not a charity program  – everyone must volunteer to receive the benefits of education, fresh food from their garden or chlorine for water purification.

After two years of addressing short-term needs, building community connections, re-discovering her home and connection to Haiti, and doing a wide variety of other things like coaching Haiti's first rugby team, Cadet is shifting the organization's focus back to the long-term needs and long-term sustainability of Limbe.

Her focus is now on education, on working with youth, on sustainable agriculture, on clean cookstoves, water filters and composting toilets – technologies that don't just improve lives, but save lives.

Cadet describes the work in Haiti as challenging and rewarding, taking steps forward and backward on any given day. She remains steadfast in her message that with limited resources and education life can be made better. It was that message that made her feel like she needed to spend this next year in Limbe to prove that she was committed.

“There will be a deeper foundation if I stay longer,” she said.

With a plane ticket departing for Haiti in January, Cadet looks forward to continuing developing gardens, reforestation and implementing biochar, an alternative fertilizer. All three of these have something powerful in common: food. The importance of such sustenance came to Cadet on her first visit back to Haiti as an adult.

“A country that can’t feed itself is dependent on others for a basic need,” she said.

Food also brings people together whether it be through working the soil or by gathering to eat. She hopes Limbe will be more like Orcas where there are farms and private gardens and where most islanders share and trade with one another. 

The reforestation project involves planting fruit trees and beneficial plants on a barren hillside located on the outskirts of Limbe. Work started last year involving the planting of produce to be used for consuming or selling. Cadet said there is a core group of 13 Ravine de Roches residents that have taken on the planting project. Taking on the work and decision-making responsibilities was rocky at first, but Cadet said the core of 13 has taken ownership. Cadet also wants to provide hand tools to farmers to help increase productivity.

Also in January, there will be a workshop held in Limbe by Samuel Michel who lives on another Haitian Island called La Gonave. He is certified in reforestation and permaculture.

“...that is our model – we teach a group something and practice it or teach it to someone else without exchanging money,” said Cadet. “It’s a knowledge bank between Haitians across the country.”

Cadet also hopes to work with Carbon Roots International (http://www.carbonrootsinternational.org), which is also located in northern Haiti and produces biochar and green charcoal to reduce deforestation, increase agricultural productivity and alleviate poverty in Haiti. Biochar is used to fertilize soil. 

“It’s made using dried farm biomass [seed pods, corn cobs,twigs], things that would be burned anyway … it can also be compressed to make cooking charcoal,” said Cadet.

She hopes to unite different organizations in Haiti to show the community in Limbe that help is within their reach.

Other projects like mango-processing and tilapia aquaculture are on her “to-do” list, but Cadet said that Helping Hands Noramise is still looking for partners in-country to help realize these goals.

As she prepares to depart she looks back on Orcas as a healing place that has helped her to see what she must do.

“There are some people that walk the same path for a lifetime. Some people travel different paths throughout their life,” she said. “My path now leads to Limbe.”

What we lack is funding

We need funding for shovels to loosen the compacted, eroded Haitian soils. We need seeds and seedlings to plant in that loosened soil, we need watering cans to coax those plants to life as they begin reforesting denuded hillsides with food.

We need materials and tools to make biochar kilns and compost systems to feed those plants. We need materials for water filters, for composting toilets, for gasifier stoves - technologies that save people money and create local industry while at the same time battling the causes of two of the largest killers globally - indoor smoke inhalation and dirty drinking water. The need for these technologies is magnified in Haiti, where cholera in the water is a fact of life, and where most cooking is done with charcoal, which causes mass deforestation while scarring children's and women's lungs.  

Where the Money Goes

• school garden

• machetes, shovels, hoes, water cans, five gallon buckets

• seeds and seedlings of fruit trees, timber trees, vegetables, beans, bamboo shoots, and plants to stop erosion and build soils

• metal and materials for biochar kilns, gasifier stoves, composting toilets, water filters, water purification systems

• support for English classes for educational programs

For the holiday season consider treating your friends and family a gift donation to help feed a community. Donate now at http://noramise.org.

story:
Not Your Ordinary Quarry Story

Or unfortunately, maybe it is.

This scenario is playing out as you read this, all over the country – the Muskoka/Near North area is being increasingly hard hit with actions to create quarries on sensitive land areas.  Unless 'the many' stand up and do something while we can, 'the few' will bulldoze, contaminate and waste our precious resources until there is nothing left.

Please don't mistake this a campaign of "NOT IN MY BACK YARD".  Our area does support operating pits and quarries, and we understand that the extraction of aggregate in rural areas is a fact of modern life and industry.

But this one is different.  That's why we are fighting.  And we need help.


WHO ARE WE?

We are a small group of Residents who got together and decided to DO SOMETHING.  We worked hard to educate ourselves, attend the council meetings, and inform our neighbours.

We are organized.  Our community has rallied.  We have hired a lawyer and a planner to our team.  Next stop, Ontario Municipal Board Pre-hearing on May 13th, 2014.

We have held fundraising events and dug into our own pockets.  To date we have be able to raise $17,287.95.  All funds raised will go to paying legal and planning fees for the OMB Pre-Hearing and helping us spread the word with road signs and mail-outs.  Funds collected are not used for administrative purposes.


WE HAVE A CASE

Our lawyer and planner are well into preparations for our case at the pre-hearing.

If we thought for one minute that there are not solid reasons that this quarry will not be approved, we would just have to accept it and would never have even attempted it.

But the facts remain that this quarry is being proposed at the wrong location.

We feel that we can win if given a chair at the table which is the OMB hearing.

Unfortunately, it always comes down to money, doesn't it?

Not always even who is right and wrong, but who has the most money to stay in the game the longest.

With your help, it could be us.


THE SCENE

Beautiful Pegg's Mountain in Ryerson Township just outside of Burks Falls, Ontario. A little bit of heaven that sits on a small and winding swamp road on Provincially Significant Wetlands butting on the Magnetawan River is up for grabs.

SO WHAT HAPPENED?

Here's the run down in very general terms...

Mega Quarry Application is submitted to Ryerson Council.

Mega Quarry Application is turned down by Ryerson Council.

Mega Quarry Application is resubmitted with some Concessions

Mega Quarry Application is approved with some Conditions.

The Proponent (Quarry Applicant) doesn't like the Conditions.

The Residents in the mountain district don't like the Conditions.

In order to solve this quandary, the only thing to do is to take the disagreements to the Ontario Municipal Board (OMB) to contest what is now called bylaw 31-13 – the bylaw put into place by Ryerson Council in order to make way for the quarry.

So off go multiple parties to the OMB, including the Pegg's Mountain Group.


WHY DID THIS HAPPEN?

Information meeting July 2012 re: proposed quarry on Pegg's Mountain. Despite being a tiny township the room was full - and 'we the people' were clear on our position - we didn't want it then and we don't want it now! 


The Applicant's position looks clear – he wants conditions that are going to net him the most cash from his quarry operation.

Ryerson Council's position is not really clear – they were found guilty of holding unnecessarily private meetings with the applicant twice by the Ombudsman according to the Sunshine Law (which is a big deal, but unfortunately holds no penalty) and refused to allow members of Pegg's Mountain Group or other parties to be 'in the loop' on communications and developments. (note: anyone is allowed access to public files at the Ryerson Township Office – it is not at all the same as being 'on board' and notified real time for information purposes.)

They also refused (literally – we asked them many times and the answer was straight out "no") to require the Applicant to Commission Independent Studies in the areas where expertise was required in order to make an educated decision. These studies are a logical and every day requirement in these types of proceedings – the Applicant pays.

These studies would examine in detail exactly the potential impact on the environment and local residents such as hydrology (water), road, blasting, noise and dust – including something called silica which is commonly found in granite (the stone that will be quarried).

Why the heck not you may ask?

So did we?

Many times.

We still don't know...


PEGG'S MOUNTAIN GROUP - LEFT HOLDING THE BAGGY

The Road To Pegg's Mountain...

Our own Ryerson Council has put us in the position of paying high legal fees to stop the quarry that they paved the way for.

Had the township done their duty to protect the residents and environment of Ryerson Township and turned down the quarry, they would likely still be going to the OMB, but it would not be at the additional cost and time of ordinary private residents – which it has turned out to be.

Hence, the Indiegogo Campaign.

We need your help.


HERE'S WHERE THE TRI AXLE GRAVEL TRUCK RUBBER MEETS THE ROAD

This is the road that we will be expected to share with tri axle gravel trucks making up to 90 trips per day - bikers, walkers, horsebaack riders, joggers included.

The Concessions made by the Applicant in his second attempt do not cover all of the original Concerns put forth by council.

The Conditions put forth by council in Bylaw 31-13 Do Not Guarantee Protection of The Mountain, the River or the People Who Live There, both as permanent residents and seasonal.

Nor Do They Protect the Tourism Industry That Supports The Town of Burk's Falls and Surrounding Townships.

So...

WE THE PEGG'S MOUNTAIN GROUP...

Have taken it upon ourselves to try and make both parties accountable to all of the above potential travesties, and to try to pull together the people who are affected, of which there are two groups.

1. Local residents and seasonal residents and visitors.

2. The people, which may include you, who are affected every time a debacle of this sort is allowed to play out.

This is your chance to help us do something about it.


CONTRIBUTE

We often see Contribute as just a word.

To Contribute is more than just an action – it's a feeling.

How Does It Feel to Contribute to Preserving a Place Like Pegg's Mountain?

How does it feel to pass it over?

Too many times we find the answer to these kinds of questions too late.

By making your contribution, you will be directly helping us to achieve the next essential step to preserve Pegg's Mountain and everything around it.

This is the kind of ripple that can resound throughout the world.

We would love for you to be a part of it.


WHAT WE HAVE SO FAR

We already have raised $17,287.95 over the past year.

This amount has come from a very small number of extremely dedicated people who believe strongly in our case – and in protecting our environment, our people and our wildlife.

These generous donations have paid for about 2/3's of the total costs associated with the pre-hearing. 

We are almost there!

Without participation in the pre-hearing, we cannot participate in the hearing, when the judge will rule for or against the approved bylaw, which allows the quarry if the proponent decides to adhere to the conditions.

And the fact is that he has not agreed. He is also taking Ryerson Council to the OMB to protest these conditions.

In our eyes this makes our presence even more necessary.

If no one is there to present all information pertinent to dismissal of the decision for bylaw approval – his chances will go up exponentially - which could result in his proceeding with the quarry unhindered by conditions at all.


WHAT ABOUT RYERSON COUNCIL?

You may be asking yourself why we need to be present at a hearing if 'our' Ryerson Council will be represented.

That is exactly the reason. 

Ryerson Council will be in defense of their decision to approve the bylaw allowing the quarry with conditions – they will not be in defense of turning down permission to amend the bylaw to prevent the quarry – far contrary.

We personally did not find Ryerson Council as a group to be friendly to the views or input of the Pegg's Mountain Group, so we highly do not expect to see any concessions made by them at the hearing in favour of pulling support from bylaw 31-13 which has already been passed on the vote of the Reeve Glen Miller and every council member except one who had the courage to stand up - George Sterling.


NO GUARANTEES

In the end, really there can be no guarantees.

And non have been given.

  • No guarantees on the rock face.

  • No guarantees on road safety.

  • No guarantees on well or water levels.

  • No guarantees on foundational or property damage by blasting.

  • No guarantees on the road structure or spring flooding issue.

  • No guarantees on property values.

  • No guarantees on quality of life for residents and cottagers.

  • No guarantees on traffic congestion in Burks Falls during the busiest commercial season of the year.

  • No guarantees that truck traffic, quarry operation and blasting noise levels will not be disruptive to mental health and rural living.

  • No guarantees of jobs.

  • No guarantees that potentially contaminated dust from quarry operations will not cause health concerns to travelers by car, bike riders, walkers, hikers or horseback riders.

  • No guarantees on the Magnetawan River or surrounding Provincially Significant Wetlands.

  • No guarantees that trucks will not congest the road at virtually any time of the day for travelers on their way to work, to appointments or in the case of emergencies. (there is an estimate of 90 trips per day but these are not staggered trips – they can all happen at virtually the same time ). 

No guarantees.

Period.


CONTACT US

If you would like more information, or want to talk about other ways to participate (join our team!), please email ihelped@savepeggsmountain.com

We look forward to hearing from you!


GET UPDATES AND BE COUNTED

Click on the website link below to go to our website and join the Pegg's Mountain Group through our email mailing list. You will be updated on important development's and your name will be added to our growing list of supporters who will be counted on the pre-hearing date Tuesday May 13 - every show of support helps.

A QUICK AND EASY WAY THAT YOU CAN HELP

We are down to the wire - every dollar raised is a dollar that we as a small citizen's group will not personally have to fork over for the legal costs in this situation where most of us at one time or another have looked around and said - "I can't believe this is happening."

Any donation you can make is appreciated more than you can know. Many heartfelt thanks to everyone who has already contributed.

By sharing with your friends on Facebook or Twitter using the links below, you will be helping us in a big way to increase awareness and raise enough funds to cover the costs of the legal battle to SAVE Pegg's Mountain.
story_txt:
Not Your Ordinary Quarry StoryOr unfortunately, maybe it is.This scenario is playing out as you read this, all over the country – the Muskoka/Near North area is being increasingly hard hit with actions to create quarries on sensitive land areas.  Unless 'the many' stand up and do something while we can, 'the few' will bulldoze, contaminate and waste our precious resources until there is nothing left.Please don't mistake this a campaign of "NOT IN MY BACK YARD".  Our area does support operating pits and quarries, and we understand that the extraction of aggregate in rural areas is a fact of modern life and industry.But this one is different.  That's why we are fighting.  And we need help.WHO ARE WE?We are a small group of Residents who got together and decided to DO SOMETHING.  We worked hard to educate ourselves, attend the council meetings, and inform our neighbours.We are organized.  Our community has rallied.  We have hired a lawyer and a planner to our team.  Next stop, Ontario Municipal Board Pre-hearing on May 13th, 2014.We have held fundraising events and dug into our own pockets.  To date we have be able to raise $17,287.95.  All funds raised will go to paying legal and planning fees for the OMB Pre-Hearing and helping us spread the word with road signs and mail-outs.  Funds collected are not used for administrative purposes.WE HAVE A CASEOur lawyer and planner are well into preparations for our case at the pre-hearing.If we thought for one minute that there are not solid reasons that this quarry will not be approved, we would just have to accept it and would never have even attempted it.But the facts remain that this quarry is being proposed at the wrong location.We feel that we can win if given a chair at the table which is the OMB hearing.Unfortunately, it always comes down to money, doesn't it?Not always even who is right and wrong, but who has the most money to stay in the game the longest.With your help, it could be us.THE SCENEBeautiful Pegg's Mountain in Ryerson Township just outside of Burks Falls, Ontario. A little bit of heaven that sits on a small and winding swamp road on Provincially Significant Wetlands butting on the Magnetawan River is up for grabs.SO WHAT HAPPENED?Here's the run down in very general terms...Mega Quarry Application is submitted to Ryerson Council.Mega Quarry Application is turned down by Ryerson Council.Mega Quarry Application is resubmitted with some ConcessionsMega Quarry Application is approved with some Conditions.The Proponent (Quarry Applicant) doesn't like the Conditions.The Residents in the mountain district don't like the Conditions.In order to solve this quandary, the only thing to do is to take the disagreements to the Ontario Municipal Board (OMB) to contest what is now called bylaw 31-13 – the bylaw put into place by Ryerson Council in order to make way for the quarry.So off go multiple parties to the OMB, including the Pegg's Mountain Group.WHY DID THIS HAPPEN?Information meeting July 2012 re: proposed quarry on Pegg's Mountain. Despite being a tiny township the room was full - and 'we the people' were clear on our position - we didn't want it then and we don't want it now! The Applicant's position looks clear – he wants conditions that are going to net him the most cash from his quarry operation.Ryerson Council's position is not really clear – they were found guilty of holding unnecessarily private meetings with the applicant twice by the Ombudsman according to the Sunshine Law (which is a big deal, but unfortunately holds no penalty) and refused to allow members of Pegg's Mountain Group or other parties to be 'in the loop' on communications and developments. (note: anyone is allowed access to public files at the Ryerson Township Office – it is not at all the same as being 'on board' and notified real time for information purposes.)They also refused (literally – we asked them many times and the answer was straight out "no") to require the Applicant to Commission Independent Studies in the areas where expertise was required in order to make an educated decision. These studies are a logical and every day requirement in these types of proceedings – the Applicant pays.These studies would examine in detail exactly the potential impact on the environment and local residents such as hydrology (water), road, blasting, noise and dust – including something called silica which is commonly found in granite (the stone that will be quarried).Why the heck not you may ask?So did we?Many times.We still don't know...PEGG'S MOUNTAIN GROUP - LEFT HOLDING THE BAGGYThe Road To Pegg's Mountain...Our own Ryerson Council has put us in the position of paying high legal fees to stop the quarry that they paved the way for.Had the township done their duty to protect the residents and environment of Ryerson Township and turned down the quarry, they would likely still be going to the OMB, but it would not be at the additional cost and time of ordinary private residents – which it has turned out to be.Hence, the Indiegogo Campaign.We need your help.HERE'S WHERE THE TRI AXLE GRAVEL TRUCK RUBBER MEETS THE ROADThis is the road that we will be expected to share with tri axle gravel trucks making up to 90 trips per day - bikers, walkers, horsebaack riders, joggers included.The Concessions made by the Applicant in his second attempt do not cover all of the original Concerns put forth by council.The Conditions put forth by council in Bylaw 31-13 Do Not Guarantee Protection of The Mountain, the River or the People Who Live There, both as permanent residents and seasonal.Nor Do They Protect the Tourism Industry That Supports The Town of Burk's Falls and Surrounding Townships.So...WE THE PEGG'S MOUNTAIN GROUP...Have taken it upon ourselves to try and make both parties accountable to all of the above potential travesties, and to try to pull together the people who are affected, of which there are two groups.1. Local residents and seasonal residents and visitors.2. The people, which may include you, who are affected every time a debacle of this sort is allowed to play out.This is your chance to help us do something about it.CONTRIBUTEWe often see Contribute as just a word.To Contribute is more than just an action – it's a feeling.How Does It Feel to Contribute to Preserving a Place Like Pegg's Mountain?How does it feel to pass it over?Too many times we find the answer to these kinds of questions too late.By making your contribution, you will be directly helping us to achieve the next essential step to preserve Pegg's Mountain and everything around it.This is the kind of ripple that can resound throughout the world.We would love for you to be a part of it.WHAT WE HAVE SO FARWe already have raised $17,287.95 over the past year.This amount has come from a very small number of extremely dedicated people who believe strongly in our case – and in protecting our environment, our people and our wildlife.These generous donations have paid for about 2/3's of the total costs associated with the pre-hearing. We are almost there!Without participation in the pre-hearing, we cannot participate in the hearing, when the judge will rule for or against the approved bylaw, which allows the quarry if the proponent decides to adhere to the conditions.And the fact is that he has not agreed. He is also taking Ryerson Council to the OMB to protest these conditions.In our eyes this makes our presence even more necessary.If no one is there to present all information pertinent to dismissal of the decision for bylaw approval – his chances will go up exponentially - which could result in his proceeding with the quarry unhindered by conditions at all.WHAT ABOUT RYERSON COUNCIL?You may be asking yourself why we need to be present at a hearing if 'our' Ryerson Council will be represented.That is exactly the reason. Ryerson Council will be in defense of their decision to approve the bylaw allowing the quarry with conditions – they will not be in defense of turning down permission to amend the bylaw to prevent the quarry – far contrary.We personally did not find Ryerson Council as a group to be friendly to the views or input of the Pegg's Mountain Group, so we highly do not expect to see any concessions made by them at the hearing in favour of pulling support from bylaw 31-13 which has already been passed on the vote of the Reeve Glen Miller and every council member except one who had the courage to stand up - George Sterling.NO GUARANTEESIn the end, really there can be no guarantees.And non have been given.
No guarantees on the rock face.
No guarantees on road safety.
No guarantees on well or water levels.
No guarantees on foundational or property damage by blasting.
No guarantees on the road structure or spring flooding issue.
No guarantees on property values.
No guarantees on quality of life for residents and cottagers.
No guarantees on traffic congestion in Burks Falls during the busiest commercial season of the year.
No guarantees that truck traffic, quarry operation and blasting noise levels will not be disruptive to mental health and rural living.
No guarantees of jobs.
No guarantees that potentially contaminated dust from quarry operations will not cause health concerns to travelers by car, bike riders, walkers, hikers or horseback riders.
No guarantees on the Magnetawan River or surrounding Provincially Significant Wetlands.
No guarantees that trucks will not congest the road at virtually any time of the day for travelers on their way to work, to appointments or in the case of emergencies. (there is an estimate of 90 trips per day but these are not staggered trips – they can all happen at virtually the same time ). 
No guarantees.Period.CONTACT USIf you would like more information, or want to talk about other ways to participate (join our team!), please email ihelped@savepeggsmountain.comWe look forward to hearing from you!GET UPDATES AND BE COUNTEDClick on the website link below to go to our website and join the Pegg's Mountain Group through our email mailing list. You will be updated on important development's and your name will be added to our growing list of supporters who will be counted on the pre-hearing date Tuesday May 13 - every show of support helps.A QUICK AND EASY WAY THAT YOU CAN HELPWe are down to the wire - every dollar raised is a dollar that we as a small citizen's group will not personally have to fork over for the legal costs in this situation where most of us at one time or another have looked around and said - "I can't believe this is happening."Any donation you can make is appreciated more than you can know. Many heartfelt thanks to everyone who has already contributed.By sharing with your friends on Facebook or Twitter using the links below, you will be helping us in a big way to increase awareness and raise enough funds to cover the costs of the legal battle to SAVE Pegg's Mountain.

story:
The Big Picture:

    On September 21, 2014, New York City is set to host the largest climate march in history: The People's Climate March. While world leaders meet at a United Nations summit to discuss the climate change crisis, over a hundred-thousand people will be taking to the streets of Manhattan to urge them to come to an agreement that would result in dramatically reducing global emissions that are contributing to climate change. By peacefully flooding the streets, we will be putting pressure on the decision makers and show them that we stand in solidarity for climate justice. 

Why Penn State?

     Without a doubt, Penn State is one of the largest and most influential research institutions/ universities in the nation. Our team at Fossil Free PSU, Penn State's Fossil Fuel Divestment club, feels that with such great influence comes great responsibility. We think that, in order to continue the tradition of leadership that Penn State has always displayed, it is immensely important for our great university to be represented at this historic march. 

And Now It's Your Turn!

     To do this we need your help! Our goal is to send (at least) one bus of approximately 50 Penn State students to the People's Climate March on September 21, 2014. The event is quickly approaching, so we need to act fast! The funds that donors are willing to give will be specifically used to Charter a Fullington bus to serve as transportation to and from the March. If you chose to donate, you can be sure that we'll keep you updated on exactly where your money is going, as we value complete transparency in financial matters. 
     If you like what you see, but aren't able to donate, never fear! You can still help! The more buzz we can get about our campaign, the better, so talk about us and share us wherever and whenever you can! You can also show your support by clicking here and signing Fossil Free PSU's petition supporting divestment that will be presented to the University. Finally, like Fossil Free PSU on Facebook and follow us on Twitter to stay updated about the March and all of our future events!
                                                                     Peace, Love, and Climate Justice!
                                                                 -People's Climate March: Penn State Team
(Nathan Larkin, Alanna Kaiser, Rachel Hoellman, Lucien Simpfendoerfer, Mark Sideck)

story:
Plastic is everyone’s problem

What would your day look like if your life depended on the amount of trash you collected and sold? Where would you live? Would it be a comfy city apartment or a family house in the suburbs? Could you afford to send your kids to university?

If you were like heroes of our story, most of the answers would wrench your heart. The estimated 1.5 million waste-pickers in India are some of the world’s most marginalized people. These waste pickers, many of them women, often live below the poverty line, work in appalling conditions and are shunned by society. Yet they form a critical line of defence in stopping plastic from entering our rivers and oceans.

 

Hope in the trash

The global plastic pollution has given rise to an informal waste picking economy. Waste-pickers see the plastic as a valuable resource that can be collected and sold. Plastics For Change has developed a marketplace platform that connects waste-pickers with global brands and creates transparency through the supply chain. Our platform mobilizes thousands of waste-pickers to collect plastic that pollutes the environment. We provide a consistent supply of high quality recycled plastic for industry partners.

 

Finding a solution in pollution

We don’t try to stop companies from producing plastic waste; that’s how they turn a profit. So, we wanted to offer them a more sustainable alternative in buying recycled, high-quality ‘fair-trade’ plastic, rather than producing their own.

After a successful campaign and four years of hard work, we did it!  Plastics For Change collected funding to launch the world's first Fair-Trade System for urban waste pickers. This system has been a game changer for a few reasons:

  • We opened international markets for informal recyclers. They went from selling to middlemen for low prices to brands like The Body Shop.
  • We created a mobile platform that records all deals and work practices. This means waste-pickers can’t get cheated and receive the best deals.
  • Our practices and prices are certified by the World Fair Trade Organization. This ensures everyone is being treated fairly.
  • We offer training, recycling infrastructure, quality assurance, safety equipment and deals to our partners. This means they are upskilled to sell to global markets.  

 

Achieving the impossible with fair trade plastic

In 2015, we launched our first Indiegogo Campaign to create The World's First Fair Trade System for Urban Waste Pickers. The campaign was successful and provided funding to establish the initiative in India.

We have since:

  • Recycled India’s first food-grade PET and sent it to Europe `
  • Met the righteous European safety standards
  • Became the first fair trade recycler to be certified by the World Fair Trade Organisation
  • Launched our fair trade plastic with The Body Shop and changed their plastic production lines

So, we now want to replicate it and launch it in coastal communities that lack waste-management services. To do that, we need 10,000 USD. That’s the cost of recycling equipment and hiring staff to run a business based on fair-trade values.

 

Invest in your planet and in yourself today

Well, what do waste-pickers in India and plastic pollution even mean to you? Isn’t this a problem you can think about later?

Unfortunately not, as we speak a garbage truck of plastic is entering the ocean each minute. A large majority of ocean plastic comes from 10 major rivers, 2 being in India. Plastic has also started entering the food chain in common dinner table items like salt, fish and even tap water. We are quite literally drowning in plastic.

Don’t be the sort of person who ignores this mess. You probably use plastic every day. Be part of something bigger than yourself and see the amazing impact of change. You may be thinking that a few dollars are just a drop in the ocean and won’t matter anyway. However, in a country like India, this little ‘drop’ can change lives and reduce global plastic pollution.

(The average person consumes a credit card sized amount of microplastics every week)

 

Receive free ethical gifts for helping our recycling efforts

We want you to join our journey for yourself, your future and your planet. We are asking you to be a backer of our expansion. We are offering some great perks to all supporters. You can follow our online updates to see where your funding is going.

  • $20 - free home eco-guide e-book
  • $30 - an ethical bracelet made from sustainable materials
  • $45 - recycle 50KG of fair trade plastic in India. This amounts to 6 months of average plastic consumption.
  • $85 - recycle 100KG of fair trade plastic in India. This amounts to 1 year of average plastic consumption.
  • $100 - waste-picker safety gear including masks, gloves, uniforms and other necessary equipment.
  • $100 - an ocean sole sculpture made from recycled flip flips in Africa.
  • $200 - your name commissioned on our new recycling centre.

Or you can enter any amount by clicking the ‘back it’ button. Take a stance today and be part of the change.
