story:
* * *

We are SO INCREDIBLY OVERJOYED that we have met our Indiegogo fundraising goal!! Thank you SO much to all of our wonderful contributors, you are amazing! We are so grateful to all of our supporters who have helped us reach our first goal. We still have about $9,000 dollars to raise through grants and sponsorships, so contributions that come in during the next 2 days will help us reach our overall goal. Thank you so much!!!

* * *

Rediscovering the Great American Prairie:

Educate, Engage, Create


The expedition:

Traversing the Great Plains of North America by horseback, our project will bring public attention to the critical role of grassland conservation in North America today. Through education and outreach, from both scientific and artistic perspectives, we will engage a wide audience in an investigation of the issues that affect this vitally important region. We aim to inspire regional scale, long-term conservation and sustainable land use practices by articulating the richness and beauty of the landscape through film, photography, and writing. Inviting discussion with local ecologists, land managers, ranchers, farmers, activists, artists, and the public alike, our journey will dive into the region’s rich historical past, shed light on its present condition, and help inspire creative possibilities for its future.

The Impact

You are supporting a creative approach to a complex problem. Our multi-faceted project merges education, outreach, art, science, and, of course, horses in a way we are certain will excite a deeper understanding, appreciation, and engagement with the natural world and our place within it.

The region: Why the Great Prairie?

Temperate grasslands are the least protected biome on earth, with less than five percent formally protected world-wide, compared with fifteen percent of all terrestrial biomes on average.[1] Within the great plains of the United States, the central tall grasslands ecoregion has the highest percentage of habitat loss of any terrestrial ecoregion on the continent with 99% habitat lost. Nearly all of the tallgrass prairie ecoregions were converted to agricultural use during the 20th century, making the protection of remaining natural areas and the restoration of degraded landscapes of vital importance. (Photo by Diane Hargreaves)

[1] Hoekstra, Molnar, et al. 2010, The Atlas of Global Conservation

Objectives:

1)   We will produce a documentary film that will share the beauty of the landscape and the perspectives of the people we meet along the way. It will be used as an educational tool to promote greater local and national involvement in determining the future of an ecologically imperative region.

2)   We will invite discussion along the way with a diverse number of stakeholders ranging from ranchers and farmers to conservation organizations, writers, artists, and middle schools. We will discuss the importance of conservation in the region, explore the complexities of its current state, and spearhead dialogue about creative solutions and approaches to a sustainable future in the region. 

3)   Along the way we will maintain an interactive website, where the public can follow our progress on the road, access articles, photography, stories, poems,  and short film clips made along the way.

4)   After we complete the ride, we will present our film at high schools, universities, and other groups, giving talks nationwide promoting conservation of this enormously important region and challenging communities to become involved in its story. Our first presentation will be hosted by Colorado College's State of the Rockies Project at their annual lecture forum.

5)   After completion of the ride, we will exhibit our work at galleries around the country, combining art, conservation, community, and education to deepen ecological understanding and appreciation of the natural world. Our first stop will be at the Smokebrush Foundation’s art gallery in Colorado Springs, CO.

Mode of Transportation: Why Horses?

By using horses as our mode of transportation, we will pay homage to the cultural heritage of the landscape and the historic importance of horses in the region. This is a landscape that is often passed through at 75 mph, or looked down upon from 30,000 feet in the air; we want to slow down. We will connect ourselves intimately to the land through which we are traveling: its fertility, the threats it faces, and the urgency of its conservation. Horseback travel will capture the imagination of the public, inspiring those we encounter to envision the vastness of both the land and its opportunities.

The route:

Team Members:

Robin Walter:

Robin graduated from Colorado College in 2012 with a major in English literature and creative writing. Growing up, she spent most of her time at the stables or in a saddle, riding the trails in Colorado Springs and the Big Horn Mountains in Sheridan, WY. Most recently she was in the Aysén region of Patagonia managing the greenhouses for Conservación Patagonica as it converts a sheep estancia into a future Chilean National Park.

“Becoming more and more familiar with the conservation work underway in Patagonia, I am inspired to pursue similar work closer to home. With a background in poetry, inquiry is at the heart of how I relate to the world. I am keenly interested in discovering and articulating the subtleties of our relationship with people and place, uncovering patterns that are at once familiar and surprising, and in engaging the reader in an intimate reflection of their relationship to the subject explored. I am excited about this project because it will provide me with a unique occasion to do just that, and in a landscape that is absolutely crucial to conservation efforts in North America. I have a life-long respect for nature and the outdoors, a zeal for stories and the craft of writing, extensive experience with photography, a long history with horses, and I have a deep interest in food and agriculture. This project takes each of these interests, and combines them in an exciting and imaginative way.” –Robin

Sebastian Tsocanos:

Sebastian was born in the coastal forests of Connecticut. Feeling the call to move west, and explore more deeply another region of America, Sebastian studied Environmental Science at Colorado College (’12). Completing his thesis on the rare and threatened remnants of tallgrass prairie in eastern Colorado, Sebastian fell in love with the American prairie, coming to appreciate its beauty and the myriad threats it faces.  Since graduation, Sebastian has worked as a natural resources field technician in El Paso County, CO, on a produce and dairy farm in western Colorado and on a grassland restoration project in Chilean Patagonia.

“I was first acquainted with the Midwestern landscape on long road trips across the country with family and friends. Driving across the plains, it was impossible not to notice how transformed the landscape is, mainly for agricultural purposes, whether plowed for corn and soybeans or heavily grazed by cattle. What was harder to notice was the wildlife that remained: along the roadways, along the railroad tracks, in the small state and local parks, national grasslands set back from the highway, and on the few well cared for farms and ranches scattered through the country, host to the rapidly disappearing native plants and animals that barely hang on in these islands of refuge. It was also hard to see the people that remain in the towns, so many driven out by farm mechanization and consolidation, when you only see the rest-stops and major cities along the interstate. I always wanted to stop and explore those scattered communities, and meet the people for whom the prairie is truly home. As an advocate of sustainable agriculture, I also am deeply interested in exploring the potential options for the future of agriculture in the region, and the work of practitioners already underway. Driving through this wide stretch of country, I always want to slow down, get off of the main roads, to really know the place. This project excites me because it is an opportunity to do that in a very special way, combining my long time love of horses and travel with my passion for prairie conservation, sustainable agriculture, and creative forms of community development, and to share that experience with others.”  -Sebastian

Sebastian and Robin are both Wilderness First Responders, have extensive risk-management skills developed over years of backcountry travel, over 18 years of equestrian experience each, and Sebastian completed the Equine Learning Center of America’s Equine First Aid Course.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to saddle up and head out we need to raise $26,000. We hope to raise atleast $12,000 through Indiegogo, and the rest through grants and sponsorships. This is a fixed funding campaign, if we don't reach our $12,000 Indiegogo goal, your card will be refunded and we call off the trip. If we reach our Indiegogo goal, but don't raise the rest, we will modify the route and do a smaller loop. Additional funds raised will help us get the word out about grasslands conservation through presentations and educational events around the country. Any amount helps, the important thing is that you give-- it shows your enthusiasm and support. Take a look at the breakdown of our budget and the great perks you'll get in exchange for your support (a horseshoe thrown from the road? A Postcard from every state? The list goes on!):

       Budget

Where It's Coming From

Partners and sponsors:

We are teaming up with Colorado College’s State of the Rockies Project, which aims to increase public awareness of environmental concerns in the Rockies states. We will present at the Rockies Project’s annual lecture forum, screening our documentary film and sharing our perspectives at Colorado College. We will be working closely with their research team and provide periodic updates on our progress and findings from the road.

Major Destinations and Contacts:

The Great American Prairie Reserve

The Great American Prairie Reserve is one of the most ambitious conservation projects in North America today. Find out what they're up to when we kick off our ride at their homebase in Glasgow, MT.

Wes Jackson at The Land Institute, Salina, Kansas

Wes Jackson is president and co-founder The Land Institute and has been predicted by Life Magazine to be among the 100 “most important Americans of the 20th century." Want to know why? Check out our video!

Elizabeth Dodd, Poet and Distinguished Professor at Kansas State University

Elizabeth Dodd is a celebrated author of poetry, creative nonfiction and ecocriticism. Her work examines relationships between humans and the natural world. Her book In the Mind’s Eye: Essays Across the Animate World, won the Best Creative Book Award from the Association for the Study of Literature and Environment in 2009.

John W. Head, Wagstaff Distinguished Professor of Law at The University of Kansas Law School

John W. Head's recent work focuses on international legal regimes for the protection of native prairies and grasslands. His most recent book Global Legal Regimes to Protect the World’s Grasslands (November 2012) treats international efforts in grasslands preservation.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us make some noise about the project! You can post our indiegogo campaign on your facebook, tweet about it, and tell your friends, family and all of your communities about it.

If you are involved in or know about an innovative project  along our route that would be of interest to the project, let us know! We'd love to check it out.

If you live along the route, or have family and friends who do and might be interested in hearing what we are up to, we'd love to stop in for the night. You can contact us at RediscoverThePrairie@gmail.com If you are interested in donating equipment or becoming a sponsor for the ride and the film, let us know!

If your gallery, school, college, or other group would like to host a presentation or exhibition, get in touch!

You can learn more about the project and follow us by visiting our website www.RediscoverThePrairie.org

Remeber to use the indiegogoshare tools and THANKYOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!
story_txt:
* * *
We are SO INCREDIBLY OVERJOYED that we have met our Indiegogo fundraising goal!! Thank you SO much to all of our wonderful contributors, you are amazing! We are so grateful to all of our supporters who have helped us reach our first goal. We still have about $9,000 dollars to raise through grants and sponsorships, so contributions that come in during the next 2 days will help us reach our overall goal. Thank you so much!!!

* * * 

Rediscovering the Great American Prairie:
Educate, Engage, Create


The expedition:
Traversing the Great Plains of North America by horseback, our project will bring public attention to the critical role of grassland conservation in North America today. Through education and outreach, from both scientific and artistic perspectives, we will engage a wide audience in an investigation of the issues that affect this vitally important region. We aim to inspire regional scale, long-term conservation and sustainable land use practices by articulating the richness and beauty of the landscape through film, photography, and writing. Inviting discussion with local ecologists, land managers, ranchers, farmers, activists, artists, and the public alike, our journey will dive into the region’s rich historical past, shed light on its present condition, and help inspire creative possibilities for its future.

The Impact
You are supporting a creative approach to a complex problem. Our multi-faceted project merges education, outreach, art, science, and, of course, horses in a way we are certain will excite a deeper understanding, appreciation, and engagement with the natural world and our place within it.


The region: Why the Great Prairie?

Temperate grasslands are the least protected biome on earth, with less than five percent formally protected world-wide, compared with fifteen percent of all terrestrial biomes on average.[1] Within the great plains of the United States, the central tall grasslands ecoregion has the highest percentage of habitat loss of any terrestrial ecoregion on the continent with 99% habitat lost. Nearly all of the tallgrass prairie ecoregions were converted to agricultural use during the 20th century, making the protection of remaining natural areas and the restoration of degraded landscapes of vital importance. (Photo by Diane Hargreaves)



[1] Hoekstra, Molnar, et al. 2010, The Atlas of Global Conservation



Objectives:
1)   We will produce a documentary film that will share the beauty of the landscape and the perspectives of the people we meet along the way. It will be used as an educational tool to promote greater local and national involvement in determining the future of an ecologically imperative region.
2)   We will invite discussion along the way with a diverse number of stakeholders ranging from ranchers and farmers to conservation organizations, writers, artists, and middle schools. We will discuss the importance of conservation in the region, explore the complexities of its current state, and spearhead dialogue about creative solutions and approaches to a sustainable future in the region. 
3)   Along the way we will maintain an interactive website, where the public can follow our progress on the road, access articles, photography, stories, poems,  and short film clips made along the way.
4)   After we complete the ride, we will present our film at high schools, universities, and other groups, giving talks nationwide promoting conservation of this enormously important region and challenging communities to become involved in its story. Our first presentation will be hosted by Colorado College's State of the Rockies Project at their annual lecture forum.
5)   After completion of the ride, we will exhibit our work at galleries around the country, combining art, conservation, community, and education to deepen ecological understanding and appreciation of the natural world. Our first stop will be at the Smokebrush Foundation’s art gallery in Colorado Springs, CO.

Mode of Transportation: Why Horses?


By using horses as our mode of transportation, we will pay homage to the cultural heritage of the landscape and the historic importance of horses in the region. This is a landscape that is often passed through at 75 mph, or looked down upon from 30,000 feet in the air; we want to slow down. We will connect ourselves intimately to the land through which we are traveling: its fertility, the threats it faces, and the urgency of its conservation. Horseback travel will capture the imagination of the public, inspiring those we encounter to envision the vastness of both the land and its opportunities.

The route:


Team Members:
Robin Walter: 
Robin graduated from Colorado College in 2012 with a major in English literature and creative writing. Growing up, she spent most of her time at the stables or in a saddle, riding the trails in Colorado Springs and the Big Horn Mountains in Sheridan, WY. Most recently she was in the Aysén region of Patagonia managing the greenhouses for Conservación Patagonica as it converts a sheep estancia into a future Chilean National Park.

“Becoming more and more familiar with the conservation work underway in Patagonia, I am inspired to pursue similar work closer to home. With a background in poetry, inquiry is at the heart of how I relate to the world. I am keenly interested in discovering and articulating the subtleties of our relationship with people and place, uncovering patterns that are at once familiar and surprising, and in engaging the reader in an intimate reflection of their relationship to the subject explored. I am excited about this project because it will provide me with a unique occasion to do just that, and in a landscape that is absolutely crucial to conservation efforts in North America. I have a life-long respect for nature and the outdoors, a zeal for stories and the craft of writing, extensive experience with photography, a long history with horses, and I have a deep interest in food and agriculture. This project takes each of these interests, and combines them in an exciting and imaginative way.” –Robin
Sebastian Tsocanos: 
Sebastian was born in the coastal forests of Connecticut. Feeling the call to move west, and explore more deeply another region of America, Sebastian studied Environmental Science at Colorado College (’12). Completing his thesis on the rare and threatened remnants of tallgrass prairie in eastern Colorado, Sebastian fell in love with the American prairie, coming to appreciate its beauty and the myriad threats it faces.  Since graduation, Sebastian has worked as a natural resources field technician in El Paso County, CO, on a produce and dairy farm in western Colorado and on a grassland restoration project in Chilean Patagonia.

“I was first acquainted with the Midwestern landscape on long road trips across the country with family and friends. Driving across the plains, it was impossible not to notice how transformed the landscape is, mainly for agricultural purposes, whether plowed for corn and soybeans or heavily grazed by cattle. What was harder to notice was the wildlife that remained: along the roadways, along the railroad tracks, in the small state and local parks, national grasslands set back from the highway, and on the few well cared for farms and ranches scattered through the country, host to the rapidly disappearing native plants and animals that barely hang on in these islands of refuge. It was also hard to see the people that remain in the towns, so many driven out by farm mechanization and consolidation, when you only see the rest-stops and major cities along the interstate. I always wanted to stop and explore those scattered communities, and meet the people for whom the prairie is truly home. As an advocate of sustainable agriculture, I also am deeply interested in exploring the potential options for the future of agriculture in the region, and the work of practitioners already underway. Driving through this wide stretch of country, I always want to slow down, get off of the main roads, to really know the place. This project excites me because it is an opportunity to do that in a very special way, combining my long time love of horses and travel with my passion for prairie conservation, sustainable agriculture, and creative forms of community development, and to share that experience with others.”  -Sebastian
Sebastian and Robin are both Wilderness First Responders, have extensive risk-management skills developed over years of backcountry travel, over 18 years of equestrian experience each, and Sebastian completed the Equine Learning Center of America’s Equine First Aid Course.


What We Need & What You Get
In order to saddle up and head out we need to raise $26,000. We hope to raise atleast $12,000 through Indiegogo, and the rest through grants and sponsorships. This is a fixed funding campaign, if we don't reach our $12,000 Indiegogo goal, your card will be refunded and we call off the trip. If we reach our Indiegogo goal, but don't raise the rest, we will modify the route and do a smaller loop. Additional funds raised will help us get the word out about grasslands conservation through presentations and educational events around the country. Any amount helps, the important thing is that you give-- it shows your enthusiasm and support. Take a look at the breakdown of our budget and the great perks you'll get in exchange for your support (a horseshoe thrown from the road? A Postcard from every state? The list goes on!):

Her book In the Mind’s Eye: Essays Across the Animate World, won the Best Creative Book Award from the Association for the Study of Literature and Environment in 2009.

story:
Why I invited you here:

The image above is of tomato plants on our window sill. They grew from seeds planted with the help of my three year old daughter - Natalia (sorry for no video, I get shy, but please take time to read it all ;)

My aim in life is to leave this planet in a better state than I found it, so that she too can enjoy it's beauty.
The problem is the way we produce food now - through industrial agriculture. Ironically this leads to desertification of this beautiful, once green landscape.
The UK now has no real national parks, very little wildlife, and the little trees remaining are cut down for sheep grazing pastures. This creates water runoff on an unprecedented scale in the highlands, and when added to the record rain fall we recently experienced during the last (and very mild) winter, created floods that put thousands of homes in risk of damage or collapse. The chemicals used to fertilize and fight diseases and pests get into our food, water streams and end up on our plate. Not to mention the pollution of coastal waters. Even golf courses have more vegetation than farms!

There is a way of producing food in a sustainable, resource efficient, restorative way, that uses the combined knowledge of ecosystems, horticulture, and other disparate disciplines. It is called Permaculture.

What We Need & What You Get

Permaculture (permanent agriculture) is the conscious design and maintenance of agriculturally productive ecosystems which have the diversity, stability and resilience of natural ecosystems. It is the harmonious integration of landscape and people providing their food, energy, shelter, and other material and non-material needs in a sustainable way.


Bill Mollison, the founder of permaculture, has endorsed the online Permaculture Design Course ran by one of his long time students - Geoff Lawton. His regular courses are normally held in Australia, and thus are largely inaccessible for people in the UK. The registration for the online course has started today and have a limited number of spaces. It runs only once a year and last year it sold out in a week's time.

The cost is $997 or £599 but the credit card is up to its limit, and there is no chance for a better salary at my current workplace. My financing options are quite limited.

Therefore I turn to you for some old fashioned social credit. A debt for my soul. Should you choose to contribute to my tuition, I will re-pay it as an when you need help or pay it forward within my means. This obviously limits my outreach to friends :)

I can:

  • cook dinner for you
  • make real chocolate from certified organic ingredients
  • help you grow your own veggies
  • grow and look after a tomato plant for you and give you the mature plant with ripening fruit ready to pick straight into a salad :)
  • help you move house :)
  • give you a BIG HUG (not that you need to do this to get one :)

You will be revered by the generations that will come after you as your name will be listed in a prominent location on my blog: http://danieltyrkiel.co.uk/

I can also bow to you whenever we see each other if you are big on flattery :)

The Impact

If you have read it thus far then I thank you and admire your patience :) Here is where you can learn about the potential for world altering value this may unleash. I happen to be a creature of many ideas. Some of these ideas are small and some grand. I have the ability to mobilize people to action or bring them together to spark cooperation. My latest project was a series of interviews with UK based worker coops (available on the blog). Now I'm busy getting to know the neighbours in the 44 flats in the block that we live in to try and build a self governing community (there's a lot of untapped potential right where we live, but normally don't see it). Next week I'm meeting with some people about the possibility of building a greenhouse in the middle of the town.

All these projects are easier to accomplish with credibility, and the course can give me just that (apart from the knowledge). So if you can, give us a chance Gov! Please chuck in to the pot and let me take the course.

Here's the thing - we haven't got much time. I don't know if this is a simple sales method they are employing or if it's genuine - the spaces are limited, and if we don't register in the next few days, then the next course is next year!

My aim of leaving this planet in a better shape than how we got it stands a better chance of reaching with this knowledge. Make us wiser please :)


Other Ways You Can Help:

I know times are tough and you may be on the budget like us. We are a family of three and it's tough to make ends meet. If you can't contribute, please, please pass this to some of your friends.

Many thanks for allowing me to learn how we can make this world a better place for her and her friends:

Oh, and if by some miracle, the amount pledged is higher than £599, then the surplus will be used to make chocolate for you - sounds like a plan?

story:
Background

What does it take to change the course of the planet, from destruction to balance?  When we recognize all the earth provides for us, we step into an unbroken circle of giving.  

Deep in the Amazon jungle, ancient peoples knew how to treat the land with care, and the land took care of them in return.   At this critical point in human history, we are remembering how to live in that reciprocity of gifting.  Peoples from all corners seek for ancient ways of healing with plants.  

We are here, hand in hand with plants, art, and medicine, with the full intention to share what we know.   Surrounded by the gifts of nature, we hope to preserve their heritage for all of humanity.

The reality of greed and disregard for the care and sanctity of the natural world puts the future of plant medicine in peril. Valued medicinal plants teeter on the edge of eradication.  They are cut before maturation, even before they flower and complete their reproductive cycle. 

Without giving back to sacred plants by taking action to protect them, we may loose them for the future generations. 

Please join us in our mission to preserve and share our ancestral ways. 

 

Project Details

INTI YACU — Foundation for the Preservation of Medicinal Plants and Ancestral Traditions

Inti Yacu, which is Quechua for “Water born of the Sun,” is a vision, a project, and a prayer born at the root of conservation, to preserve the traditional medicine of the Amazon.  On our 24 hectares of land in the Amazon Jungle of Peru, we are working to create a refuge to preserve the delicate biodiversity that is home to many plants that feed and heal us spiritually and physically. 

To maintain the balance of these precious lands, requires care and maintenance to allow for our plant healers to flourish.  

We have dedicated our lives to working with these medicines, and bringing their blessings and healing to many communities around the globe.  We are witnesses to the profound healing that occurs, and this project is how we complete the cycle of healing, taking care of these precious medicines that take care of us.

Through the funds we raise, we will continue constructing more cabins and structures to receive more of you who would like to come visit, heal, and learn with us.  Along with preserving and cultivating medicinal plants, we will open the space to receive guests to make ceremonies, diet master plants, and hold visionary art retreats.

The jungle is full of plants that awaken our creative abilities. Inti Yacu is a space for inspired creation, and healing through artistic disciplines as well. The richness of each element thriving there fuels new awareness and expression.

Our own personal healing is deeply connected to environmental restoration. When we heal ourselves, we heal around ourselves too: community, family and earth alike. Our vision is for our work here in the jungle to ignite healing in the souls of those who come to stay with us, and that they bring that healing back to their communities all around the globe.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

In order to continue our work, we need to fund the next phase of construction.

In return for your donation, we have put together gifts as tokens of our gratitude and appreciation.  You can type in any amount to donate, or pick from our perks.

 

The Impact

 

Your donation will help to preserve the delicate biodiversity of this precious jungle, that is being diminished more and more every day. Your support will help us ensure a future for the coming generations that will still know the raw beauty and power of the untouched natural world, and still be able to practice the traditions of their ancestors.

 

Timeline & Budget

 

Here is our budget for 2018: 

The goal we are striving to achieve through this fundraiser is to be a fully functioning center able to receive guests and volunteers. To succeed at this, we need to incorporate appropriate technology such as solar panels, and clean water access throughout the property. We will also be creating jobs for the local community as we will need to hire a cook, groundskeeper, construction and maintenance crews. 

So far, we’ve invested approximately $20,000 into the project during June & July 2017. This money was spent on labor and materials for Maloka construction, kitchen, two cabins, two bathrooms, and a shower; tools; labor for land cultivation; fuel for transportation; wage for cooks and workers; furniture for cabins, Maloka, and kitchen; food for the workers, us, and 8 volunteers; Molaka maintenance; and many other misc costs that arise when working on a project such as this.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Your donations will make this visión a reality. Thank you for offering what you can! We also understand not everyone is in the position to offer funds. If you’d still like to support this project, please share share share with your friends families and communities. Thank you!!

 

Who are We?

 

 

Franz Freyre Del Aguila: Curandero/ Tabaquero native to Pucallpa, Peru.

Juan Carlos Taminchi: Curandero and visionary artist and teacher from Pucallpa, Peru.

Fiammetta Roccisano: Plant medicine disciple and eco-activist from the United States, now living in Pucallpa Peru.

 

We want to express our deepest gratitude to all of our brothers and sisters that feel this value of this work in your being. Thank you for supporting our vision to preserve sacred plants and the traditions of our ancestors.

The richness of each element thriving there fuels new awareness and expression.Our own personal healing is deeply connected to environmental restoration. When we heal ourselves, we heal around ourselves too: community, family and earth alike. Our vision is for our work here in the jungle to ignite healing in the souls of those who come to stay with us, and that they bring that healing back to their communities all around the globe. What We Need & What You Get In order to continue our work, we need to fund the next phase of construction.In return for your donation, we have put together gifts as tokens of our gratitude and appreciation.  You can type in any amount to donate, or pick from our perks. The Impact Your donation will help to preserve the delicate biodiversity of this precious jungle, that is being diminished more and more every day. Your support will help us ensure a future for the coming generations that will still know the raw beauty and power of the untouched natural world, and still be able to practice the traditions of their ancestors. Timeline & Budget Here is our budget for 2018: The goal we are striving to achieve through this fundraiser is to be a fully functioning center able to receive guests and volunteers. To succeed at this, we need to incorporate appropriate technology such as solar panels, and clean water access throughout the property. We will also be creating jobs for the local community as we will need to hire a cook, groundskeeper, construction and maintenance crews. So far, we’ve invested approximately $20,000 into the project during June & July 2017. This money was spent on labor and materials for Maloka construction, kitchen, two cabins, two bathrooms, and a shower; tools; labor for land cultivation; fuel for transportation; wage for cooks and workers; furniture for cabins, Maloka, and kitchen; food for the workers, us, and 8 volunteers; Molaka maintenance; and many other misc costs that arise when working on a project such as this.   Other Ways You Can Help Your donations will make this visión a reality. Thank you for offering what you can! We also understand not everyone is in the position to offer funds. If you’d still like to support this project, please share share share with your friends families and communities. Thank you!! Who are We?  Franz Freyre Del Aguila: Curandero/ Tabaquero native to Pucallpa, Peru.Juan Carlos Taminchi: Curandero and visionary artist and teacher from Pucallpa, Peru.Fiammetta Roccisano: Plant medicine disciple and eco-activist from the United States, now living in Pucallpa Peru. We want to express our deepest gratitude to all of our brothers and sisters that feel this value of this work in your being. Thank you for supporting our vision to preserve sacred plants and the traditions of our ancestors.

story:
The goal

In 1588 a Spanish Armada wreck sank off the coast of Scotland and I have the license to investigate and recover all treasures and am raising funds to enable this exploration. I have already undertaken surveys and investigations on this wreck to give us its position. I am now looking for funds to go and recover what is in it. Contemporaneous records talk about the value of the wreck’s contents being 30,000,000.

I am seeking £390,000 to investigate the wreck and recover the treasure from within.

The history

In 1588, the King of Spain sent what was then the largest fleet ever amassed to invade England. The English fleet stopped the Spanish from invading, but bad weather then scattered the fleet and they were forced to sail all the way round the north of Scotland and Ireland with only a few making it back to Spain. One ship staggered into a sheltered bay in Scotland where it remained for several months until there was an explosion on board which sank it. The ship was carrying several treasures and these were stored in the part of the ship that did not explode.

Picture of a cannon ball from the wreck site.

The remains of the wreck remained visible on the seabed until about 1700 after which it disappeared below the seabed. Before it did, Archibald Miller recovered at least one bronze cannon (a sure sign of the importance of the ship) and saw, but could not reach, a crown. In those days, ‘diving’ consisted of being lowered in a barrel. We know that none of the real treasure was recovered from this wreck before it disappeared below the seabed.

How will the money be spent?

The money will fund the team of divers and investigators who will work to uncover the wreck (lying about ten feet below the seabed). We will use a team of divers instead of robots as only humans can do what is necessary. The advantage to the wreck lying under the mud, is that it has prevented others from finding the wreck and recovering its treasure.

What is the benefit for the investor?

This wreck is privately owned and the treasure will be sold at Sotheby’s of London who are contracted to do this and to safeguard everything brought up. The benefit of investing in this project is the historical value of recovering sixteenth century Spanish treasure, a chance to own some of it and a substantial financial reward. The reward is based on a sliding scale depending on how much is found and realised at sale and can be as much as 150% after the initial investment has been repaid.

My background

My background is an underwater map maker, oceanographer and wreck investigator. During my career I have found and investigated many wrecks both ancient and modern steel ones, including in the Falkland Islands, the Caribbean, the deep mid-Atlantic (5,000 metres down) and many around UK waters. My team of divers and researcher also has 20+ years of research into ancient and modern wrecks.

I hope that you will be part of this exciting and historic project that should also produce you substantial financial benefit as well.

Please help spread the word about this exciting and historic project

story:
Overview:

Koda Quest is an innovative 3-D game for change app staring an adorable polar bear named Koda who lives in the Arctic on a rapidly shrinking iceberg. The innovative game is designed to teach kids about climate change, catalyze energy saving actions and involve the whole family in the issue.

While kids play, they also must take real world energy saving actions to level up and win rewards. 

                                    

Players must care for Koda by feeding him and cleaning him, but they only advance when they do things in the real world like recycle and reduce electricity.  And, they can only win the best rewards for Koda when their parents verify actions have been taken.

At last, a game kids and parents can agree on!

This fundraising campaign will raise the necessary funds to allow the non-profit organization Cool the Earth to complete Koda Quest and roll it out to the world.

Background:

Cool the Earth was established seven years ago to raise awareness about climate change and inspire kids and their families to take small, simple actions to reduce their energy and water use. To-date, our School Program has reached 250,000 families who have collectively taken over 300,000 actions to reduce their carbon footprint. The School Program uses a child-driven model to inspire kids to make changes at home which are then reported back to their school.

In 2010, researchers at Stanford University completed a study of the School Program and found that participant children engaged their parents in climate-positive action, and 33% of parents took new steps to help fight climate change, such as purchasing earth friendly products and making energy efficiency changes in their homes.

                            

                            

With that good news, Cool the Earth decided to increase the reach and impact of the behavior-changing model by developing the fun and engaging game Koda Quest, featuring a polar bear, Koda, who lives on a rapidly shrinking iceberg. Players can slow the melting iceberg by caring for Koda and completing real-world actions to lower their carbon emissions.

In the same way that Smokey the Bear taught kids to prevent forest fires in the 1940s, Koda teaches children earth-friendly behavior by asking them to complete real-world actions at home, such as turning off lights, walking to school and taking a shorter shower. When children complete these tasks, they see that their actions directly help Koda.

With 75% of U.S. children having access to smart mobile devices, playing an average of 17 hours per week, and wielding considerable influence in the family, a unique opportunity exists to address the climate change challenge by melding grassroots real-world action with the application of technology.

Cool the Earth is excited that Koda Quest will soon be bringing the message of kid-powered behavior change to thousands of additional families throughout the nation, at no cost! 

Campaign

Cool the Earth needs your help!  Development of Koda Quest is now 80% complete and although Koda is already pretty adorable, Cool the Earth knows that the game needs to be engaging, inspirational, and fun in order to stand out in the crowd.

The game currently includes the ability to care for Koda by washing and feeding him, as well as two educational mini games, where players swipe carbon clouds in the sky, and fish trash out of the ocean. However, more features need to be added to ensure the game is a success.

             

Cool the Earth would like to add a dress up feature where kids will be able to earn Koda clothes such as baseball hats and t-shirts, and a feature to allow children to talk to their device so they can tell Koda what they’re doing to help the planet for example, “Yes Koda, I separated my recycling today!”

                

                 

During the next sixty days, Cool the Earth will raise the $10,000 needed to complete Koda Quest and roll out the first ever kid-powered game that reduces carbon emissions and preserves our planet for future generations. 

What you can do

Give a little or give a lot. Consider donating a tank of gas $50 — or the amount of you monthly energy bill — $100, but no matter how much you give, all contributions will go a long way to help introduce Koda to the world and spread the climate-change message.

In addition, please share this campaign on your Facebook Wall, so that others can discover the great work done by Cool the Earth.

Find this Campaign On:

FaceBook,  You Tube. Cool the Earth, Twitter

story:
Paul Klopfer's and Josh Katz's Official Fundraising Campaign Page

What Is This

Typhoon Haiyan, known as Typhoon Yolanda in the Philippines, was an exceptionally powerful tropical cyclone that devastated portions of Southeast Asia, particularly the Philippines, in early November 2013. It is the deadliest Philippine typhoon on record, killing at least 5,786 people in that country alone, and displacing 4 million Filipinos. Haiyan is also the strongest storm recorded at landfall, and unofficially the fourth strongest typhoon ever recorded in terms of wind speed.

One island in particular was hit very badly, Bantayan Island, 95% of people lost thier homes. Unfortunately, none of the major aid like the UN or Red Cross are providing support here because they are focused on the bigger cities. We are part of a group of people that is spending ~3 months living on the island aiding in the reconstruction effort. Paul and Josh specifically will be spending 3 weeks at the end of december helping to rebuild the schools, bring in funds, coordinate involvement from local volunteers, and building relationships with larger organizations to attract more support.

The focus of our efforts will be on rebuilding the schools that were destroyed and have left the children on the island without education, shelter, and safety. This fundraising campaign will help fund the development efforts on the island. Things are some what cheap over there, so every donation will have a big impact.

So this is an amazing chance to help get the kids of Bantayan Island back into their classrooms!

 We are working with two major groups for reconstruction. The Young Pioneer Tours and the Bangon Bantayanons. You can check out the Young Pioneer Tour's Indiegogo campaign here http://igg.me/at/Typhoon-Yolanda-Relief/x/5573894!

What you Need to Know

Our Official Website has all the details you might want on the reconstruction initiative. --->>>http://www.bantayanreconstruction.org/  As a quick summary, we will be rebuilding 5 schools on the island. Reconstruction has already begun on the first school, Santa Fe Elementary. Info and progress updates can be seen and the coordinating organizations FB page. https://www.facebook.com/groups/739567302724644/.

Major Impact

We are targeting $15k in funding. Of that, the first $2k will cover 40% of our personal expense, and we covered the other 60%, committing $3k of our own money to this effort, in addition to 3 weeks of our time. For the remaining $13k, every dollar will be spent directly on materials supplies and local labor to rebuild the schools. We are going to be super transparent because we want you to see and feel the impact you are having. So we will post every single dollar spent out of this fundraising budget on our website at www.bantayanreconstruction.org/donationtracking, and you can go own and see how your money has made a difference in the lives of thousand of kids.

Contacting

Call us for any concerns, questions, ideas about fundraising, Filipino contacts, to wish us a safe and effective reconstruction, want to know how things are on the ground, want to talk to a local, or want to write a story on this to help increase fundraising efforts, email us here.

Paul Klopfer - paul@challengage.com

Josh Katz - josh.robert.katz@gmail.com

story:
Breve reseña

Mi nombre es Miguel Ángel Moreno después, de 35 años de ser comerciante y habiendo quebrado una micro empresa de artículos automotrices, queriendo buscar empleo no obtuve resultados positivos con las personas a las que solicite, por lo que decidí aprender algo de química (soluciones acuosas) y así nació Mijomova Internacional SA, ya hace 7 años. Encontrándome sin capital para trabajar y con un mercado muy competido y saturado de los diversos productos que había aprendido a fabricar pensé que debía hacer algo diferente, y nació la idea de fabricar un coolant solido dando como resultado final este coolant antioxidante hecho a base de sales de sodio  

Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes

Estoy solicitando $200.000 esto se va a emplear en materia prima, en la creación de un laboratorio, empacado, compra de maquinaria y equipo, salarios de los colaboradores, alquiler de bodega y publicidad del producto. En el vídeo que les aporte se puede ver que la maquinaria que hoy en día usamos no es la adecuada y que no existe un laboratorio ni mesas de trabajo. La idea es poder mantener tres meses aproximadamente la producción, para levantar la empresa y lograr colocarnos en el mercado internacional.    

A todas la personas que contribuyan con este proyecto van a figurar en nuestra lista  de fundadores en mención honorifica en linea (Redes Sociales).

Los que colaboren con $15 se les enviara una muestra de Coolant DEX de una unidad del tipo que requieran diesel/gasolina a la dirección que nos faciliten.

Los que colaboren $25 se les enviara una muestra de Coolant DEX de cuatro unidades del tipo que requieran diesel/gasolina a la dirección que nos faciliten.

Los que colaboren con $50 se les enviara una muestra de Coolant DEX de cuatro unidades y un Certificado Honorifico como colaborador externo de la empresa, a la dirección que nos faciliten.

Los que colaboren con $100 se les enviara una muestra de 10 unidades de Coolant DEX diesel/gasolina mas un Certificado Honorifico como Colaborador externo de la empresa, a la dirección que nos faciliten. 

Los que colaboren con $500 se les enviara una muestra de 24 unidades de Coolant DEX diesel/gasolina mas un Certificado Honorifico como Colaborador VIP de la empresa, a la dirección que nos faciliten. 

Los que colaboren con  $1000 se les enviara una muestra de 50 unidades de Coolant DEX diesel/gasolina mas un Certificado Honorifico como Colaborador VIP de la empresa, a la dirección que nos faciliten y podrán optar por ser parte de nuestro equipo de distribución en la región de su interés, siempre y cuando allá disponibilidad en la región prometiendo le crédito después de 6 meses de operaciones.

Ademas a todos los colaboradores se les dará prioridad cuando tengamos que seleccionar distribuidores.

Pienso que con $200.000 puedo empezar este proyecto y ponerlo en marcha, si acaso no se lograra la meta, tendría que emplear los fondos que se recauden en atender prioridades como el alquiler de la bodega, la compra de empaque y materia prima, el pago de personal de producción y un poco de publicidad que me permita tener ventas a nivel local, para luego pensar con las utilidades obtenidas comprar maquinaria mas optima y buscar mercado internacionales.

El Impacto

Este invento es un  antioxidante solido soluble en agua, apto para cualquier sistema de enfriamiento donde el agua este en contacto con el hierro y se requiera que este no oxide. En esta modalidad existen muchos antioxidantes de diversas marcas todos ellos en presentación liquida. Este nuevo Coolant DEX, pretende brindarle al usuario una mayor calidad y cuidado en su sistema de enfriamiento.

Utilizando este producto vamos a proteger el planeta, pues dejaremos de contaminar con millones de envases plásticos, con millones de cajas de cartón, por ejemplo. en una caja donde se envasan seis galones de coolant liquido, se pueden empacar seiscientas pastillas de Coolant DEX, lo que nos permite dejar de utilizar noventa y nueve cajas y seiscientos galones plásticos. A parte de esto dejaremos de contaminar el medio ambiente con las emisiones de gases producidos por los combustibles que se utilizan en el trasiego del coolant liquido pues una caja con seiscientas pastillas alcanza un peso promedio de tres kilos y medio, mientras que para seiscientos galones se ocupan cien cajas, seiscientos envases con un peso promedio de tres mil kilos.

El usuario final va obtener un producto mas fácil de transportar, almacenar y de aplicar y va a colaborar en la preservación del planeta.   

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

A todos aquellos que lean sobre este proyecto empresarial y no puedan apoyar económicamente, pueden darnos un gran aporte transfiriendo esta información a familiares  y amigos en la red, esto creara consciencia de que hay una posibilidad mas de sostener el planeta y que también alguno podrá aportar su granito de arena y por su puesto estaremos muy agradecidos tanto con los que nos ayuden económicamente como con los que nos comenten con otros. muchas gracias. 

Para negocios o información puedes contactarnos en:

Mijomova Internacional SA

Tel: (506)22541800 - (506)85187611

San José, Costa Rica

http://more271051.wix.com/mijomova
story_txt: Breve reseñaMi nombre es Miguel Ángel Moreno después, de 35 años de ser comerciante y habiendo quebrado una micro empresa de artículos automotrices, queriendo buscar empleo no obtuve resultados positivos con las personas a las que solicite, por lo que decidí aprender algo de química (soluciones acuosas) y así nació Mijomova Internacional SA, ya hace 7 años. Encontrándome sin capital para trabajar y con un mercado muy competido y saturado de los diversos productos que había aprendido a fabricar pensé que debía hacer algo diferente, y nació la idea de fabricar un coolant solido dando como resultado final este coolant antioxidante hecho a base de sales de sodio  Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienesEstoy solicitando $200.000 esto se va a emplear en materia prima, en la creación de un laboratorio, empacado, compra de maquinaria y equipo, salarios de los colaboradores, alquiler de bodega y publicidad del producto. En el vídeo que les aporte se puede ver que la maquinaria que hoy en día usamos no es la adecuada y que no existe un laboratorio ni mesas de trabajo. La idea es poder mantener tres meses aproximadamente la producción, para levantar la empresa y lograr colocarnos en el mercado internacional.    A todas la personas que contribuyan con este proyecto van a figurar en nuestra lista  de fundadores en mención honorifica en linea (Redes Sociales).Los que colaboren con $15 se les enviara una muestra de Coolant DEX de una unidad del tipo que requieran diesel/gasolina a la dirección que nos faciliten.Los que colaboren $25 se les enviara una muestra de Coolant DEX de cuatro unidades del tipo que requieran diesel/gasolina a la dirección que nos faciliten.Los que colaboren con $50 se les enviara una muestra de Coolant DEX de cuatro unidades y un Certificado Honorifico como colaborador externo de la empresa, a la dirección que nos faciliten.Los que colaboren con $100 se les enviara una muestra de 10 unidades de Coolant DEX diesel/gasolina mas un Certificado Honorifico como Colaborador externo de la empresa, a la dirección que nos faciliten. Los que colaboren con $500 se les enviara una muestra de 24 unidades de Coolant DEX diesel/gasolina mas un Certificado Honorifico como Colaborador VIP de la empresa, a la dirección que nos faciliten. Los que colaboren con  $1000 se les enviara una muestra de 50 unidades de Coolant DEX diesel/gasolina mas un Certificado Honorifico como Colaborador VIP de la empresa, a la dirección que nos faciliten y podrán optar por ser parte de nuestro equipo de distribución en la región de su interés, siempre y cuando allá disponibilidad en la región prometiendo le crédito después de 6 meses de operaciones. Ademas a todos los colaboradores se les dará prioridad cuando tengamos que seleccionar distribuidores.Pienso que con $200.000 puedo empezar este proyecto y ponerlo en marcha, si acaso no se lograra la meta, tendría que emplear los fondos que se recauden en atender prioridades como el alquiler de la bodega, la compra de empaque y materia prima, el pago de personal de producción y un poco de publicidad que me permita tener ventas a nivel local, para luego pensar con las utilidades obtenidas comprar maquinaria mas optima y buscar mercado internacionales.El Impacto Este invento es un  antioxidante solido soluble en agua, apto para cualquier sistema de enfriamiento donde el agua este en contacto con el hierro y se requiera que este no oxide. En esta modalidad existen muchos antioxidantes de diversas marcas todos ellos en presentación liquida. Este nuevo Coolant DEX, pretende brindarle al usuario una mayor calidad y cuidado en su sistema de enfriamiento. Utilizando este producto vamos a proteger el planeta, pues dejaremos de contaminar con millones de envases plásticos, con millones de cajas de cartón, por ejemplo. en una caja donde se envasan seis galones de coolant liquido, se pueden empacar seiscientas pastillas de Coolant DEX, lo que nos permite dejar de utilizar noventa y nueve cajas y seiscientos galones plásticos. A parte de esto dejaremos de contaminar el medio ambiente con las emisiones de gases producidos por los combustibles que se utilizan en el trasiego del coolant liquido pues una caja con seiscientas pastillas alcanza un peso promedio de tres kilos y medio, mientras que para seiscientos galones se ocupan cien cajas, seiscientos envases con un peso promedio de tres mil kilos. El usuario final va obtener un producto mas fácil de transportar, almacenar y de aplicar y va a colaborar en la preservación del planeta.   Otras formas en las que puedes ayudarA todos aquellos que lean sobre este proyecto empresarial y no puedan apoyar económicamente, pueden darnos un gran aporte transfiriendo esta información a familiares  y amigos en la red, esto creara consciencia de que hay una posibilidad mas de sostener el planeta y que también alguno podrá aportar su granito de arena y por su puesto estaremos muy agradecidos tanto con los que nos ayuden económicamente como con los que nos comenten con otros. muchas gracias. Para negocios o información puedes contactarnos en:Mijomova Internacional SATel: (506)22541800 - (506)85187611San José, Costa Ricahttp://more271051.wix.com/mijomova

story:
Let’s Do It! World Cleanup happening world-wide and in ONE DAY - also in your country!

With your kind help we can build up teams in all the countries in the world to organise the biggest civic action in human history - a World Cleanup Day on the 8th of September 2018. 

Your donation will make sure we find and train capable leaders in every country - including your country! We have unique experience mobilizing a big number of people – having involved ca 14 million people already! 

Imagine in 2018, a powerful “green wave” starting in Japan and ending in Hawaii with hundreds of millions of people taking positive action together on the same day.

Our ultimate goal is a clean world, and we have a plan consisting of four big steps:

  • Firstly, we are actively recruiting for ambitious leaders willing to run the massive nationwide cleanups.

  • Then, using technology, the best professionals, and our worldwide volunteer base, we will map the world’s waste.

  • Our third step will be to clean up the entire world in one massive world-wide cleanup day in September, 2018.

  • And finally, together with organizations, experts, and visionaries around the world we will create a plan to stop the waste problem once and for all. We can keep our planet clean, but only if we do it together.

    Let’s Do It! is a civic-led mass movement that began in Estonia in 2008 when 50,000 people united together to clean up the entire country (10,000 tonnes of waste) in just five hours. Since then, we have spread this model—one country in one day—around the world. To date, 112 countries and almost 14 million people have joined us and cleaned up more than 500,000 tonnes of illegal waste.


Why are we doing this? 

Did you know that every year 20 million tons of garbage is added to our oceans, 80% of it from mainland waste. That’s like dumping over 710,000 Boeing 737 airplanes into the ocean…each year.

The fact is, waste has a nasty little habit of not staying in one place. As trash begins to decompose, harmful chemicals and toxins begin to leak. First into the soil, then it spreads into the water and air– the very things that all living things depend on for a healthy life. Dirty drinking water, the spread of diseases, red-flag air pollution days… these are all related to the waste we produce.

We need to do something about it, because waste is a worldwide problem and knows no borders.

Why we need your help?

If you share our dream of a Clean World, and wish to see the plan succeed, then support us and make a donation for the World Cleanup Day 2018.

Your Support Will Help to Find & Train Over 150 Leaders Who Will Clean Up Their Countries in Just One Day - 8 September 2018

If we really want a clean world and live to see it, we need your help. Let’s Do It! has never been only about waste. It’s about people. This is why it makes a lot of sense to kickstart the whole ambitious plan together with people like you. We have a plan and we have gathered enough experience to make it happen, but to raise the bar and unite 150 countries for a one massive civic action. Raising 150 000 € (ca $162 000) will be our seed money to make Let’s Do It! blossom around the world.

We’ve invested 43,5 million hours of voluntary work to build teams, plan logistics, organise cleanups, etc. Every 100 € (ca 109 USD) raised helps to bring five new volunteers to a cleanup day.

We need the funds to carry out every step of our plan. Even if we do not raise as much as planned here in Indiegogo (but we trust you, guys!), we will keep working our asses off, so that the trash problem would not come and bite you in the butt. But let’s be honest here, your help will make us meet the goals much faster.

Our dedicated staff and volunteers are responsible for seeking out inspiring leaders across the globe, and supporting new and existing teams in their efforts to organize and lead teams of change-makers in their respective countries.


If you are experiencing difficulties with payment (we are truly sorry!) you can become a supporter of World Cleanup Day 2018, by making a transfer to our bank account in Estonia. We'll make sure it will be transferred to this Indiegogo campaign: 

Account details: Swedbank
Name of the Owner of the Account: Lets Do It Foundation
IBAN: EE65 2200 2210 5275 4853
BIC/SWIFT: HABAEE2X

By pushing "Contribute now" you can make a donation:
1) via credit card; or 
2) using your PayPal account. 

 


Our lasting gratitude for supporting the cause and good feeling from helping to clean up the world from waste. You will join the community of millions of people with your own unique and personal number. As a part of the #iam380million, you get your very own identification, starting from the 14 500 000 volunteers who have participated in Let's Do It campaigns up to date.


Good feeling, lasting gratitude and a specially designed social media token to share and show yourself as a supporter of the Clean World plus your own unique and personal number as an indication of being a part of a Let's Do It! community #iam380million 
 

Our team members from around the world will send you a handwritten postcard with Clean World greetings. Imagine getting a postcard from Lapland, or from Siberia – or from the Philippines, Iceland or Kenya! Each of them unique and one of the kind. You will naturally also receive the “The Feel-Good Contributor" package.

Since caring about the environment we live in is the most humane thing to do, you will receive your own copy of the book “Human: Instructions for Use” (Operating guide to a healthy body). The book brings up shocking questions, revealing the adversity of such seemingly harmless items as chairs, tables, toothbrushes, sitting toilets, shoes, calendars, etc. and exposes a number of crippling cultural norms that are blindly upheld only because they are so widely accepted.
You will naturally also receive the “The Feel-Good Contributor" package.

You will be awarded with a copy of the documentary film “Let’s do it!” (Taiga Film) that will be released in 2016, covering the efforts of Let's Do It! activists to clean up the Mediterranean Sea.

You will naturally also receive the “The Feel-Good Contributor" package.



For a do-gooder like you, we’d like to give you a gift of music. You will get a special collection from our partner, a Grammy awarded band Monsieur Periné, who are true civic activists and love what Let's Do It! is all about!

You will also receive the “The Feel-Good Contributor" package.



You’re a true change maker and only deserve walking around and being awesome in designer up-cycled T-shirts. You will receive the original UpShirt® by eco-designer Reet Aus. Reet Aus’ UpShirt® is a Tee with the smallest environmental footprint in the World.​ It’s made 100% out of industrial textile leftovers with no virgin materials used. By wearing the UpShirt®, you are part of saving 77% of water, 93% of energy and avoiding 89% of CO2 emission compared to any conventional cotton T-shirt. You can choose women's (sizes XS, S, M, L, XL) or men's (sizes S, M, L, XL or XXL). How cool is that?

You will naturally also receive the “The Feel-Good Contributor" package and an album from Monsieur Periné to give your walk a jazzy touch!

Wow! You really deserve to be noticed, and two thousand hugs! You will be listed on our web page as one of the supporters of Let’s Do It! World and get to wear the original UpShirt® by eco-designer Reet Aus. Reet Aus’ UpShirt® is a Tee with the smallest environmental footprint in the World.​ By wearing the UpShirt®, you are part of saving 77% of water, 93% of energy and avoiding 89% of CO2 emission compared to any conventional cotton T-shirt.

Welcome on board! You are invited to Estonia, the birth country of Let’s Do It! and attend the Let’s Do It! Day of Civic Actions on May 7th 2016. We will treat you like the Clean World Captain you are, covering your accommodation, activities and meals. We will make sure you get a true local experience together with our Let’s Do It! World management team. Ever dreamed about white nights, a real sauna experience or want to see if WiFi works in the forest – we will plan a visit together with you, which you will never forget.


Our experience from many countries has shown we can bring real change, and fast, if a massive amount of people are mobilized for one positive cause. It’s all about ambition, action, cooperation and positivity.

Active people in many countries have joined to clean up their countries in one day. In Latvia (210,000), Lithuania (250,000), Portugal (100,000), Slovenia (270,000), Romania (250,000), Albania (147,000), Hungary (200,000), Bulgaria (375,000), Ukraine (500,000), India (54,000), the Philippines (28,000) and in many other countries massive Let’s Do It! cleanups for a clean planet have been taking place.

Success stories

A real change has already happened in Slovenia. The same Let’s Do It! volunteers who cleaned up Slovenia are now leading the change to make Ljubljana the first capital city of Europe to be Zero Waste. Other municipalities and regions have already joined the plan to stop the waste and to start seeing materials as resources. Today, country-wide cleanup campaigns are no longer even necessary.

In Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, the cleanups have been so successful in bringing people together, that the tradition still persists. Even though there is no longer the need to mobilize such a massive amount of people to clean up litter. It’s now about celebrating civic activism and doing any kind of community work together.

According to the 2016 Environmental Performance Index, which ranks 180 countries on how they protect human health and ecosystems, Estonia is the eighth most environmentally friendly country on Earth. That’s a huge leap – from 10 000 tonnes of waste in nature to one of the most environmentally friendly countries on Earth. Slovenia ranks number five in the same category.

In many countries, Let’s Do It! has grown so fast, that it has created a new culture of civic activism and volunteering that was no longer there. Read about some of our success stories here.

Risks & Challenges

The idea of cleaning the world in one day might sound crazy, maybe even impossible, but we have the plan and we have had some amazing success stories, and some hard core experience. This is our foundation for a plan in which we truly believe in.

Our biggest risk is not finding the right people in time to lead country-wide cleanup actions. This is why every donation you make will be invested in finding and training these leaders, who really have it in them to make it happen. It’s the people who get things done!

Other Ways You Can Help

We believe in the dream of a Clean World. We are driven to find new solutions and bring great ideas to life, together with you. Show your support by spreading the word among your friends, colleagues and others in your contact network.

Together, we can make it happen! You can also help by becoming our partner or help us to find new partners (write to partners@letsdoitworld.org to get in touch).We welcome everyone to join our team and help us to become better. It’s a great way to do more, be more. If you’re interested in joining our international team or contacting a team in your country, check out our website for more information: www.letsdoitworld.org




Let's Do It! is one of the world's fastest growing civic movements; born in Estonia in 2008 it now unites 112 countries all over the world. The goal of this grassroots worldwide network is to initiate positive change at a local and global level, working towards a clean, healthy and waste-free world. I am confident about the movement´s success.“

"This project is changing the world. People from over 112 countries are becoming engaged, educated and passionate toward the world's one common problem: waste. Let's do it! has changed lives, improved communities and inspired people to make a lasting difference. It's a revolution." 
Watch Luke's TEDx talk HERE

"Introduced in 2012 to Let’s Do It! World by a Meridian International Center alumna of the U.S. Department of State’s International Visitor Leadership Program (IVLP), I have watched this amazing initiative  to clean up the world’s waste grow from a seedling to a full fledged tree with branches reaching out around the world.  At Meridian International Center, our work with international visitors through the IVLP strives to achieve the same reach through programs of global importance.  We are happy to join with the World Clean-Up Initiative and we encourage our IVLP alumni to join us as team leaders to clean up the world’s waste on one glorious day of service to our respective communities. Let’s Do It! World!"

story:
Short Summary

As an author, I use words and books to entertain and educate readers. Creating Mitzy, the Butterfly was a way of introducing young readers to their environment and to ways the readers can make a positive difference in protecting and caring for their environment. 

Writing the books is the easy part. I know about rain gardens, edible gardens and even bay scape gardens along with rain barrels, trees and so much more; but, none of that matters if the books do not get into the hands of the readers. These readers are often elementary school students who are being introduced to their environment through science classes.  It is important for us to incorporate this information in other classes too... such as Reading, English and Library.

By adding a set of Mitzy, the Butterfly books to a school library, you are not just reaching ONE reader... you are opening the door to a potential readership that reaches into the hundreds. Think about this, if you put a set in just one elementary school library in a school that has over 500 students, what is the potential for having the books read by hundreds of readers? Sadly, school library budgets are limited and this is a chance to make a huge contribution to the school, their library and to all those students!  Will you help make this happen?

What We Need & What You Get

 Each set of Mitzy, the Butterfly books (current just five books) can be purchased for approximately $50.  By raising just $500, ten schools can receive a full set.  The ten schools on my list have an enrollment of nearly 5,000 students... that will make a huge impact on the immediate environment as well as the entire Chesapeake Bay watershed.

Essex, Hawthorne, Middleborough, Sandalwood and Sussex Elementary Schools in Baltimore County are on or very close to local rivers.  Middlesex, Mars Estates, Deep Creek, Martin Boulevard and Victory Villa Elementary Schools are also within this water-access community.  Clean air, clean water and proper protection of the land environment are essential to a clean, healthy neighborhood.  The Mitzy books will encourage readers and give them ways to be good stewards of the environment.

If the goal is not reached, each school will still receive some of the Mitzy books, with the hope that readers will be eager to search out the other books in the series. Book 2, which asks readers to analyze their immediate environment, will surely be one of the books provided to the schools.  It is finding a huge adult audience and to date has had the biggest readership.

The bottom line is... THROUGH this campaign much can be accomplished with very little effort.  Getting the info into the hands of the correct audience is an awesome goal... and can be accomplished here!

The Impact

Check out my personal website, www.annarenault.com, to learn more about me and the projects on which I participate -- the environment and cancer. I've published a number of books that not only entertain but educate. Many of the books are fundraising projects for schools, environmental organizations and a cancer foundation.  YOUR participation in this project will greatly assist with two of those three.

Risks & Challenges

Getting books published has become much easier through the Amazon owned program, CreateSpace.  This allows authors like me to provide these educational books at very reasonable prices. The hurdle then, however, is to get these books into the hands of those who most need to read them.  Sadly, with a very tight environment, many parents are not able to buy a variety of books. By getting these books into the school libraries, YOU can get the books into the hands of the readers who most need to read them.

Other Ways You Can Help

As I mentioned, the economy has been tight... and there are many people who cannot contribute cash to the project.  IF this describes you, then I ask for your help in sharing this information with others who might be willing and able to contribute. AND, I ask that you post information about the books on your facebook page and other social media sites to get the information to the readers.

 THANK YOU for taking the time to read this post... for participating in some way... and for being excited about YOUR environment!
story_txt:
Short Summary As an author, I use words and books to entertain and educate readers. Creating Mitzy, the Butterfly was a way of introducing young readers to their environment and to ways the readers can make a positive difference in protecting and caring for their environment. 
Writing the books is the easy part. I know about rain gardens, edible gardens and even bay scape gardens along with rain barrels, trees and so much more; but, none of that matters if the books do not get into the hands of the readers. These readers are often elementary school students who are being introduced to their environment through science classes.  It is important for us to incorporate this information in other classes too... such as Reading, English and Library.
By adding a set of Mitzy, the Butterfly books to a school library, you are not just reaching ONE reader... you are opening the door to a potential readership that reaches into the hundreds. Think about this, if you put a set in just one elementary school library in a school that has over 500 students, what is the potential for having the books read by hundreds of readers? Sadly, school library budgets are limited and this is a chance to make a huge contribution to the school, their library and to all those students!  Will you help make this happen?   What We Need & What You Get  Each set of Mitzy, the Butterfly books (current just five books) can be purchased for approximately $50.  By raising just $500, ten schools can receive a full set.  The ten schools on my list have an enrollment of nearly 5,000 students... that will make a huge impact on the immediate environment as well as the entire Chesapeake Bay watershed.
