story:
Bonobos, the underdog of the primate world, have been waiting peacefully in the shadows for too long!  Overlooked by their primate cousins (that us humans), bonobos were the last of the great apes to be recognised by Science and remain 'the forgotten ape' to this day.  Underlined in red by spellcheck, omitted from Hollywood's Planet of the Apes and associated more closely with an electronic DJ from Bristol than with our closest living evolutionary relative...

                           ...it is an oversight that might cost us their lives. 

Please watch our video (including our pretty awesome animation about bonobos) to find out more!

 

I'm Tallulah, the UK Director of the Bonobo Conservation Initiative UK (www.bonobo.org.uk).  I set up BCI-UK in 2011 after discovering that there were no existing charities for bonobos in the UK!  What started out as a frustration with the shocking lack of support for our fellow ape, ended up in a plan to leave my job as a Science teacher and to do something about it.  For the last two years I have been campaigning for the cause - a decision which has resulted in me dressing up as a bonobo to walk the streets of London on multiple occasions, hosting frequent burlesque fundraisers and tweeting, blogging and talking incessantly to anyone who will listen about why bonobos need our help!    

Over the last 18 months BCI-UK has raised over £9000 ($13,500) and all of our profits have funded community managed conservation projects. 

 

Despite our successes I am asked the same question day after day:

                              What is a bonobo?

 

It's hard to save what you don't know, and unless we get to know bonobos soon we may lose that chance forever.  

And so, this summer I will be travelling to DRC with my talented photographer friend, Emma, to film a documentary about bonobos and BCI's work to empower local communities to live sustainably.

I have never been to DRC or seen bonobos in the wild (despite running the charity, and having both a Zoology degree and a MSc in Primate Conservation).  The trip is sadly far from cost-effective requiring 3 planes into the interior of the Congo Basin - one international, one commercial and one chartered (all very exciting but cavorting around like James Bond doesn't come cheap).  But this summer a wonderful opportunity has arisen to share a chartered plane with a team of 8 to reduce costs (see full details below). The benefits of the expedition will more than pay for themselves:  The film will be an invaluable marketing and campaign tool raising public awareness and helping to showcase the work of BCI to an international audience and to future grant makers and sponsors.

 

The more people that know and care about bonobos the greater their chance of survival.

 

Please help us to acheive this once in a lifetime opportunity if you can and help us to help the all-too-often forgotten ape.

 

FAQ:

What is a bonobo?

I could talk all about bonobos non-stop but I'll give you the skinny version:  Bonobos are matriarchal, peaceful and empathetic, they avoid conflict by following the 'make love not war' philosophy.  All bonobos are bisexual, their societies are complex and egalitarian, governed by a sorority of unrelated females that develop close friendships.  They are highly intelligent and in scientific studies have been shown to consider other's feelings, share food with strangers rather than eat alone, demonstrate theory of mind and possess basic language distinguishing between food types and different threats with a range of specific calls.  They walk upright on two feet almost half the time, they live up to 50 years and will have up to 4 offspring in their lifetime.  All members of the group contribute to the child care responsibilities.  Bushmeating hunting aside, it's a pretty idyllic life for a bonobo...

 

Who are BCI?

BCI are an American organisation (www.bonobo.org) that work with local communities to empower people living within the bonobo habitat to have the means and the education to protect bonobos and safeguard their rainforest home.  The work that BCI do is remarkable, building leadership capacity, setting up health centres, establishing colleges that teach sustainable agriculture and conservation management and providing microfinance initiatives to support local livelihoods.  So much of their work goes by unnoticed by the world, they are currently in desperate need of funding to continue to support the 28 communities that they work with and to protect the remaining bonobo populations.  

BCI-UK is an independent British NFP organisation (www.bonobo.org.uk), set up under UK law, our mission is to raise awareness of bonobos and support ongoing efforts to protect bonobos by funding community managed conservation projects in DRC.

 

Why are bonobos endangered?

Bonobos are hunted for bushmeat in the beleagured Democratic Republic of Congo, where, due to recent wars, political instability and rural poverty up to 80% of protein is derived from wild meat.  Bonobos are only foung in DRC and their population, small to begin with, is fragmented and decreasing.  Whole populations have been wiped out from areas where they were once abundant.  Bonobos now only exist in small pockets of their former range and, based on the best evidence available, researchers estimate that less than 10,000 bonobos may remain.  If ever they needed to be bailed out of trouble by their big brother, the time is now.

 
An adult female bonobo stares thoughtfully

  

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

With that in mind we invite you to show the bonobos some love! 

  

Why do we need £5500?

Flights London to Kinshasa = £850  X 2 = £1700

Flights Kinshasa to Mbandaka = £330  X  2 = £660

Chartered plane Mbandaka to Djolu (1/8) = £600  X 2 = £1200

Film equipment hire = £1000

Yellow fever vaccinations = £30 X 2 = £60

Accomodation 2 night Kinshasa, 2 nights Mbandaka = £130

30 day Visa to DRC from UK = £60  X 2 = £120

Fuel and transport costs = approx £150

 

I am always amazed by the generosity and kindness of strangers and the ongoing support from friends and family, so I will just use this last bit of space to say... thank you.  We appreciate every penny!

story:
Context

Do you know where the energy comes from when you switch on the lights at home? Over 40% of the world’s electricity comes from coal, and of all the fossil fuels, coal has the highest carbon content. The extraction and use of coal for energy is the single greatest threat facing our climate. Colombia is one of the largest coal exporters in the world. The majority of benefits from the coal industry are reaped by foreign entities extracting the coal, primarily for export to the United States and countries in Europe. Those facing the most adverse effects of coal operations are the communities living close to or forced to leave their homes near the mine. This means that there are powerful international corporations at work in the area, and the obstacles facing communities working to remain on their land are seemingly endless. 

Tierra Digna is a collective of human rights and environmental lawyers that works to defend these communities by helping them clarify and advocate for their rights in confronting these big mining companies and in dignified resettlement. In doing so they effectively challenge the interests of these corporations and as a result, face threats and serious security risks.

At FOR Peace Presence we care deeply about these issues. We accompany Tierra Digna in the field, in their struggle with these communities who are saying no to corporate supremacy and standing up to protect the environment and their communities.

Our Work

At FOR Peace Presence, we’ve been working to promote human and environmental rights, peace and justice in Colombia since 2002. Our mission is to provide physical safety, political visibility, and stand in solidarity by accompanying communities and organizations that embrace active nonviolence to defend life, land and dignity. We stand proudly with Tierra Digna and accompany them so that they are safe and are supported politically by our international network while conducting their work.


What is accompaniment?

Physical/Protective Accompaniment -- Colombia's conflict includes three armed groups with varied interests and in this case, powerful corporations are also implicated. Our team is constantly analyzing the political context to ensure that we are able to do the work to keep people safe. We travel with organizations like Tierra Digna, and our physical presence demonstrates an attentive international eye as they confront large-scale “development” projects and corporate extractive industries.

Political Accompaniment and Advocacy -- We collaborate with Tierra Digna to carry out political work with government officials and the diplomatic core. We also build networks abroad in places like the U.S. and Europe, which are consumer countries where natural resources, like coal, are taken from Colombia and exported.Our team raises concerns to authorities so that corporations are held accountable.

Solidarity -- Finally, we host delegations, organize speaking tours, and publish a variety of resources to help folks understand better what is going on in Colombia and connect the issues here with the issues elsewhere.

Accompaniment is hard to explain. Below is a brief narrative that sheds some light on our work as accompaniers with Tierra Digna:

Julia, on an accompaniment trip to Cesar, talks with a member of Tierra Digna to review the agenda of the meeting they have made with the corporations responsible for the local mines. Tierra Digna is working with a community where the mine has made the water and land too contaminated for people to continue sustaining themselves fishing and planting crops as they’ve historically done. Representatives from the mining companies have been passing by the area more recently, and Tierra Digna has made this meeting to express their concern about the area; the same companies are often accused of working with the area’s violent armed actors who intimidate workers and threaten and harass local communities living on valuable land. While Julia won’t present the case, she will introduce herself as an international observer, letting the corporation know that Tierra Digna and the community aren’t alone.

That same day, Michaela, from Austria, conducts meetings with the Colombian government and the Germany Embassy. She has made the meetings to express her concerns about a corporation accused of violating its environmental license by illegally dumped vast quantities of coal into the ocean while trying to load it onto its ships for export. The tons of coal further contaminated an already vulnerable marine eco-system as well as the traditional fishing communities that depend on them.

Peter, a team member who has already completed his service and is now doing conflict mediation work in London, is working with the current team to organize a delegation that will make the connection between the people consuming coal in Germany and the communities affected by large-scale coal mining on Colombia’s Caribbean Coast.

Risks & Challenges

Doing this work in Colombia means dealing with a changing political situation, security factors and capacity of the organizations and communities we accompany as well as our own. Colombia's conflict includes three armed groups with different and changing interests and in this case, corporations are also involved. Our team is constantly analyzing the political context to ensure that we are able to do the work by using dissuasion and providing protection rather than put people in danger. In any moment, the context could change in the region where Tierra Digna works, causing us to reconsider how and when we accompany. Additionally, these struggles always require more time and energy than communities and organizations have. A risk to fulfilling the work is the fact that there are only so many hours in a day.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Join upcoming delegation to Colombia February 21-March 6, 2015
  • Speaking tours: We're on tour with Tierra Digna in the U.S. now - please check out our tour page for more information
  • Join our team
  • Sign-up for email updates: Contact candice [at]peacepresence.org to be added to our email list!
  • Also, please help us get the word out about this campaign via Facebook, Twitter, email, etc.! With your help, we can demand justice, corporate accountability and say no to an industry that is not only destroying communities and the environment in Colombia, but is also the single greatest threat facing our global climate!

    Support us and stand with Tierra Digna to defend communities saying “no” to corporate supremacy and standing up to protect the environment and their communities.

Other Ways You Can Help




Join upcoming delegation to Colombia February 21-March 6, 2015

Sign-up for email updates: Contact candice [at]peacepresence.org to be added to our email list!
Also, please help us get the word out about this campaign via Facebook, Twitter, email, etc.! With your help, we can demand justice, corporate accountability and say no to an industry that is not only destroying communities and the environment in Colombia, but is also the single greatest threat facing our global climate!Support us and stand with Tierra Digna to defend communities saying “no” to corporate supremacy and standing up to protect the environment and their communities.

story:
Our Story

I've served in education for 13 years and am ready for a change. For several generations, my family farmed our land in Tennessee, and last summer, I decided to return to those roots. My life partner and I are currently in the process of building an organic hydroponic farm where we will grow tomatoes, cucumbers, cauliflower, lettuce, spinach, and beans. The building we will use has been part of the property for many years and has served many purposes, and with 2,400 square feet, it has plenty of room to get the farm productive. We intend on building more facilities as we move forward and also plan to install solar panels as we grow so that we are minimizing our energy consumption and creating a self-sufficient environment for the farm. Long-term, we want the farm to be a model for sustainability in the Tennessee Valley.


The Impact

Organic farming has been slow to come to Tennessee, while traditional farming has been in decline for decades. We want to restore the local agricultural base to this area by creating a blueprint for other farmers to follow and stimulate awareness in the areas of sustainability, environmental conservation, and energy efficiency. Currently, there is a growing demand for fresh organic produce in this area but not enough local farms to supply this demand. We also want to provide agricultural jobs that pay a living wage to our employees and offer opportunities for them to live well.


Our purpose for choosing hydroponics as our primary growing medium is because of efficiency. Hydroponic farming utilizes 90% less water than traditional in-ground farming. Also, hydroponic farms can produce significantly higher yields per acre because the plants tend to grow faster and bloom earlier. Long-term, because of this efficiency hydroponics has the potential to revolutionize global food production and end famine.


Additionally, our region in East Tennessee has some of the worst obesity rates in the nation, both adult and juvenile, and we both want to reduce these rates by increasing awareness. We plan to educate as many people as we can about the benefits of fresh, unprocessed foods by developing partnerships with local school districts.


What We Need & What You Get

Currently, our two biggest needs for startup are materials to renovate the building for indoor growing and then the equipment for the hydroponic units. The building has sat unused for 16 years, and while the foundation and frame are still in excellent shape, the walls and ceiling need insulation and new wood, which will cost nearly $1,000. Each hydroponic unit requires a lighting system, irrigation, timers, and sensors to maintain efficient operation at an average cost of roughly $2,000 per unit. As an educator, I don't earn much and need help with the initial startup capital to get the building and first unit operational. My goal is to have it running by mid-May.


Please, donate what you can afford to help us launch this farm. Along the way, I will post many more updates to keep you informed of our progress. Your donation will help create a more environmentally friendly future.


Other Ways You Can Help

Share our link with your friends, family, and co-workers. If you are interested in the environment and sustainable agriculture, please help us make this small step forward a reality.

The building we will use has been part of the property for many years and has served many purposes, and with 2,400 square feet, it has plenty of room to get the farm productive. We intend on building more facilities as we move forward and also plan to install solar panels as we grow so that we are minimizing our energy consumption and creating a self-sufficient environment for the farm. Long-term, we want the farm to be a model for sustainability in the Tennessee Valley.


The Impact
Organic farming has been slow to come to Tennessee, while traditional farming has been in decline for decades. We want to restore the local agricultural base to this area by creating a blueprint for other farmers to follow and stimulate awareness in the areas of sustainability, environmental conservation, and energy efficiency. Currently, there is a growing demand for fresh organic produce in this area but not enough local farms to supply this demand. We also want to provide agricultural jobs that pay a living wage to our employees and offer opportunities for them to live well.

Our purpose for choosing hydroponics as our primary growing medium is because of efficiency. Hydroponic farming utilizes 90% less water than traditional in-ground farming. Also, hydroponic farms can produce significantly higher yields per acre because the plants tend to grow faster and bloom earlier. Long-term, because of this efficiency hydroponics has the potential to revolutionize global food production and end famine.

Additionally, our region in East Tennessee has some of the worst obesity rates in the nation, both adult and juvenile, and we both want to reduce these rates by increasing awareness. We plan to educate as many people as we can about the benefits of fresh, unprocessed foods by developing partnerships with local school districts.


What We Need & What You Get
Currently, our two biggest needs for startup are materials to renovate the building for indoor growing and then the equipment for the hydroponic units. The building has sat unused for 16 years, and while the foundation and frame are still in excellent shape, the walls and ceiling need insulation and new wood, which will cost nearly $1,000. Each hydroponic unit requires a lighting system, irrigation, timers, and sensors to maintain efficient operation at an average cost of roughly $2,000 per unit. As an educator, I don't earn much and need help with the initial startup capital to get the building and first unit operational. My goal is to have it running by mid-May.

Please, donate what you can afford to help us launch this farm. Along the way, I will post many more updates to keep you informed of our progress. Your donation will help create a more environmentally friendly future.


Other Ways You Can Help
Share our link with your friends, family, and co-workers. If you are interested in the environment and sustainable agriculture, please help us make this small step forward a reality.

story:
My name is Frank Martinelli and I am an actor and philanthropist based out of Los Angeles and New York City. My mission is to continue to raise awareness with E.P.I.C., Everyday People Initiating Change, to bring clean water to under developed villages in Africa. So far E.P.I.C has drilled 7 water wells. Our goal is to visit all 7 locations where they have drilled, and implement hygiene/sanitation programs.  The water wells are in Kawe, Weru, Mangalali, a village in Arusha, and two hamlets in Ugele. We will also be scouting locations for the 8th and 9th wells.  This will be my first trip to Africa as the past few years have had extenuating circumstances prevent me from attending. I have been involved with this charity since 2006 and I am a recent board member.  This is a grassroots organization and 100 percent of the donations go directly to the cause so I am asking your help and support in getting me there.. 

We have a film crew joining us to document every step of our trip hoping to raise awareness of the tremendous injustice plaguing the developing world.  Did you know that their are still 1.1 Billion People in the world who do not have access to clean water?   And every day 4,000 children are affected by water related diseases.

By supporting me on my journey to Tanzania, I hope to raise awareness to the real problems crippling the developing world: disease, lack of access to basic needs, poor nutrition and death. This cause is extremely important to me for several reasons. First and foremost it was started by two dear friends who had a passion to make a difference and opened so many eyes to perils around the world. Also because as Westerners we take for granted something as simple as being able to pour a glass of water from the sink or take a shower at our leisure and I felt it was necessary to help spread the word about the struggles going on around the world. These are things that these villagers cannot even dream of.  We are incredibly fortunate to have access to organic foods and clean water when in some villages in Tanzania the locals have to walk 7 miles to collect 1 bucket of DIRTY water. The average family is lucky if they can get 4 gallons total....As Americans we average 50 GALLONS PER PERSON! 

Water Facts -There are still 1.1 billion people in the world who do not have access to clean drinking water. 1.8 million children die every year as a result of diseases caused by unclean water and poor sanitation - this amounts to around 5000 deaths a day. More people die each year from unsafe water than from all forms of violence, including war.

E.P.I.C. (Everyday People Initiating Change) is an organization my dear friends formed to show people from all walks of life that we have the ability to make a difference. As everyday people, WE can initiate the change that all the world’s nations are hungering for, and there is no better day to start than TODAY!  I am honored to be on the board of E.P.I.C and I am elated to embark on my first journey to Africa so I ask you to please donate, big or small, to my trip to Tanzania.

I am using the money donated to:

    * Book the flight to Tanzania

    * Survival gear

    * Get vaccines necessary

    * Help to provide fruits, vegetables and proteins to host family

 

REMEMBER YOU AREN'T JUST DONATING TO HELP ME, YOU'RE DONATING TO HELP MANY PEOPLE IN NEED.

  

Other Ways You Can Help:

Some people may not be able to contribute, but that doesn’t mean YOU can’t help:

    * Please get the word out about my campaign.

    *Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

    * Check out http://www.epicthemovement.org/

 

AND ASK YOURSELF...WHAT HAVE YOU DONE TODAY?

story:
Short Summary

Mt Kilimandjaro and Mt Kenya are not the only places in Africa where snow and glaciers can be found. The Rwenzori Mountains, the legendary 'Mountains of the Moon' located along the border between Uganda and the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and often considered as the highest source of the (White) Nile, deserve much more scientific attention than they currently receive. During the last centuries, this rugged, remote and high-altitude mountain range which includes Africa's third highest peak (Mount Margherita: 5,109 m) and where some of the last African ice fields are fast receding, is probably one of the least documented glaciated areas around the tropics.

Through this international, exploratory expedition, we plan to start a surveying study of the current state of Rwenzori glaciers and of the microbiological communities associated to them. Through your contribution, our results will lay ground for knowledge and future research on glacier and biological sensitivity to climate change in high-altitude, tropical regions.

The Impact

Glacier ressearch in the Mountains of Rwenzori, where some of the last African glaciers are fast receding at about 5,000 m altitude, and where environmental and climatic data are severely lacking, will contribute to retrieving invaluable information:

  • on the past and present dynamics of tropical glaciers;
  • on the factors behind sensitivity to climate change of high-altitude ecosystems;
  • on the future challenges facing local communities who are depending on meltwater supply from glaciers for their own living.

Given the limited period of time before these glaciers disappear entirely (max. 10 to 20 years from now), this project will be a unique opportunity to investigate, before they melt completely, the invaluable body of information retained in them.

Yes, you can contribute to glacier science right now!

story:
Thank you | Dhanyabad!

 

With the help of 53 funders we successfully raised over $3,400! We are overwhelmed by the gracious comments and support our team recieved. We are now excited for the next steps toward making Kathmandu greener and we will start with fulfilling YOUR PERKS - consisting of creating a mural, seed bombs, environmental graffiti and a few garden beds! Stay posted on our progress via the Hariyo Chowk Facebook page (www.facebook.com/HariyoChowk)!  

 

Grateful + Gardening,

 

- Hariyo Chowk Team

 

 

 

Who We Are

Sattya Media Arts Collective in Kathmandu Nepal has set out to transform a space into a modern adaption of a traditional chowk - Hariyo Chowk. Hariyo Chowk or 'green square' is an area to learn and share about urban greening and how to create a socially sustainable future for Kathmandu. 

Hariyo Chowk has been made possible with a multifaceted team of passionately dedicated people knowledgeable about sustainable architecture, design, organic farming, photography, and media. Aside from our hired team, the 'green square' has come into fruition with help from dozens of volunteers, students, organizations, and volunteer teachers that have supported us since we began in the Spring of 2012. 

Why Kathmandu?

As Kathmandu rapidly urbanizes there are fewer and fewer green spaces left in the city once known for urban farming. Air quality, pollution, and lack of electricity are daily problems for locals. Hariyo Chowk has the potential to grow a sustainable future with Kathmandu by empowering its people with environmental awareness, social sustainability and urban greening knowledge specific to the region's problems and resources. 

Things We Have Done

So many people have helped us bloom to where we are today. With our initial fundraiser we were able to raise $12,000, which we have been using resourcefully towards construction, administration, workshop costs and salaries. Specifically Hariyo Chowk has:

  • Designed and constructed our own green space to near completion. Hariyo Chowk's home base is used for holding fun and educational workshops, gardening, and documentary screening.
  • Built affordably with recycled and natural materials:
    - an outdoor urbanite pavilion
    - a bamboo structure for vertical gardening
    - a garden for native, edible, and medicinal plants
    - a compost bin to manage food waste and produce fertilizer
    - a workshop area for arts and education
    - a rainwater collection system to reduce reliance on city water
    - a sunken fire pit for outdoor gatherings 
    - an earthen oven made out of mud bricks
  • Maintained media coverage via Facebook on our process and gained a following of over 1000 people.
  • Built relationships with community and local organizations
  • Held events and workdays for local community, youth and organization groups.

Our Campaign Goal

Hariyo Chowk has has spent the last 8 months creating our own green space, a hub for the community to learn and practice sustainable gardening and building. We have been working resourcefully with existing contributions and will be celebrating our grand opening in March 2013. We are envisioning a new season to begin in April, in which we want to grow in two specific ways:

  • To become financially self-sustained within Kathmandu. We will make this possible by selling plants and seed at markets, forging relationships with local organizations, and hosting affordable workshops, events, film screenings and even parties. 
  • To make Kathmandu greener with guerrilla gardening, having workdays during which we will maintain existing public green spaces, aid people in start-up of community gardens and more edible plants, and starting a seed bank and library of native plant knowledge.

What We Need

With a little extra watering, and $5,000 though Indiegogo, we will be able to take root
in our own space, and start greening the city. Specially the $5,000 will go toward:

  • Investing in a few good tools
  • Expansion into new locations which will require rent
  • Providing modest salaries for our dedicated team 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools to help get Hariyo Chowk support
  • Start where you stand and gureilla garden within your own community

Hariyo Chowk is a community project and we are extreamly grateful to have the fruits of our labour and community grow with your support!

Start where you stand and gureilla garden within your own community


Hariyo Chowk is a community project and we are extreamly grateful to have the fruits of our labour and community grow with your support!
